The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: A PARAPHRASE UPON THE BOOKS OF ECCLESIASTES AND THE SONG of SOLOMON. WITH ARGUMENTS to each Chapter, and ANNOTATIONS thereupon.
By SYMON PATRICK D. D. Now Lord Bi≈øhop of Ely.
LONDON, Printed by W. H. for Luke Meredith at the Star in St. Paul's Church-Yard, MDCC.

div.head: To the Right Reverend Father in God and the no le≈øs Honourable HENRY, Lord BISHOP of LONDON, one of His MAJESTY'S mo≈øt Honourable Privy Council.
div.p: WE ≈øee in Your Lord≈øhip ≈øuch a plain and familiar Example of that Wi≈ødom which SOLOMON preaches in the Book of ECCLESIASTES, that I am invited thereby to this boldne≈øs of prefixing Your Lord≈øhip's Name before the Paraphra≈øe I have made upon it, and upon the Book that follows it.

A Wi≈ødom, which hath rai≈øed Your Mind above the deceitfulne≈øs of Riches, and of all Worldly Glories: a Divine Wi≈ødom, which hath rai≈øed You above your ≈øelf; and made the faithful ≈øervice of God, and of the King, the ≈øole ≈øcope of all Your Endeavours.

It is a token ≈øurely of the Divine favour towards us, and ought to be reckoned
among the felicities of our Sovereign's Reign, that a Vertue ≈øo active and laborious in doing good, is placed in ≈øuch a wide and capacious Sphere, as that wherein Your Lord≈øhip moves. From whence Your influences are no le≈øs powerful than they are benign: ≈øtirring us up to indu≈øtry, and quickning us, by Your own great Example, to do our Duties uprightly and unweariedly in our ≈øeveral Stations.

Some ≈ømall ≈øervice I hope I have performed in the Explication of the≈øe two holy Books. In the fir≈øt of which (according to the ancient Opinion) the foundation is laid for a due progre≈øs unto the other: the Mind not being fitted for ≈øuch ≈øublime thoughts, as lye hid under the Figures, in the Book of Canticles, till it hath learnt by the Eccle≈øia≈øtes, the vanity of all earthly Enjoyments; and, by looking down upon them with contempt, be di≈øpo≈øed to value heavenly Ble≈ø≈øings. To this
purpo≈øe Origen di≈øcour≈øes in his Preface to the Song of Songs.

Which is a Depth into which I have adventured to dive, though it hath been famous, as one ≈øpeaks, for the ≈øhipwrack of many great Pilots: who went too far, as I conceive, and ≈øought for more there than is to be found; and therefore mi≈øcarried. Which Rock I have carefully avoided; and ≈øteered my Cour≈øe by ≈øuch a clear and certain Direction (which I thought I e≈øpied in other holy Writings) that if I have kept my eye ≈øtedfa≈øtly fixt upon it, I am ≈øatisfied hath not mi≈øled me, but carried me to the right ≈øen≈øe of this admirable Piece of Divine Poetry.

Which I tru≈øt I have made ≈øo evident, that if the Readers will ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øider the Ri≈øe and Ground I have taken for my Expo≈øition: even they who have made bold to prophane this Book with their wanton imaginations, will hereafter look upon it with reverence.

If in any Part of this difficult Work, I have mi≈øtaken my way Your Lord≈øhip I know hath the Goodne≈øs, not only to pardon the errours of my weakne≈øs, but, to accept of the ≈øincerity of my endeavours to do Honour to the Holy Scriptures: by repre≈øenting them, to the be≈øt of my power, in their native Beauty, that is ≈øimplicity, unto the eyes of tho≈øe, who have the heart to make them their Study.

Praying God to continue Your Lord≈øhip a long Ble≈ø≈øing to this Church, by Your prudent, ≈øteady and obliging Conduct, in the Government of us, who have the happine≈øs to be under Your particular care; I remain,

closer.signed: Your mo≈øt humble and dutiful Servant, S. Patrick.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: I. THis Book not carrying in the front of it the expre≈øs Name of SOLOMON, it hath emboldned ≈øome to take the liberty of intitling other Authors to it. Hezekiah, for in≈øtance, whom the Talmudi≈øts make to ≈øpeak tho≈øe Words in the entrance of it, The words of the Preacher, &c. Or I≈øaiah, as R. Mo≈øes Kimchi, with ≈øome other Jews, fan≈øie: Or, to name no more, Zorobabel, whom Grotius (in his Notes upon Chap. XII. 11.) conjectures to have appointed certain men to make this Collection. For ≈øo he would have the word COHELETH tran≈ølated, a Collector; or Heaper up of Opinions, rather than a Preacher.

II. But there are ≈øo many pa≈ø≈øages in the Book which agree to none but Solomon, that it is a wonder ≈øo great a man as Grotius ≈øhould be led away from the common Opinion, by ≈øuch ≈ølight rea≈øons, as I ≈øhall pre≈øently mention. For in≈øtance, there never was any Body that could truly ≈øpeak tho≈øe words which we read v. 16. of the fir≈øt Chapter, but only Solomon. For neither Hezekiah, nor Jo≈øiah, nor Zorobabel kept ≈øuch great State, as he did, much le≈øs excelled him in Wi≈ødom. And who but he could boa≈øt of ≈øuch things as are mentioned
Chap. II. v. 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9. to repre≈øent the ≈øplendour wherein he lived, above all that had been before him in Jeru≈øalem? Or, on the contrary, Who had ≈øuch rea≈øon as he, to make that ≈øad complaint (Chap. VII. 26, &c.) of the mi≈øchief he had received by Women? And to omit the re≈øt, tho≈øe words in the la≈øt Chapter, v. 9, 10. can belong to none but him, who ≈øet in order many Proverbs, as appears in the foregoing Book.

III. Which things are ≈øo convincing, that Grotius is forced to acknowledge that Zorobabel cau≈øed this Book to be compo≈øed in the Name of King Solomon (for he was no King him≈øelf, but a Governour under the King of Per≈øia) repenting of his former vain and ≈øinful life. Which very acknowledgment carries in it a plain ≈øolution of the principal Argument, whereby he was led to this odd Opinion: Which is, that he finds ≈øome words in this Book, that are no where to be met withal, but in Daniel and Ezra, and the Chaldee Interpreters. Which makes it probable, he thinks, that it was written after their Captivity in Babylon. But ≈øuppo≈øing Solomon to write here as a Penitent, after he had frequented the Company of many Outlandi≈øh Women (of whom we read 1 Kings XI. 1, 2.) it need not ≈øeem ≈øtrange to us that he had learnt the u≈øe of many of their words. And ≈øo, notwith≈øtanding this Objection, he may ≈øtill be thought to have been the Author of this Book him≈øelf: which the Hebrews generally conceive to have been written by him, towards the end of his Reign; after he had tried all manner of plea≈øures,
even to an exce≈øs. Be≈øides, in other Books of Scripture there are words, for the ≈øignification of which we are fain to have re≈øort unto other languages; and particularly the Arabick; becau≈øe they are not to be found el≈øewhere in the Scripture: and yet, for all that, might be pure Hebrew, according to the language which was then ≈øpoken, when ≈øuch Books were written.

IV. But it is not fit to ≈øtay any longer, in the confutation of ≈øuch a weak rea≈øon as this; which hath no force in it (though it be the be≈øt he hath) to make us think of any other Author of this Book, than Solomon. Who, if he did not write it him≈øelf it is certain ≈øpake the things contained in it: and calls him≈øelf the PREACHER, becau≈øe of the great gravity and dignity of the Subject, whereof he treats; of which he was wont to ≈øpeak frequently (Chap. XII. 9.) de≈øiring it might be under≈øtood and laid to heart, by the whole Congregation of I≈ørael; as the Word Coheleth ≈øeems to import; which in the Aethiopick language ≈øignifies a Circle, or a Company of men gathered together, in the form of a Circle, as Ludolphus hath lately ob≈øerved. For the ≈øcope of this Di≈øcour≈øe is concerning the chief Good or happine≈øs of man: the great end he ≈øhould propo≈øe to him≈øelf all his life long. Which is not that, he ≈øhows, which men generally follow: but that which is generally neglected. For mo≈øt men mind nothing, but ju≈øt what is before them: which they will find at la≈øt, as he had done by ≈øad experience, to be mere vanity; utterly unable to quiet their minds.
Which mu≈øt therefore ≈øeek for ≈øatisfaction in ≈øomething el≈øe; and, after all their bu≈øie thoughts, de≈øigns and labours come to this Conclu≈øion, that to fear God and keep his Commandments, is the happine≈øs of man: who ought therefore to u≈øe all the plea≈øures of this World (which is the only Good it can afford us) with a con≈øtant re≈øpect to the future account, we mu≈øt all make to God.

V. This, it appears by the beginning and the end of this Book, is the Scope of it. ∆≤nto which they that will not attend, are wont to pick out here and there a loo≈øe Sentence, which agrees with their de≈øires; and then plea≈øe them≈øelves with a fancy that they have got Solomon on their ≈øide, to help to maintain their infidelity: Not con≈øidering what he a≈ø≈øerts directly contrary, in other places. Where he pre≈ø≈øes the greate≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øerious reverence to Almighty God, IV. 17. V. 1, 2, &c. VIII. 12, 13. XII. 13. together with a remembrance of the future Judgment, III. 17. XI. 9. XII. 14. Works of mercy and charity al≈øo, whereby we may do good to others, XI. 1, 2, &c. and the contempt of tho≈øe frivolous plea≈øures, which draw our hearts from God and from good works, II. 2. VII. 2, &c. All which plainly ≈øhew, that tho≈øe words which ≈øeem to countenance men in their neglect of Religion, and open a Gap to licentiou≈øne≈øs, are only Opinions which he intends to confute, according to the method he had propounded to him≈øelf in this Book. Wherein he fir≈øt repre≈øents the various ends men drive at; which in the very entrance of it (that men might not mi≈øtake his meaning) he pronounces
to be ≈øo vain; that he had not words ≈øignificant enough to expre≈øs their vanity; and then, their different Opinions about God, and his Providence, and their own ≈øouls: and what thoughts he him≈øelf had to≈ø≈øed up and down in his mind; which at la≈øt came to that re≈øolution I mentioned before, wherewith he ends his Book. In the clo≈øe of which, to give the greater weight unto what he had ≈øaid, he adds this: That the≈øe were not only the re≈øult of his own thoughts, but the judgment of other Wi≈øe men, with whom he had con≈øulted.

Let no man therefore deceive him≈øelf (to u≈øe the grave words of Ca≈øtalio) as ≈øome, I wi≈øh I could ≈øay a few, have done: who not minding the end and drift of this Book, but having met with ≈øome one place in it that ≈øeems to favour their beloved lu≈øts, lay hold on that Scrap alone; and with that endeavour to defend their licentious cour≈øe of life. As if they expected, they ≈øhould find God ju≈øt ≈øuch a Judge hereafter, as they are of them≈øelves at pre≈øent.
VI. To compri≈øe all in a few words. The ≈øen≈øe of the whole Sermon, as we may call it, ≈øeems to be comprehended in this Syllogi≈øm,

p.hi: What≈øoever is vain and peri≈øhing cannot make men happy;
But all mens de≈øigns here in this World are vain and peri≈øhing:
Therefore, They cannot by pro≈øecuting ≈øuch de≈øigns make them≈øelves happy.

div.p:
The Propo≈øition is evident in it ≈øelf; and needs no Proof. The A≈ø≈øumption therefore he demon≈øtrates
in the ≈øix fir≈øt Chapters, by an enumeration of Particulars; as I ≈øhall ≈øhew in the Argument before, or Annotations upon, each Chapter: And then proceeds, in the re≈øt of the Book, to advi≈øe men unto the be≈øt cour≈øe to make them≈øelves happy; evidently proving all along from this incon≈øtancy and vanity of all things here, that he who wi≈øhes well to him≈øelf, ought to rai≈øe his mind above them, to the Creator of the World: and, expecting to give an account to Him, ≈øo to demean him≈øelf in the u≈øe of all earthly enjoyments, that he devoutly acknowledge his Divine Maje≈øty, fearing, and wor≈øhipping Him, and doing his Will.

Such indeed is the dulne≈øs of Mankind, that, hearing all was but vanity, they might condemn every thing as evil and hurtful; and declaim too bitterly again≈øt this World. Which was ≈øo far from Solomon's intention, that having explained the vanity of all our injoyments here, and the vanity of humane cares, ≈øolicitous de≈øires and endeavours; he per≈øwades all men to be content with things pre≈øent, to give God thanks for them, to u≈øe them freely with quiet minds: living as plea≈øantly, and taking as much liberty, as the remembrance of a future account will allow; void of anxious and trouble≈øome thoughts, what will become of them hereafter in this life.

VII. But it may not be ami≈øs perhaps to give a larger account of this Sermon; and let the Reader ≈øee in what method it proceeds. For many men imagine it to be a confu≈øed Di≈øcour≈øe, which doth
not hang together: and therefore have explained this Book, only by giving an account of the meaning of each Ver≈øe; as if it were a di≈øtinct Sentence, independant on the re≈øt; like tho≈øe in his Proverbs. But Antonius Corranus, a mo≈øt excellent per≈øon, in a ≈ømall Di≈øcour≈øe of his upon this Book, written above an hundred years ago; hath drawn ≈øuch a Scheme of it, as I believe will ≈øatisfie tho≈øe who con≈øider it, that Solomon proceeds after an exact order, to deduce what he intended. And therefore I will tran≈ølate the ≈øen≈øe of what he ≈øaith, into Engli≈øh; which is to this purpo≈øe:

VIII. The de≈øign of the Author is to find out and to ≈øhew, What it is, in which the chief good and compleat felicity of man doth con≈øi≈øt. As appears by this, that reflecting upon various things in which men place their happine≈øs; at the end of his Di≈øcour≈øe upon every one of them, he rejects them as utterly in≈øufficient for that purpo≈øe: but continues his ≈øearch ≈øo far till at la≈øt he finds it, and declares in the concluding Epiphonema, that he had been ≈øeeking it, through the whole Di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øaying, the ≈øumm of the matter is this, Fear God, and keep his Commandments, for this is the whole of man.

Now there are two principal Parts of the whole Sermon, The fir≈øt of which contains a recital, and confutation, of mens fal≈øe Opinions about their Chiefe≈øt Good: the other teaches, in what our genuine, true and ≈øolid felicity lies; both in this life, and in the next. In both he ≈øhows very deligently, what is the end to which a man ≈øhould
direct all his Coun≈øels, Studies and Endeavours, what he ought to follow, as mo≈øt de≈øirable above all things; and what to avoid, as the extreame≈øt of evils.

Of the fir≈øt of the≈øe he treats in his VI. fir≈øt Chapters; of the other in as many more that follow. Which is both a per≈øpicuous and exact method. For being to treat of felicity, it was but fitting he ≈øhould divide it into fal≈øe, and true; and then define aright what that true felicity is. For we mu≈øt fir≈øt ≈øhun that which is evil, and then pur≈øue that which is good: according to the frequent admonitions we meet withal in the holy Prophets.

div.head: The fir≈øt Part.
div.p: IX. Now the fir≈øt part of his Sermon relies upon a Propo≈øition, which no body denies, viz. That vain, frail and trouble≈øome things cannot make any man happy: And ≈øuch ≈øaith he in the very fir≈øt words of the Book, are all things here, Vanity of Vanities; i. e. extremely vain.

Which A≈ø≈øumption it may ≈øeem hard to prove, if we con≈øider what account blind Mortals make of their own inventions, coun≈øels, ≈øtudies and labours, by which they think to attain felicity. But to Solomon nothing was more ea≈øie; who having made a full and long experiment of all enjoyments here, mo≈øt evidently demon≈øtrates this by an enumeration of Parts, and that in an apt, per≈øpicuous, and compendious order. For he neither confounds the
parts; nor too curiou≈øly pur≈øues them; nor mentions all the fal≈øe Opinions of men about the chiefe≈øt Good (which would have been too tedious, if like Varro he had told us of two hundred, eighty five, and yet that he could not reckon all) but reducing the mo≈øt probable Opinions unto four principal Heads, he confutes them by various Arguments; drawn chiefly from adjuncts and effects.

The fir≈øt is of tho≈øe who place Ble≈ø≈øedne≈øs in the knowledge of natural things, and in humane Wi≈ødom, which begins at the 12th. Ver≈øe of the fir≈øt Chapter, and reaches to the beginning of the ≈øecond. For in the precedent Ver≈øes, he only lays a foundation for his Di≈øcour≈øe, and plains his way to the proof of what he intended.

The ≈øecond is of tho≈øe who place it in plea≈øure; which he di≈øpatches, as unworthy of a long confutation, in the three fir≈øt Ver≈øes of the ≈øecond Chapter. But there being tho≈øe of this Sect, who joining the≈øe two together, plea≈øure and knowledge, imagine they will make up a complete happine≈øs; he ≈øpends more time in ≈øhowing their Vanity; from the 4th Ver≈øe of the ≈øecond Chapter, to the 16th Ver≈øe of the third: interpo≈øing only a Parenthe≈øis, wherein he compares Wi≈ødom with Folly; and from the effects of both ≈øhews how much the former is to be preferred before the latter.

The third touches tho≈øe who think Honours, Magi≈øtracies, and Power in the Commonwealth, to be the highe≈øt of all Goods. In which number are they, who ≈øeek to extend their Empire, though it be by a va≈øt effu≈øion of their own Subjects blood;
by which means al≈øo they e≈øtabli≈øh their tyranny. when they have acquired it. Which di≈øputation reaches from the 16th Ver≈øe of the third Chapter, to the 9th Ver≈øe of the fifth. Yet ≈øo, that from the beginning of the fourth Chapter to the 13th Ver≈øe of the ≈øame, he in≈øerts the mi≈øeries that grow from ≈øuch tyrannical admini≈øtration; and the Vices which break in, upon the impunity of evil Doers, and neglect of the Laws. Particularly, he gives us a lively de≈øcription, of Emulation, and Covetou≈øne≈øs: two of the foule≈øt and mo≈øt cruel pe≈øts of the Commonwealth. In the fifth Chapter al≈øo he in≈øerts a Di≈øcour≈øe of that ≈øuper≈øtitious and vain Wor≈øhip of God; in which ≈øome, de≈øpi≈øing all other things, place their ≈øatisfaction: and mo≈øt lamentably applaud them≈øelves in it. Which Di≈øputation contains in it ≈øome excellent Precepts of true Religion and Piety; which the Reader may find, in the fir≈øt eight Ver≈øes of the fifth Chapter.

After which follows the fourth Opinion of tho≈øe who propound to them≈øelves Riches and Wealth as their la≈øt end: which if they can attain, they doubt not they ≈øhall live very happily. Which extends it ≈øelf from thence to the 11th Ver≈øe of the ≈øixth Chapter; where you have the general Epilogue of the fir≈øt Part, concerning fal≈øe felicity.

div.head: The other Part.
div.p:
X. Then follows the ≈øecond, and mo≈øt Elegant as well as u≈øeful part of the Sermon. In which
he teaches, that the felicity, for which men take ≈øo much pains (every one going his own way to it) is not to be found any where, but in a religious and ≈øerious fear of God: according to that of the P≈øalmi≈øt, Ble≈ø≈øed are all they that fear the Lord; that walk in his ways; and again, Ble≈ø≈øed is the man that feareth the Lord; that delighteth greatly in his Commandments. For other things; though they promi≈øe felicity, yet they cannot perform it; becau≈øe they have ≈øuch a mixture of vanity, trouble and grief with them, as will not ≈øuffer them to be ab≈øolutely good; and becau≈øe, if they were ≈øincere, yet they being ≈øo uncertain that they may be lo≈øt before we dye, and at the be≈øt are terminated within the narrow Bounds of this ≈øhort life; they cannot give that ≈øatisfaction and quiet of mind, which we de≈øire. But the fear of God is ≈øuch a Good that it both gives true contentment, ≈øatisfaction and tranquility of mind, as long as we live; and when we die, fills us with a ≈øure hope of a better life: in which true and genuine felicity is accompli≈øhed.
For the ≈øumm of what can be ≈øaid in this matter, may be reduced to this Argumentation:
That which can make a mans mind quiet, ≈øtill and calm, both in life and death; that alone can make him happy;
Now this the Fear of the Lord can do for him, and this alone:
Therefore this, and nothing el≈øe, will make him a happy man.

The Propo≈øition needs no Proof; For then we feel our ≈øelves happy, when our minds are ≈øo quiet and well plea≈øed; that they neither grieve, nor fear, nor ≈øolicitou≈øly de≈øire, nor vainly hope for uncertain things: but re≈øt ≈øatisfied in that excellent and mo≈øt certain joy and hope, which ari≈øes out of a pure Con≈øcience.

The A≈ø≈øumption is proved from two effects of the Fear of God, viz. Wi≈ødom and Ju≈øtice. The fir≈øt of which teaches us what to follow, and what to fly: and furni≈øhes us with ≈øuch caution, that we be not impo≈øed on, in the choice of that which ≈øeems to be good for us. The other in≈øtructs us to do our whole Duty, towards God, towards our Neighbour, and towards our ≈øelves. And becau≈øe effects are more known than their cau≈øes, and it would be uncertain what he meant by the fear of God, unle≈øs he explained it by tho≈øe things wherein it con≈øi≈øts; he begins his Di≈øputation on this Subject with tho≈øe effects; and employs him≈øelf wholly in ≈øhewing what are the Offices of Wi≈ødom and Ju≈øtice: that he might inform us not only what is the Chief Good, to which we ought to a≈øpire; but by what ways and means we may come at it.

XI. Of Wi≈ødom and Prudence therefore, which is conver≈øant in the choice of things; he treats in the fir≈øt place; Chapter the Seventh: becau≈øe no man can act either righteou≈øly, or valiantly,

He explains therefore its various Offices in ≈øuch Documents as the≈øe; That a good Fame is to be de≈øired above all things; That Death ought to be the Subject of our frequent Meditations; That tho≈øe things are to be avoided, which incite to plea≈øure, and the contrary to be followed, which admoni≈øh us to be mode≈øt and ≈øober; That ≈øeverity and gravity are to be preferred before mirth; Cha≈øti≈øements and corrections to be willingly admitted; Flattery and ≈øoothing people to be ca≈øhiered; Not to be too much di≈øturbed at calumnies and reproaches; To take no Bribes; To expect the i≈ø≈øue and conclu≈øion of things; To bridle anger, as an Enemy to rea≈øon; To love the u≈øe of money, not mony it ≈øelf; and ≈øuch like. ∆≤nto which, la≈øt of all, he adjoins a brief commendation of Wi≈ødom; rejecting both the larger Explication of its effects, and its prai≈øes, to the end of the ninth Chapter, and beginning of the tenth.
Now this fir≈øt Part concerning Wi≈ødom, is handled in the twelve fir≈øt Ver≈øes of the ≈øeventh Chapter.

XII. Then he enters upon the other, concerning Ju≈øtice: which he divides into that which re≈øpects God, and that which re≈øpects men. The former of which (comprehended under the names
of Religion, Piety, and Godline≈øs) con≈øi≈øts in this: That in the fir≈øt place, we conceive aright and judge well of God, and of his Providence in the Admini≈øtration of humane Affairs; and then that we pay Him that Honour, Wor≈øhip and Service, which is due unto His Divine Maje≈øty.

This Di≈øcour≈øe, which he touches upon from the 13th to the 16th Ver≈øe of the VIIth Chapter he re≈øumes again in the VIIIth Chapter, and pur≈øues it from the 9th Ver≈øe of it, to the 13th Ver≈øe of the IXth Chapter.

As for that Ju≈øtice which re≈øpects others, it is manifold. For it is either towards men, or towards women: Which con≈øi≈øts, in a manner, altogether in ≈øhunning both the Extremes of it, and ob≈øerving an „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , moderation or equity; and hath re≈øpect to their offences, either again≈øt our ≈øelves or others: which we are partly to correct, and partly to bear withal. Where inter≈øper≈øing a few things, after his manner, in the prai≈øe of Wi≈ødom, he begins another Divi≈øion of Ju≈øtice: concerning the Duty of Subjects to their Princes, from the ≈øecond Ver≈øe to the eighth; and on the other ≈øide, the Duty of Princes towards their Subjects: of both which, it may be fit to give a larger account. For this Tractate is truly Royal, and worthy to be read perpetually, in this mo≈øt turbulent Age, both by high and low: That from hence Subjects may
learn to perform Obedience, and the greate≈øt ob≈øervance both in word and deed towards their Princes; chu≈øing rather to bear and ≈øuffer any thing, than to attempt Rebellion again≈øt them; and Kings may al≈øo remember, that they ought to govern their Kingdoms, according to the Rules of Law and Equity, and not according to their own will and plea≈øure; God having committed unto them the Scepter of Ju≈øtice, Clemency, and Welfare of their Subjects; not the Scepter of Cruelty, Tyranny, and De≈øtruction.

In which this Wi≈øe King ob≈øerving both Princes and People, to be too negligent, and that thence ari≈øeth a very great licen≈øe in ≈øinning, le≈øt well affected minds ≈øhould be offended at this horrible corruption of manners; he digre≈ø≈øeth into a long, but very profitable and nece≈ø≈øary Di≈øputation of God's Providence, and the Oeconomy of Ju≈øtice. Which though the wicked deny, and deride, becau≈øe they ≈øee not ≈øuch manife≈øt difference, as one would expect, made between the Good, and the Bad, in the Events that befal them both; yet he advi≈øes all that fear the Divine Maje≈øty not to be dejected and di≈øheartned at this; nor to ≈øearch with too much curio≈øity into God's ≈øecrets; but ≈øtedfa≈øtly re≈øolving, that it ≈øhall not be well with the wicked, though all things flow at pre≈øent according to their hearts de≈øire, and that what≈øoever the godly may ≈øuffer now, they ≈øhall find at la≈øt that God is their Friend; to look upon them≈øelves therefore as happy men, both in the peace of their Con≈øcience in this World,
and in a ≈øure and certain hope of a better condition in the other. ∆≤pon which account, he frequently inculcates this coun≈øel, That they who are ≈øtudious to fear God, and do well, being ≈øecure of God's Admini≈øtration and of the event of things, ≈øhould enjoy the pre≈øent good things, which his Divine Bounty be≈øtows upon them; with cheerful minds, and with thank≈øgiving to Him. This Di≈øcour≈øe (which it mu≈øt be confe≈ø≈øed is not altogether ≈øo methodical as ≈øome other) extends) from the 9th Ver≈øe of the eighth Chapter, to the 13th Ver≈øe of the ninth.

And becau≈øe he had ≈øhown, that the event of things is not in our own coun≈øel and in humane Wi≈ødom, but in the hand of God, le≈øt any body ≈øhould be ≈øo weak or perver≈øe, as thence to conclude, That it is the ≈øame thing, whether we act wi≈øely or fooli≈øhly; he again makes a Digre≈ø≈øion into the prai≈øes of Wi≈ødom; ≈øhowing how much it excells folly, from the effects of both. It begins at the 17th Ver≈øe, and reaches to the 4th of the tenth Chapter. Where he returns to his Di≈øcour≈øes, about the mutual Offices of Ju≈øtice between one another; both of Princes and Subjects.

And then in the ≈øix fir≈øt Ver≈øes of the eleventh Chapter, he exhorts mo≈øt earne≈øtly to Liberality, and Alm≈øgiving; which is no ≈ømall part of righteou≈øne≈øs. And with that he concludes the two effects of the Fear of God; Wi≈ødom and Ju≈øtice.

XIII. The re≈øt of the Work is his Peroration: in which he fully opens his Opinion concerning the Chief Good: which he confirms to
lie wholly in a truly religious Fear of God. Which therefore he ≈øeriou≈øly exhorts every one to make their ≈øtudy as early as is po≈ø≈øible: before dull and unactive Old Age, and Death it ≈øelf, (both which he elegantly de≈øcribes) come upon us, and, before we think of it, oppre≈øs us.

This is the method of this mo≈øt excellent Sermon: which I cannot but exhort all men to ≈øtudy diligently, and with great intention of mind; both for the Authors ≈øake, and for the matter of it. Which he handles in ≈øuch a manner, as fir≈øt to draw us from the de≈øire and love of earthly things; and from the perver≈øe u≈øe of them: and then to lead us unto the true and lawful u≈øe of them, without any offence to God, as well as without hurt to our ≈øelves. And he teaches us how we may, without a prepo≈øterous ≈øolicitude and anxiety about events, enjoy all things in the Fear of God; with tranquility and ≈øatisfaction of mind at pre≈øent; and at la≈øt, by the ≈øame Fear of God and ob≈øervance of his Commandments, arrive at a never-dying felicity.

To conclude, He inter≈øper≈øes through the whole Di≈øcour≈øe abundance of Common Places, both Philo≈øophical and Theological; which are ≈øo fitted to make us every way more learned, more prudent, and more pious; that we ≈øhall find great u≈øe of them in all the pa≈ø≈øages of our lives.

XIV. Thus that learned Spaniard concludes his Preface: which I have contracted, that I might ≈øet before the Readers eyes in one ≈øhort view, both the de≈øign and the procedure of the Di≈øcour≈øe.
Of the former (the De≈øign) there is no doubt: and the latter is very regular, as it will further appear, in the explication I ≈øhall give of it. Wherein I have not followed this Author throughout, in every Part of this Divi≈øion of the Book; becau≈øe, though for the mo≈øt part I take it to be accurate enough; yet, I think, in ≈øeveral places I had rea≈øon to differ from him; and take another way to make the connexion more ea≈øie and natural; and the ≈øen≈øe thereby more clear and evident.

I be≈øeech God, that the pains I have taken herein may not be in vain; but prove an effectual means both to make the mind of Solomon in this Book better under≈øtood; and to turn all our minds from the≈øe frivolous things, about which now they are too much employed, unto the ≈øolid and full Good which here he recommends to us. Who may be the better tru≈øted in what he ≈øaith; becau≈øe he had tried what ≈øatisfaction could be found in all manner of enjoyments here: and it could not be objected to him that he di≈øparaged the World, merely becau≈øe he could not get any ≈øhare in it, or had not the liberty which was nece≈ø≈øary to enjoy it. For no man ever had greater plenty, or gave a greater loo≈øe to his de≈øires; but, after all the experiments he could make, came to this re≈øolution which he had better have taken at fir≈øt; that Religion and Vertue are the only things can make a man happy.

And perhaps, as God ≈øuffered St. Thomas to doubt of our Saviour's Re≈øurrection, for the greater confirmation of our Faith; by the ≈øatisfaction
he at la≈øt received: ≈øo he let this great man go a≈øtray, that by his dear-bought experience he might teach us this Wi≈ødom; to keep the clo≈øer to God in faithful obedience.

Which it will be a very great ≈øhame, it we do not learn, who live under the in≈øtruction of a greater Ma≈øter than Solomon; the Son of God him≈øelf. By whom we are taught the≈øe things in a more effectual manner; not only by his Doctrine, but by his whole life, and by his death: in which he declared the greate≈øt neglect and contempt of this World; and that his mind was wholly ≈øet upon the other.

And what a ble≈ø≈øed ≈øort of Reformation would it be, if (as Era≈ømus ≈øomewhere admirably ≈øpeaks) we would all lay a≈øide our di≈ø≈øen≈øions, ≈øtrifes, and quarrels, and ≈øtudy the Le≈ø≈øons our Lord hath taught us. Who≈øe bu≈øine≈øs it was in this World, to form unto Him≈øelf a people that ≈øhould wholly depend on heaven, and placing no confidence in any Earthly ≈øupport or comfort, ≈øhould be after another manner rich, after another manner wi≈øe, after another manner noble, after another manner potent, in one word, after another manner happy: de≈øigning to attain felicity by the contempt of tho≈øe things, which are vulgarly admired. A people that ≈øhould be Strangers to filthy lu≈øts, by ≈øtudying in this fle≈øh the life of Angels; that ≈øhould have no need of Divorce, by being able to mend or to bear all manner of Evils; that ≈øhould be wholly ignorant of
Oaths, as tho≈øe who neither di≈øtru≈øt, nor will deceive any body; that make not the getting of Money their bu≈øine≈øs, having laid up their Trea≈øures in Heaven; that ≈øhould not be tickled with vain glory, becau≈øe they refer all to the Glory of Chri≈øt alone; be void of ambition, as di≈øpo≈øed, the greater they are, to ≈øubmit them≈øelves, ≈øo much the more, unto all men for Chri≈øt his ≈øake; that ≈øhould be unacquainted with wrath, much more with revenge, as ≈øtudying to de≈øerve well of tho≈øe who de≈øerve ill of them: that ≈øhould be ≈øo innocent in their behaviour, as to force commendations even from Heathens; that ≈øhould be born again to the purity and ≈øimplicity of Infants; that ≈øhould live like the Birds of the Air, without care and ≈øolicitude; among whom there ≈øhould be the greate≈øt concord, nothing different from that which is between the Members of the ≈øame Body; in which mutual Charity ≈øhould make all things common; that whether there were any good thing, it ≈øhould help to ≈øupply him that wanted, or any evil thing, it ≈øhould either be removed or mitigated by the good Offices of others; who ≈øhould be ≈øo wi≈øe by the teaching of the Holy Gho≈øt, ≈øo live according to the example of Chri≈øt, as to be the Salt of the Earth, the Light of the World, like a City on an Hill, con≈øpicuous to all the Country round about; who≈øe abilities, what≈øoever they are, ≈øhould make them forward to
help others; to whom this life ≈øhould ≈øeem vile, Death de≈øirable, out of a longing for immortality; who ≈øhould neither fear tyranny, nor death, nor the Devil him≈øelf, relying upon the invincible power of Chri≈øt alone; who ≈øhould act in all things ≈øo, as to be ever prepared and ready for that la≈øt, and mo≈øt to be wi≈øht for Day, when they ≈øhall take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of true and of eternal felicity.

argument.p: In the eleven fir≈øt Ver≈øes he lays the foundation of his following Di≈øcour≈øes, and makes his way to the proof of what he intends (viz. And then v. 12. he enters into a particular con≈øideration of the in≈øufficiency of humane Wi≈ødom and knowledge alone, to give us full ≈øatisfaction: though this be one of the very be≈øt things wherein men place their felicity. div.p: 1. THE words of the preacher, the Son of David King of Jeru≈øalem.

1. THe≈øe are the words of him, who thought the name of a Preacher, or Publick In≈øtructer of Gods people (to whom he calls aloud in this Book, to mind what he ≈øaith concerning the ≈øupreme Good of Man) no le≈øs honourable, than that of

[e]

12. ¬∂ I the preacher was king over I≈ørael in Jeru≈øalem.

For as there are inexplicable difficulties in all ≈øorts of knowledge, of which no man can give an account; ≈øo, with all our ≈øtudy, we cannot get skill enough, either to prevent misfortunes, or to remove out of the way that which cro≈ø≈øeth our de≈øigns, much le≈øs to alter the nature of things (no, not ≈øo much as in our own Con≈øtitutions) nor to redre≈øs the di≈øorders in Government: the defects in which, and in all other things and conditions, we are ≈øo far from being able to ≈øupply, that we cannot number them; and yet the folly of Mankind repre≈øents every thing to their de≈øires, as if it were completely good, and wanted nothing to make one happy. See Annot. [k]

16. I communed with mine own heart, Saying, Lo, I am come to great e≈øtate, and have gotten more wi≈ødom than all they that have been before me in Jeru≈øalem: yea, my heart had great experience of wi≈ødom and knowledge.

16. I my ≈øelf ≈øtill per≈øi≈øted in my reach after knowledge, though I found it ≈øo painful and ≈øo un≈øatisfactory: thinking within my ≈øelf, that there was this Good at lea≈øt in it,
that it had gotten me a very great Name, and rai≈øed me ≈øo high in all mens opinion, that I was noted for the wi≈øe≈øt per≈øon that had ever been in the≈øe Parts of the World, there being no ≈øort of knowledge, wherewith my mind was not ≈øtored in great abundance. See Annot. [l]
17. And I gave my heart to know wi≈ødom, and to know madne≈øs and folly: I perceived that this al≈øo is vexation of ≈øpirit.

17. And, as the nature of all knowledge is to excite a thir≈øt after more, this made me apply my mind more earne≈øtly to comprehend, not only the greate≈øt but, the meane≈øt matters; to mark, for in≈øtance, the actions and occupations of mad men and Fools, as well as the motions of wi≈øer per≈øons: but I perceived, that to be plea≈øed merely with fame was to live upon Air; and it was an afflicting thought to ob≈øerve, how little the mo≈øt of the World (tho' they thought them≈øelves very wi≈øe) differed from Lunaticks and di≈øtracted Folk. See Annot. [m]
18. For in much wi≈ødom is much grief: and he that increa≈øeth knowledge, increa≈øeth ≈øorrow.

18. So that, though knowledge be the mo≈øt excellent of all other Earthly Goods, being the Ornament of the mind which is the be≈øt part of us, yet this al≈øo is in≈øufficient for our happine≈øs: becau≈øe, after it hath co≈øt a man infinite pains (and ≈øometimes exhau≈øted his ≈øpirits, and made him melancholy and moro≈øe, nay thrown him into many Di≈øea≈øes) to acquire that little Wi≈ødom he can attain; which rai≈øes al≈øo more doubts than it can re≈øolve, and meets with trouble≈øome oppo≈øition from various Opinions that cla≈øh again≈øt it; it cannot but fill him with indignation to find folly generally applauded more than his wi≈ødom; and grieve his very ≈øoul to ≈øee that it is dangerous for a man to know more than his Neighbours; and that he is ≈øo far from being able to remedy what is ami≈øs, that he is hated if he endeavour it; and rewarded with reproaches for his care of the publick good. See Annot. [n]

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p: [a] V. 1. The Wi≈ødom, Vertue and Dignity of an Author making his Work more valuable and regarded, Solomon (or he who compo≈øed this Book from what he had heard him deliver, or found in his Writings) begins with his Quality; not merely as a King, and as the Son of a Great King, and of a great people, in a famous City: but, which was mo≈øt of all con≈øiderable, as a publick In≈øtructor, having ability and authority to inform all men where they ≈øhould find that happine≈øs, which they ignorantly ≈øought, but could not meet withal. This he proclaims with a loud voice; de≈øiring ≈øerious attention to ≈øuch a weighty Di≈øcour≈øe, and that they would often recollect, as he had done (all which may be the import of the word Koheleth See Preface, num. IV.) how frivolous and trivial, all tho≈øe things are, which mo≈øt men pur≈øue with the greate≈øt earne≈øtne≈øs.

[b] V. 2. This is the Subject of this Book; to ≈øhow how ≈øen≈øle≈øs it is to place our happine≈øs in the≈øe frail and incon≈øtant things, that we enjoy upon this Earth: which he not only pronounces, but proves to be mere emptine≈øs. So Vanity ≈øignifies; and what is con≈øequent upon that, di≈ø≈øatisfaction, trouble and affliction. See P≈øal. LXXVIII. 33. And this, beyond what can be expre≈ø≈øed: for our Tran≈ølators take it to be a word of the ≈øame import with Tohu; which is u≈øed in the Hebrew language, when they would ≈øignifie that of which they ≈øpeak, to be ≈øo trivial, that it is below le≈øs than nothing, XL. I≈øai. 17. And yet Solomon is not content with this ≈øingle word, but doubles it; to denote the extreme di≈ø≈øatisfaction he found in all things, which made a ≈øhow of affording him contentment; but performed nothing of that which they ≈øeemed to promi≈øe. So the Word Vanity
is al≈øo u≈øed for that which is fal≈øe, lying and deceitful, LXII. P≈øal. 9. and other places, where Idols are called Vanities.

[c] V. 3. Here begins the Proof of his A≈ø≈øertion; by con≈øidering fir≈øt the mind of man: which runs from one thing to another without any end: but finds no ≈øatisfaction remaining after all its re≈øtle≈øs thoughts. And then the body of man (V. 4.) which, as proud and lofty as it now looks, mu≈øt moulder into Du≈øt; and the poore≈øt per≈øon perhaps ≈øhall tread upon its Grave. For it cannot la≈øt like the Earth, from whence it comes; which ≈øtands for ever, as a publick Theatre, whereon men enter and act their Part, and then go off and never appear again: and when they go (as ≈øome prettily rather than ≈øolidly glo≈øs upon tho≈øe Words, The Earth abideth for ever) they can carry none of it along with them, but leave it all behind them, unto tho≈øe that come after; who pa≈øs away al≈øo, leaving the Earth where they found it.

[d] V. 5. The Sun al≈øo in a ≈øettled cour≈øe, ob≈øerves its times of ri≈øing and ≈øetting: whereas man, when he goes down to the Earth, cannot like the Sun come up again. So the fifth Ver≈øe ≈øeems to be mo≈øt naturally connected with the foregoing; and in like manner the ≈øixth and ≈øeventh Ver≈øes are to be expounded. There are many Interpreters indeed, who look upon the things mentioned in the≈øe three Ver≈øes, only as Emblems of the in≈øtability of all humane Affairs, and of the con≈øtant revolutions of the ≈øame mi≈øeries: which cannot be hindred by any humane coun≈øels, but will return after all the changes, whereby we think to mend our ≈øelves. Upon which ≈øen≈øe I have ju≈øt touched in my Paraphra≈øe, but not followed it; becau≈øe it doth not ≈øeem to me to be the ≈øcope of the≈øe Ver≈øes. In which man is repre≈øented, by four compari≈øons, with the Earth, the Sun, the Wind, and
the Sea, to be more ≈øubject to Vanity than other things.

[e] V. 8. Which having thus illu≈øtrated, he proceeds here more particularly to con≈øider, what he had ≈øaid in general words (V. 3.) of mans vain endeavour to ≈øatisfie him≈øelf in worldly de≈øigns and contrivances: in which he is tired, but comes to no end of his de≈øires. How ≈øhould he? when his whole bu≈øine≈øs here is only to do and to enjoy the very ≈øame things over and over again: as all men have done before us, and ≈øhall do after us, v. 9, 10, 11.

[f] V. 9. We may fan≈øie indeed, that we have found ≈øome new thing: but this conceit proceeds merely from our ignorance; as the Lord Bacon excellently di≈øcour≈øes in his fir≈øt Book of the Advancement of Learning, Chap. 8.

Learning and Knowledge, ≈øaith he, takes away vain and exce≈ø≈øive admiration; which is the very root of all weak coun≈øels. For we admire things, either becau≈øe they are new, or becau≈øe they are great. As for Novelty, there is no man that con≈øiders things thoroughly, but hath this printed in his heart, There is nothing new under the Sun: nor can any man much admire a Puppet-Play, who doth but thru≈øt his head behind the Curtain, and ≈øeeth the In≈øtruments and Wires whereby they are moved. As for Greatne≈øs, we may ≈øay as Alexander, who, after his great Conque≈øts in A≈øia, receiving Letters of ≈øome ≈ømall Fights or Skirmi≈øhes in Greece, at the taking of ≈øome Bridge, or Fort, was wont to tell his Friends, that it ≈øeemed to him, that they had ≈øent him News of the Battles of Homer's Frogs and Mice: ≈øo, certainly, if a man con≈øider the Univer≈øe, and the Fabrick of it, to him this Globe of Earth with the men upon it, and their bu≈øie motions (excepting always the Divinene≈øs of Souls) will not ≈øeem much
more con≈øiderable than an Hillock of Ants, whereon ≈øome creep up and down with their Corn, others with their Eggs, others empty: all about a very little heap of Du≈øt. And as Melancthon well ob≈øerves, the ≈øame de≈øires, the ≈øame coun≈øels, the ≈øame ends, the ≈øame cau≈øes of War, and calamitous events, return again: according to that of Thucydides, While humane nature continues what it is, the like mi≈øchiefs will happen; ≈øometimes le≈øs, ≈øometimes more direfully.

[g] V. 12. Thus having confirmed his main Propo≈øitions, by ≈øuch general Arguments as reach to all things in this World; he proceeds here to a more particular proof of it, from his own proper experience. And de≈øigning (before he declared his own Opinion of the Chief Good, and by what means it may be attained) to confute the vain fancies of men about it; he reduces them, as I have ≈øhown in the Preface, to four Heads. And ob≈øerving that ≈øome place it in knowledge, and curious inquiries into all manner of things, others in plea≈øure, or in both the≈øe together; others in honour and power; others in riches and heaps of wealth; he begins with that which is the mo≈øt plau≈øible. And demon≈øtrates, from the 13th Ver≈øe to the end of this Chapter, how little ≈øatisfaction is to be found in the mere ≈øpeculation of things; though a man arrive at the highe≈øt degree of humane knowledge.

[h] V. 13, 14. Melancthon re≈øtrains the≈øe two Ver≈øes, to political Wi≈ødom, in the Government of Kingdoms. Which gives men a double affliction: fir≈øt, in that the Wi≈øe≈øt men often err in their coun≈øels; and ≈øecondly, that events ≈øometimes do not an≈øwer to the be≈øt coun≈øels that men can follow. Examples of the fir≈øt are innumerable: Sometime they err through ambition, as Perdiccas, after Alexander; ≈øometime through a fal≈øe opinion of Right, as Brutus;
≈øometime, through over-doing, bu≈øie headedne≈øs and inquietude of mind, as Pericles; ≈øometime through anger, as Marius. And how many ways good coun≈øels have mi≈øcarried, it is too long here to remember: becau≈øe, it is here further ob≈øervable, that ≈øometime more doubtfulne≈øs and uncertainty of mind what cour≈øe to take, is as great a torment to the mind as any other. Thus Pompey was fir≈øt perplexed in his Coun≈øels, before he ≈øaw the di≈øa≈øtrous event of his Error. To conclude this; All Government is ≈øo full of cares, perplexities, and impediments, that it made Demo≈øthenes ≈øay, If he were to begin the World again, he would rather die than be promoted to it. And Ae≈øchines, that he was as glad when he was rid of his Office, as he would have been to be delivered from a mad Dog.

[i] V. 14. The word we tran≈ølate vexation is found only in this Book, and is capable of many ≈øen≈øes, all pertinent to the ≈øcope of this place. For according to the ≈øeveral Fountains from whence it may be derived; this Phra≈øe may be interpreted, either angui≈øh of Spirit, or breaking of Spirit, or preying upon the Spirits; or (in another ≈øen≈øe of the word Spirit) feeding on the Wind or Air: none of which I have neglected in the Parapra≈øe.

[k] V. 15. The ≈øhortne≈øs of humane Wit, though never ≈øo much improved, is here repre≈øented by two things:
fir≈øt, that it cannot remove what is inconvenient; ≈øecondly, that it cannot ≈øupply what is deficient, in any condition of life. Or, as others will have it, the fir≈øt part of the Ver≈øe refers to the inability of man to rectifie that perver≈øene≈øs (as the Hebrew word we tran≈ølate crooked ≈øignifies) which he finds in him≈øelf or others; and the latter part, to the ≈ømall reach o≈ø humane under≈øtanding, which can attain but a very imperfect knowledge, either of words, things, times, per≈øons or actions; as ≈øome branch out the innumerable Particulars of which we mu≈øt be content to be ignorant.

[l] V. 16. I have not curiou≈øly di≈øtingui≈øhed between Wi≈ødom and Knowledge, either in this Ver≈øe, or in the 18th. But there may be this difference pertinently made, That Wi≈ødom directs a man, in the practical affairs of life, unto that which is mo≈øt fit for his purpo≈øe, according to the various circum≈øtances wherein he may be. It con≈øi≈øts chiefly in a clear judgment, to di≈øcern our true intere≈øt, and the proper means to compa≈øs it: together with a pre≈øentne≈øs of mind, to obviate ≈øudden accidents. And then Knowledge relates to the ≈øpeculation of natural things; in their cau≈øes and effects, their properties and differences, and ≈øuch like things.

[m] V. 17. Madne≈øs and Folly, may refer al≈øo to all the idle Speculations, wherein men of Parts and Wit, ≈øometimes not only imploy, but applaud them≈øelves, as the fir≈øt of tho≈øe words ≈øeems to import in the Hebrew. This trifling ≈øort of Knowledge is notably de≈øcribed by Era≈ømus, in his Prai≈øe of Folly.

[n] V. 18. If there be any difference to be made between Wi≈ødom and Knowledge, I have noted it above upon v. 16. As for grief and ≈øorrow, they may be thus di≈øtingui≈øhed, That the former, in the Original word, includes in it indignation which is a ≈øharp anger mingled with ≈øcorn; to find either our Per≈øons
and Coun≈øels contemned, or our Projects and well laid De≈øigns defeated. Such as was in Achitophel; who≈øe penetrating Wit made his rage the greater, to ≈øee his judicious advice rejected, and the whole Con≈øpiracy utterly di≈øappointed. The other word (≈øorrow) properly denotes an extreme great trouble and ≈øickne≈øs of mind; and is ≈øometimes applied to pains in the Body: which is the effect too frequently of overhard ≈øtudy Melancthon under≈øtands the whole Ver≈øe (as he did v. 13, 14.) of the trouble that wi≈øe men have, when they are intru≈øted with Government, to ≈øee the confu≈øions, errors, vices and calamities of Mankind. And their afflictions are the greater, becau≈øe they are not only more ≈øen≈øible than other men of pre≈øent evils, but fore≈øee by the pre≈øent tho≈øe that are future: and therefore are tormented with a ≈øore pain and grief, both for what they feel and for what they fear. For they know, that from the fir≈øt di≈øorders, there commonly follow greater confu≈øions: as when Pericles had once ≈øtirred up a War, there followed the de≈øtruction of almo≈øt all the great Cities of Greece. And it is too truly ≈øaid by Pindar, that it is ea≈øie for any body to di≈øturb a City; but God alone can re≈øtore peace unto it.

This I take to be too limited a ≈øen≈øe; but it is no ≈ømall trouble to a wi≈øe and prudent per≈øon, as Corranus excellently expre≈ø≈øes it, to behold the mi≈øerable di≈øorders and confu≈øions of humane affairs. For how is it po≈ø≈øible to avoid it, nay how can a man chu≈øe but be filled with indignation, to ≈øee Ju≈øtice, Equity, Probity, Fidelity, Integrity and Con≈øtancy, and all other ≈øuch like Vertues ≈ølighted and di≈øregarded by mankind; and on the contrary, Inju≈øtice, Ba≈øene≈øs, Perfidiou≈øne≈øs, Flattery, and ≈øuch like Vices, po≈ø≈øe≈øs the World, and carry all before them? Or what man can, without vexation, ob≈øerve the prepo≈øterous judgment of mankind, which magnifies tho≈øe things, that
are not only vain but hurtful and pernicious; and not only contemn but hate tho≈øe things, which are truly good for them; nay, alone de≈øirable: No man can either be wi≈øe alone to him≈øelf, in ≈øuch a multitude of Fools and mad men, without the greate≈øt grief and indignation: nor can be accommodate him≈øelf, with an equal mind, to the dotages of the common people; when he ≈øees that which is better.
I ≈øhall conclude this Chapter with the Lord Bacon's Ob≈øervation, concerning this anxiety of ≈øpirit which ari≈øeth out of Knowledge; in the beginning of his Book of the Advancement of Learning.

p.q:
Solomon, ≈øaith he, doth not pa≈øs this cen≈øure ab≈øolutely upon Wi≈ødom and Knowledge, but only ≈øets forth the true Bounds, wherein humane knowledge is to be circum≈øcribed: which if we do not ob≈øerve, it will prove very trouble≈øome to us and others. And tho≈øe limitations are three. Fir≈øt, That we do not ≈øo place our felicity in Knowledge, as to forget our mortality. Secondly, That we u≈øe not our Knowledge to beget anxiety, but repo≈øe and contentment of mind: and Thirdly, That we do not pre≈øume by the contemplation of Nature, to think our ≈øelves able to comprehend the My≈øteries of God. The fir≈øt and the la≈øt of the≈øe are plain enough; and therefore I ≈øhall only note what he ≈øaith of the ≈øecond: that it is certain, no anxiety or perturbation of mind ari≈øeth from Knowledge, but by mere accident. For all Knowledge, and Admiration (which is the Seed of Knowledge) is plea≈øant in it ≈øelf: but when we fall to frame Conclu≈øions from thence, which, obliquely applied to our own affairs, beget either weak fears, or immoderate de≈øires, then ari≈øeth that torment and trouble of mind, whereof Solomon here ≈øpeaketh. For then Knowledge is no longer dry light, (which Heraclitus was wont to ≈øay was the be≈øt) but moi≈øt
light, ≈øteeped and infu≈øed in the humours of the affections.

div.p: As for that Expo≈øition which ≈øome have given of the≈øe words, that he increa≈øeth the number of his ≈øtripes (or wounds) who increa≈øeth knowledge; but makes no u≈øe of it, nor takes care that his obedience ri≈øe in ≈øome good proportion with it; it is not the proper ≈øen≈øe of the place, but rather an accommodation of the words to another profitable purpo≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Having pa≈ø≈øed his cen≈øure upon the fir≈øt way men take to find ≈øatisfaction (mentioned in the Notes upon v. 12. of the fir≈øt Chapter) which without all contradiction is the chief, and the be≈øt of the four; he proceeds here to con≈øider the ≈øecond, which is the more common: mo≈øt men immer≈øing them≈øelves in plea≈øure, as their highe≈øt Good. Of which he was more capable to judge, than any other man; becau≈øe he denied him≈øelf no delights that he de≈øired, and yet did not plung him≈øelf wholly into them, but with a mixture of Wi≈ødom, as he tells us, v. 3. Whereby he ≈øoon perceived that they who leave the pur≈øuit of Knowledge, for the ≈øake of bodily plea≈øure, change for the wor≈øe: For after he had tried all ≈øorts of things that could give him any plea≈øure, he went back to Wi≈ødom and Knowledge, as the better of the two, v. 12. And yet, after he had con≈øidered that again the ≈øecond time, he could not but confe≈øs, that there were ≈øuch great imperfections in it; that it could not make a man happy, as he di≈øcour≈øes in the following Ver≈øes. Of which I ≈øhall give a more paticular account in the Annotations.

div.p: 1. I Said in mine heart, Go to now, I will prove thee with mirth, therefore enjoy plea≈øure: and behold, this al≈øo is vanity.

1. BEing thus di≈øappointed therefore in the expectations I had of happipine≈øs from much Wi≈ødom and Knowledge, and beholding many men look jollily who had none at all, I re≈øolved to leave off tho≈øe trouble≈øome cares and labours, and to follow my plea≈øures: ≈øaying to my ≈øelf, Why do≈øt thou vex and torment thy mind to no purpo≈øe? Let alone the≈øe crabbed Studies, which ha≈øten Old Age, and indulge thy ≈øelf in all tho≈øe ≈øweet delights which Youth de≈øires: Try what ≈øatisfaction mirth and joy can give thee; and for that end, take no thought for the future, but enjoy to the heighth the pre≈øent Goods of this life: Which accordingly I did; but believe me, though this promi≈øed much at fir≈øt, it performed little; but left me more void of contentment than it found me. See Annot. [a]
2. I ≈øaid of laughter, It is mad: and of mirth, What doeth it?

2. For the noi≈øe, the tumult, the indecent motions, and ≈øcurrilous je≈øtings, of men that let them≈øelves loo≈øe to exce≈ø≈øive laughter, and extragavant merriment, appeared to me like di≈øtraction of mind: and con≈øidering how unprofitable it is, I could not but with a pa≈ø≈øionate di≈ødain put it from me: ≈øaying of it, and of mirth, and dancing, and all the frolickne≈øs of mankind, What is there in it, that thus bewitcheth them? Where lies the plea≈øure, that thus inchants them, and puts them ≈øo be≈øide them≈øelves; that they think neither of God, nor of any thing el≈øe that is worthy of them; but of this alone? See Annot. [b]

3. I ≈øought in mine heart to give my ≈øelf unto wine (yet acquainting mine heart with wi≈ødom) and to lay hold on folly, till I might ≈øee what was that good for the ≈øons of men, which they ≈øhould do under the heaven, all the days of their life.

3. I deliberated therefore with my ≈øelf about a middle cour≈øe of life; which ≈øhould neither be altogether ≈øtudious, nor altogether voluptuous, but a mixture of both: and in pur≈øuance of this coun≈øel
entertained my ≈øelf freely, with all the delights of fea≈øting and banquetting; yet ≈øo, as not to lo≈øe my acquaintance with Wi≈ødom, but to keep my mind ≈øo intent upon it, that Folly might not have its full ≈øwing; but find a check upon it, till I might make a ≈øufficient tryal, whether herein lay, that ≈øo-much-de≈øired Good which men ≈øhould propo≈øe to them≈øelves, and pro≈øecute all the time of their ≈øtay in this World. See Annot. [c]
4. I made me great works, I builded me hou≈øes I planted me vineyards.

4. For which end, I rai≈øed, with exqui≈øite Art, the mo≈øt ≈øtately and maje≈øtick works that could be contrived, for the plea≈øure of all the ≈øen≈øes: As fir≈øt of all, I built my ≈øelf a mo≈øt magnifient Palace, and other goodly Hou≈øes; which when I had elegantly adorned and ≈øumptuou≈øly furni≈øhed, I proceeded to plant about them, in a beautiful order, the choice≈øt Vines (VIII. Cant. 11.) which, be≈øides the fragrant ≈ømell (II. Cant. 13.) and the lovely ≈øight, wherewith they entertained me abroad, afforded the mo≈øt generous Wines for my table at home. See Annot. [d]
5. I made me Gardens and orchards, and I planted trees in them of all kind of fruits.

5. To which I added delicious Gardens, full of various Flowers, Herbs and Plants for all the Sea≈øons of the Year; and then ≈øpacious Fore≈øts and Parks, or rather Paradi≈øes of Plea≈øure, wherein, be≈øides other delights, were lovely Shades and Coverts for all ≈øorts of Bea≈øts: nor were Orhards wanting ≈øtored with all kinds of Fruit-Trees, which either this, or other Countries could afford. See Annot. [e]
6. I made me pools of water, to water therewith the wood that bringeth forth trees.

6. And that nothing might be want-in to the perfection or pre≈øervation of the≈øe places, I made with great charge, and no le≈øs Art, either Fountains, or Ci≈øterns, or Pools of Water: not only for delight and for Fi≈øh, but to ≈øerve in≈øtead of Rain; to water the Flowers and Herbs, e≈øpecially the young Nur≈øeries of Trees; that they might not die with Drought. See Annot. [f]
7. I got me ≈øervants and maidens, and had ≈øervants born in my hou≈øe; al≈øo I had great po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions of great and ≈ømall cattel, above all that were in Jeru≈øalem before me.

7. I. 13, 17.) and e≈øpecially that Wi≈ødom which moderates our plea≈øures, and keeps them from running into madne≈øs and folly (and who is there that can give a better account of this than I? who have had ≈øuch advantages above any private man to know the Hi≈øtory of former times, as well as of my own; that I am confident, they who come after can pa≈øs no other judgment upon things, than I do now.)

For I clearly di≈øcerned, that there is as wide a difference between Wi≈ødom and Folly; as there is between the light of the Sun, which beautifies the whole World, and ≈øhows all things di≈øtinctly to us; and the darkne≈øs of the Night, which wraps up all in di≈ømal confu≈øion, and hides even our dangers from us.

[k] V. 10. my portion] Though Wi≈ødom thus bridled his plea≈øures, yet it did not re≈øtrain him from ≈øuch a free and plentiful enjoyment of them, that there was no ≈øort which he did not ta≈øte as highly of, as was po≈ø≈øibly; without making him≈øelf a mere Fool.
