Fir≈øt, That they may provide for their ≈øafety and ≈øecurity: Secondly, That they may commend their Names to Po≈øterity; or Thirdly, That they may leave to their Children, what their ≈øingular Prudence, and great diligence hath gathered together. But all the≈øe he ≈øhows are vain De≈øigns.

[m] V. 15. hapned] For in≈øtance, he repre≈øents here, how all Mankind, Wi≈øe and Fools, are alike liable to the ≈øame ca≈øualties, and many incoveniences, which are common to every one of us in this life. Which the Lord Bacon (in his IV. Book of the Advancement of Learning, chap. 2.) extends to ≈øuch Con≈øiderations as this; that in all times, Witches and old Women, and impo≈øtors, have been Rivals and Competitors, in the reputation and opinion of the multitude, with the able≈øt Phy≈øicians; and contended with them for the fame of Cures. Nay, the impo≈øtor bears away the prize, and Vertue lies under the cen≈øure. Such is the weakne≈øs and credulity of men, they prefer a Mountebank, or a Witch, before a learned Phy≈øician: which the Poets ob≈øerved when they made Ae≈øculapius and Circe, Brother and Si≈øter; both Children of the Sun. And what follows from hence, but that Phy≈øicians ≈øay to them≈øelves, as Solomon in another ca≈øe, It befalls to me, as it doth to the Fool; why ≈øhould I labour to be more wi≈øe? It di≈øcourages them, that is, in their Profe≈ø≈øion.

[n] V. 16. no remembrance] And then for the other two (mentioned above, k) he ob≈øerves how ≈øhort-liv'd our memorial is, as well as our ≈øelves, v. 16, 17. and that no man can be ≈øure, who ≈øhall inherit his labours, or what kind of per≈øon he ≈øhall be; wi≈øe or ≈øotti≈øh, good or bad, v. 18, 19. Which he reflects upon again in the following Ver≈øes, with a very heavy heart, that made him weary of life, v. 20, 21. at lea≈øt of the labour and toil of it, v. 22. the folly of which he repre≈øents v. 23. And then concludes the Chapter, with a brief account of the true way to enjoy all the happine≈øs that this World can afford us: of which we are utterly uncapable, unle≈øs we have a ≈øen≈øe of God, be devoutly affected towards Him as the Author and Donor of all good things. Which I
have expre≈ø≈øed ≈øo fully in the Paraphra≈øe, of ver≈øe 24, &c. that I may be cen≈øured for making it too long; and therefore ≈øhall not commit another error, in enlarging it further here.

[o] V. 26. But only ob≈øerve, that Wi≈ødom and Knowledge in this Ver≈øe, do not differ, as they may be thought to do, Chap. I. v. 16, 18. but relate; both of them, to the ≈øame thing; only with ≈øuch a di≈øtinction, as I have mentioned in the Paraphra≈øe: or, as others will have it, Wi≈ødom relates to the acqui≈øition of the good things of this World, Knowledge to the u≈øe; from which prudent fruition flows the joy he mentions together with them. Thus Corranus.

The la≈øt words of the Chapter, are referred by all Expo≈øitors, in a manner, only to the condition of the Sinner, which immediately precedes: but ≈øince they have a true ≈øen≈øe, with re≈øpect to all men what≈øoever, good and had, I thought it be≈øt ≈øo to expound them; with regard to the whole foregoing Ver≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p:
Upon the mention of God's over-ruling Providence, in the latter end of the foregoing Chapter, Solomon proceeds from thence to illu≈øtrate (in the fir≈øt part of this Chapter) both tho≈øe things, of which he had di≈øcour≈øed before, viz. fir≈øt, the imperfection of humane Wi≈ødom; which is confined to a certain time or ≈øea≈øon, for all things that it would effect: which if we neglect, or let ≈ølip, all our contrivances ≈øignifie nothing. And ≈øecondly, That the utmo≈øt perfection at which our Wi≈ødom can arrive in this World, con≈øi≈øts in the≈øe things. Fir≈øt, In being contented with this order wherein God hath placed all things,
and not di≈øquieting our ≈øelves about that which it is not in our power to remedy, or alter; at lea≈øt, not for the pre≈øent. Secondly, In ob≈øerving and taking the fitte≈øt opportunity of doing every thing; as the mo≈øt certain means to tranquility: there being nothing that makes our mind more unquiet, than ≈øtriving again≈øt the ≈øtream) as we ≈øpeak) and when the wind is again≈øt us, labouring to bring about our ends, and to obtain our de≈øires: and Thirdly, In taking the comfort of what we have at pre≈øent; and making a ≈øea≈øonable and legitimate u≈øe of it: And la≈øtly, In bearing the vici≈ø≈øitudes that we find in all humane things, with an equal mind; becau≈øe they are nece≈ø≈øary and unalterable.

The≈øe were the things he had ≈øugge≈øted in the Conclu≈øion of the former Chapter; and the beginning of this may have relation to every one of them. And ≈øince he had ≈øpoken before al≈øo (v. 9, 10, of the ≈øecond Chater) concerning the moderating of plea≈øures by Wi≈ødom and of the ≈øtudy of Wi≈ødom by ≈øea≈øonable plea≈øures; I do not know but he may have re≈øpect unto that al≈øo: and therefore I have begun with it, in the Paraphra≈øe.

Ca≈øtalio goes ≈øtill further, and thinks the meaning of the fir≈øt part of this Chapter may be, that it is in vain to expect our happine≈øs in this World: for this is no more the time, and the place for it, than Seedtime is the Harve≈øt. But we mu≈øt ≈øtay till the next life for it: which is the proper time for complete happine≈øs: here we mu≈øt be content with a great many tears. Which is a pious Meditation, but ≈øeems not to be the Scope of Solomon; and therefore I have not touched upon it.

In ≈øhort, He ≈øtill continues to enlarge him≈øelf upon the two fir≈øt things, wherein men place their happine≈øs; Wi≈ødom and Plea≈øure: and comes not to the third, till the middle of this Chapter; where I ≈øhall ob≈øerve it.

div.p: 1. TO every thing there is a ≈øea≈øon, and a time to every purpo≈øe under the heaven:

1. HOW vain an attempt it is, to obtain the forenamed tranquillity by fixing our mind upon any one thing in this World; and how nece≈ø≈øary it is, to let the ≈øtudy of Wi≈ødom, for in≈øtance, and the enjoyment of plea≈øure, labour and re≈øt, take their turns; God him≈øelf hath ≈øhown us, by tying us to this order in the cour≈øe of things: which‚ñ™ whether they be natural, or depend upon our will, have their certain, appointed ≈øea≈øons and occa≈øions: upon which all our de≈øigns, coun≈øels and endeavours have ≈øuch a dependance, that if we will not ob≈øerve them, we ≈øhall not only lo≈øe our labour, but mi≈øerably vex and torment our ≈øelves to no purpo≈øe. See Annot. [a]
2. A time to be born, and a time to die: a time to plant, and a time to pluck up that which is planted:

2. As for natural things, we ≈øee in our ≈øelves, that there is a ≈øtated time for an Infants lying in the Womb, before it can be born; and the time afterward for its growth, and ≈øtay in the World; beyond which a man cannot go, but drops into his Grave: And ≈øo it is not only with other living Creatures as well as man, but with Herbs, and Roots, and Plants, which we cannot fet and ≈øow at all times; but mu≈øt take the proper Sea≈øon, both for that, and for gathering the Crop, when it is come to maturity; or el≈øe our pains are ill be≈øtowed, and we find to our ≈øorrow that we have laboured in vain.
3. A time to kill, and a time to heal: a time to break down, and a time to build up.

3. And thus it is in the Di≈øea≈øes of our Body; there is a time when they are ≈øo infectious, that they are incurable, or when it is ≈øo improper to admini≈øter Phy≈øick, that it doth no good, but certainly kills; whereas at another time, tho≈øe very remedies prove effectual means, to re≈øtore our health unto us: And ≈øo it is in other Structures, as well as our own Bodies; there is a time when it is more proper to break down a Building, than it is to rai≈øe it; and when Hou≈øes are built, there are ≈øea≈øons for repairs, and ≈øometimes
for pulling them down and erecting them anew, or el≈øe they will not ≈øtand. See Annot. [b]
4. A time to weep, and a time to laugh: a time to mourn, and a time to dance:

4. Other alterations, al≈øo there are in humane life, which ≈øometimes naturally move our tears; and at another time our laughter: any, there are times not only for tears, but for the bittere≈øt lamentations, which the Funerals of our deare≈øt Relations, or the publick Calamities require; and again, there is a time (at a Wedding ≈øuppo≈øe) which provokes us ≈øo naturally, not only to be merry, but, to leap and dance for joy, that it would be as ab≈øurd then to bewail our ≈øelves, as it is to dance about the dead Bodies of our Friends.
5. A time to ca≈øt away ≈øtones, and a time to gather ≈øtones together: a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing.

5. And in the Plantations which we make, there is a time when it is fit to pick up Stones, and throw them out of our Vineyards, or Fields of Corn; and there is another time, when it will be as nece≈ø≈øary to gather up the ≈øame Stones again, to make a Fence about tho≈øe Vineyards or Fields, or to repair the High-ways; And as it is in the≈øe natural things, ≈øo it is in tho≈øe that depend upon our own di≈øpo≈øal; there are Sea≈øons proper for Husband and Wife to enjoy the ends of Marriage; but there are other times, when they ought to refrain, and deny them≈øelves even the≈øe otherways innocent plea≈øures.
6. A time to get, and a time to lo≈øe: a time to keep, and a time to ca≈øt away.

6. In like manner, in our traffick and commerce one with another, there is a time of gaining much; but there are other times, when a man mu≈øt be content to lo≈øe by his Commodities: ≈øometimes al≈øo it is fit for him to lay up, and keep what he hath gotten; but at another time, it will be as fit for him to ≈øpend or to give way to tho≈øe that need it.
7. A time to rent, and a time to ≈øew: a time to keep ≈øilence, and a time to ≈øpeak:

7. In direful di≈øa≈øters al≈øo, as when God is bla≈øphemed, it becomes us to rend
our Garments; but after a certain time, it will be as becoming to ≈øew up the rent again: and, as on other occa≈øions, the proper times for holding ones peace, or for ≈øpeaking, are to be ab≈øerved; ≈øo in great grief, it is to no purpo≈øe to admini≈øter comfort, till the pa≈ø≈øion be a little over; and then di≈øcour≈øe will be as ≈øea≈øonable as ≈øilence was before, II. Job 13. IV. 1, 2.
8. A time to love, and a time to hate: a time of war, and a time of peace.

8. To conclude, love it ≈øelf may turn into hatred; ≈øo that they who are now well-affected towards us, may prove our Enemies; or tho≈øe in who≈øe Company we now delight, there may be rea≈øon hereafter to avoid: And the like turns there are in publick, as well as in private Affairs; there being ju≈øt cau≈øes ≈øometimes for making War; and then, ≈øuch a change in the ≈øtate of things that, it is greater Wi≈ødom to conclude a Peace.
9. What profit hath he that worketh, in that wherein he laboureth?

9. And therefore, why do we fan≈øie any thing to be ≈øetled, fixed and con≈øtant, here in this World; unle≈øs it be the≈øe oppo≈øite Changes? Or to what purpo≈øe is all our labour and travail for any thing, out of the Sea≈øon proper for it? And what great matter is it that we then get; ≈øince we mu≈øt expect another Sea≈øon to part with it? See Annot. [c].
10. I have ≈øeen the travail which God hath given to the ≈øons of men, to be exerci≈øed in it.

10. For that which I have ob≈øerved from all this is, That God hath made it our bu≈øine≈øs to mark the times and ≈øea≈øons, that are fit for the doing all things, which hath great trouble and anxiety in it: and there is a further trouble, that after we have done what we de≈øired, we mu≈øt ≈øubmit to that time and ≈øea≈øon, which will undo all again.
11. He hath made every thing beautiful in his time: al≈øo he hath ≈øet the world in their heart, ≈øo that no man can find out the work that God maketh from the beginning to the end.

11. And, though we are not wont to be ≈øatisfied with this vici≈ø≈øitude of things yet, God no doubt, hath di≈øpo≈øed them
thus mo≈øt wi≈øely; and there is ≈øuch a beautiful order appears in ≈øeveral contrarieties (as for example, of heat and cold, of day and night) that we may well conclude there is ≈øo in all manner of events, though never ≈øo oppo≈øite; which God al≈øo hath given us Wi≈ødom to di≈øcern, in part; having endued man with the under≈øtanding of the pre≈øent ≈øtate of things, in the Age wherein he lives: yet as that is imperfect (it being beyond our skill to know when our indu≈øtry will ≈øucceed, and when a change will come) ≈øo he is not able to find out what re≈øpect the pre≈øent changes have to the times that are gone before, and to tho≈øe that are yet to come hereafter; and ≈øo cannot give an exact account of the Government of God, becau≈øe he ≈øees not the beginning, and the progre≈øs, and the conclu≈øion of every thing that comes to pa≈øs. See Annot. [d].
12. I know that there is no good in them, but for a man to rejoyce, and to do good in his life.

12. Wherefore long con≈øideration and experience a≈ø≈øure me, that, leaving the≈øe fruitle≈øs enquiries and vexatious cares about the future, the only happine≈øs that is in our power, is to make the be≈øt we can of our pre≈øent condition: rejoycing that things are ≈øo well with us, and being ≈øolicitous for nothing in this World, but to obtain a good hope in God, by living piou≈øly and vertuou≈øly, and doing good to others with what we have; and this, not remi≈øly and by fits, but ≈øeriou≈øly and con≈øtantly, as long as we live. See Annot. [e].
13. And al≈øo that every man ≈øhould eat and drink, and enjoy the good of all his labour, it is the gift of God.

13. And if a man have arrived at ≈øo much happine≈øs, as not to deny him≈øelf the u≈øe of what he hath at pre≈øent, out of a vain fear of wanting in time to come; but can ≈øo freely and cheerfully enjoy the fruit of his hone≈øt labours, as to be well ≈øatisfied in the mid≈øt of all the inconveniences of this life; let him not a≈øcribe it unto his own Wi≈ødom, but thankfully acknowledge the great Goodne≈øs of God herein: For it is a ≈øingular gift of his, to be able with a quiet and contented mind, to take the comfort of tho≈øe Ble≈ø≈øings, which God's Bounty hath be≈øtowed on us, Chap. II. 24.
14. I know that what≈øover God doeth, it ≈øhall be for ever: nothing can be put to it, nor any thing taken from it: and God doth it, that men ≈øhould fear before him.

14. And, on the other ≈øide, it is not only very fooli≈øh and vain, but a great Plague, to be di≈øcontented that things go otherways than we de≈øire; for, certain it is, God hath ≈øettled them by ≈øuch an eternal and immutable Law, in that cour≈øe and order before de≈øcribed, (v. 1, 2, 3, &c. in which nothing is ≈øuperfluous, nothing wanting) that it is not in the power of man, to make the lea≈øt alteration, one way or other: therefore we mu≈øt alter our ≈øelves, and not murmur that we cannot change the cour≈øe of things; which God hath thus immoveably fixed, not to make us mi≈øerable, by fretting at it, but happy, by reverent ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the Divine Government; and humble patience under tho≈øe troubles, which we cannot hone≈øtly avoid; and a due care not to offend the Divine Maje≈øty; who≈øe Will ≈øhall be done one way or other if not by us, yet upon us. See Annot. [f]
15. That which hath been, is now; and that which is to be hath already been, and God requireth that which is pa≈øt.

15. This alone is ≈øufficient to ≈øilence all our unprofitable, as well as undutiful, complaints, about that which hath always been, and ever will be. For we, in this pre≈øent Age, are ≈øubject to no other Laws, than tho≈øe by which God hath governed the World from the beginning; nor will the next produce any other method, than that wherein He hath already proceeded: but, though that which ≈øucceeds thru≈øt out what went before, it brings the very ≈øame things about again; as con≈øtantly as Spring and Fall, Summer and Winter, return in their Sea≈øons.
16. ¬∂ And moreover, I ≈øaw under the ≈øun the place of judgment, that wickedne≈øs was there: and the place of righteou≈øne≈øs, that iniquity was there.

16. But, beyond all this, it is lamentable to con≈øider, how that which God hath provided as a remedy for a great many evils which we bring one upon another in this
World, is quite perverted; and turned to be it ≈øelf the greate≈øt evil of all other. The Power and Authority, I mean, which is committed unto men of great Place, Wi≈ødom, and Dignity: who lean ≈øo much to their own affections, that I my ≈øelf have ob≈øerved nothing but corruption, in the highe≈øt, as well as lowe≈øt Courts of Judicature: for, whether mens lives or their e≈øtates were concerned, ≈øuch unju≈øt Sentences were pronounced (to the condemning the innocent, and acquitting the guilty, &c.) that I could not but conclude, There is nothing more dangerous, than for a man who hath not that fear of God before his eyes (which I now mentioned, v. 14.) to be advanced unto honour, and intru≈øted with power. So vain are they that place their felicity in the≈øe. See Annot. [g].
17. I ≈øaid in mine heart, God ≈øhall judge the righteous and the wicked: for there is a time there for every purpo≈øe, and for every work.

17. For, ≈øo rooted is this impiety in the hearts of men, and ≈øuch Arts there are to defeat the be≈øt endeavours to redre≈øs it, I could bring my thoughts about this matter, to no other i≈ø≈øue but this (in which we mu≈øt all be ≈øatisfied) that there is a ≈øupreme Judge of all, who will in due time make that difference between men and things, which we cannot do now; ab≈øolving and rewarding the righteous, and condemning and puni≈øhing the wicked: for as there is a time, I ob≈øerved before, for all other things, ≈øo there is for this; they that govern the World have their time now, for contriving and acting what mi≈øchief they plea≈øe; but He will take a time hereafter, of calling them to an account, for the inju≈øtice they de≈øigned, as well as did in the Courts of Judgment. See Annot. [h].
18. I ≈øaid in my heart concerning the e≈øtate of the ≈øons of men, that God might manife≈øt them, and that they might ≈øee that they them≈øelves are bea≈øts.

18. But in the mean time, I could not but think the condition of Mankind, e≈øpecially of the poorer ≈øort of them, to be very deplorable; which made me fetch a deep ≈øigh and wi≈øh to God, that
He would be plea≈øed to lay the≈øe Great men open, and manife≈øt to them≈øelves and make them ≈øen≈øible, that they have no rea≈øon to look down with ≈øo much contempt upon others; much le≈øs treat them like Bea≈øts, de≈øtined to the ≈ølaughter: for, were they ≈øtript of their external Pomp and Power, they are ≈øo far from excelling other men; that, in many regards, they do not excel the very Bea≈øts. See Annot. [i].

19. For that which befalleth the ≈øons of men befalleth bea≈øts, even one thing befalleth them: as the one dieth, ≈øo dieth the other, yea, they have all one breath, ≈øo that a man hath no pre-eminence above a bea≈øt: for all is vanity.

19. For, as the Bea≈øts are ≈øubject to many accidents which they think not of, ≈øo are all Mankind; who can no more fore≈øee ≈øeveral things that happen to them, than the Bea≈øts them≈øelves; or, if they herein differ from them, that they can better defend them≈øelves from ≈øome things that befal them; yet, there is one thing, which makes them all equal; and that is, Death: For both Men and Bea≈øts, not only grow old, but die alike; and while they live, one ≈øucks in no other Air, than the other doth; which when they can no longer breathe, a man remains as much an unprofitable lump and putrid Carka≈øe, as a Bea≈øt: and therefore herein can pretend to no preheminence, above other inferiour Creatures; but they are both equally vain and peri≈øhing.
20. All go unto one place, all are of the du≈øt, and all turn to du≈øt again.

20. And being dead, their Bodies are re≈øolved into the ≈øame Principles, out of which they ≈øprang; ≈øo that herein they are both alike again: for Man, as proud as he is, derives his Body from no higher Original, than the Du≈øt; the very ≈øame Du≈øt of which the Bea≈øts are made; into which they both, Men and Bea≈øt, mu≈øt return again at the la≈øt.
21. Who knoweth the ≈øpirit of man that goeth upward, and the ≈øpirit of the bea≈øt that goeth downward to the earth?

21. As for the Spirit, which makes all the difference between the Bea≈øts and us, that is invi≈øible; and
where ≈øhall we find a man, e≈øpecially among tho≈øe Great Per≈øons (≈øpoken of before) who ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øiders it? and believes that the ≈øouls of all mankind, go to God that gave them (XII. 7.) to be judged by Him (v. 17. of this Chapter,) whereas the Souls of Bea≈øts peri≈øh with them? No; herein they differ not at all from Bea≈øts, that having buried their minds in bruti≈øh plea≈øures, they have no more ≈øen≈øe of a future life than they; but imagine that their ≈øouls die together with their bodies.

So ≈øen≈øele≈øly ≈øtupied are they, that trample upon the re≈øt of Mankind; and yet have ≈øuch ignoble thoughts of them≈øelves, that they imagine their very ≈øouls are no longerliv'd than a Bea≈øt. See Annot. [k].
22. Wherefore I percieve that there is nothing better than that a man ≈øhould rejoyce in his own works; for that is his portion: for who ≈øhall bring him to ≈øee what ≈øhall be after him?

22. And therefore (con≈øidering that our Bodies have no privilege above the Bea≈øts, and that Mankind are ≈øo liable to be abu≈øed by tho≈øe who ≈øhould protect them, v. 16, 19, 20.) I was confirmed in my former Opinion (II. 24.) that it is be≈øt for a man, herein al≈øo to imitate the Bea≈øts; by enjoying freely the good things God hath ble≈ø≈øed him withal, and taking all the comfort he can find in them at pre≈øent, without ≈øolicitous care about the future: For this is all he can be ≈øure of; it being in no mans power to ≈øecure him, he ≈øhall enjoy that hereafter, which he makes no u≈øe of now; much le≈øs, when he is dead, can he be brought back again, to take any plea≈øure in the fruit of all his labours, or ≈øee what becomes of them.

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p:
[a] V. 1. ≈øea≈øon] The Hebrew words Zeman and Gneth, ≈øignifie either that point of time, when things, being ripe, come forth of them≈øelves, by the con≈øtitution of their ≈øeveral Beings; as all natural
things do: or that occa≈øion which ≈øerves our voluntary actions; and is fit for effecting what we de≈øign. The Hebrews ob≈øerve that Solomon here reckons ≈øeven oppo≈øite Sea≈øons, of each ≈øort: as a complete demon≈øtration, by induction, of the truth of this General Propo≈øition in the fir≈øt Ver≈øe. Which bolds good even in Vertue it ≈øelf: which is not proper, but in its place. For Fortitude hath not always been ≈øucce≈øsful, (as the Lord Herbert ob≈øerves) nor Temperance ≈øafe; nor Ju≈øtice opportune: the fury and in≈øolence of the outragious people, having in ≈øome in≈øurrections grown to that exce≈øs; that is hath been greater Wi≈ødom to pa≈øs by a while, than to puni≈øh them. And it is very apparent al≈øo in our Councels, when they are conducted merely by humane Wi≈ødom; which is not able, without a Divine direction, to chu≈øe the mo≈øt fortunate (as we call them) and happy Sea≈øons for undertakings. Brutus, Cicero, Hertius Pan≈øa, all thought to re≈øtore the ancient e≈øtate of the Roman Commonwealth (as Melancthon notes) but were deceived; and after the ≈øame manner many are ≈øtill, and will always be deceived. Then bu≈øine≈ø≈øes proceed, when we obey his Divine directions, and He a≈ø≈øists: and yet then ≈øometimes more, and ≈øometimes le≈øs difficultly.

[b] V. 3. kill] In the third Ver≈øe I have taken the liberty of following my own Judgment in expounding the first part of it: which I have not referred to puni≈øhing and ≈øparing Offenders, as Interpreters do; but to the condition of Di≈øea≈øes that are in our own Bodies. For, though the other be an excellent ≈øen≈øe, yet, this ≈øeems to be more agreeable to the Wi≈øe mans meaning. Becau≈øe he is hitherto ≈øpeaking of things Natural; and the word heal al≈øo directs rather to that ≈øen≈øe, which I have given of killing, than the common one. The ≈øame may be ≈øaid of the next part of the Ver≈øe; there being a crazine≈øs in Buildings, as well as in
the Body of man: and ≈øome Weather ≈øo improper to rai≈øe a Fabrick, that the parts will not hang together; but that which cements them moulders ≈øo fa≈øt away, that that time were better ≈øpent, in pulling down an hou≈øe, than in building it up.

As for the re≈øt of the Calender or Ephemeris (as the Lord Bacon calls it) which the Wi≈øe man hath made of the diver≈øities of times and occa≈øions for all actions; I need give no further account of it here, than I have done in the Paraphra≈øe.

[c] V. 9. What profit] Nor is it hard to expound the inference he makes in this Ver≈øe, from the foregoing induction: which I have expre≈ø≈øed as fully as I could in the Paraphra≈øe; and more largely in the Argument of this Chapter. Gregory Nazianzen thinks, he only intends to reflect upon the great incon≈øtancy, as of all earthly things, ≈øo of humane actions (≈øometimes, for in≈øtance, men are madly in love with a Woman, and in time they as much hate her; now they are eager to get, and at another time they profu≈øely ≈øpend, ≈øometimes they kill, and ≈øometimes are killed, ≈øometimes do nothing but talk, and at another time have not a word to ≈øay, &c.) and therefore all his labours are vain. But I have extended it further, with a re≈øpect to other things, which the forenamed induction ≈øugge≈øts to us.

[d] V. 11. world in their heart] There is greater difficulty in this Ver≈øe, if we connect it with the re≈øt of the Di≈øcour≈øe; as we ought to do. Which I have endeavoured to explain by taking the word Haolam, the World; for the pre≈øent ≈øtate of things, in this Age wherein we live (which is a genuine ≈øen≈øe of it) whereof God hath given us ≈øome under≈øtanding; but not ≈øo perfect as to be able to give an account, of the rea≈øon and ≈øcope of every thing, that we ≈øee happen in this World; becau≈øe we are ignorant of what went before, and of what will
follow after, when we had or ≈øhall have no Being here.

It is commonly under≈øtood of the works of Nature. And in this ≈øen≈øe the Lord Bacon (in the beginning of his Book of the Advancement of Learning) hath admirably expounded it; in this manner: In the≈øe words, He hath placed the world in mans heart, &c. Solomon declares not ob≈øcurely, that God hath framed the mind of man, as a Mirrour, or Looking-gla≈øs, capable of the Image of the whole World; and as de≈øirous to receive it, as the eye is to entertain the light: and not only delighted in beholding the variety of things, and the vici≈ø≈øitude of times; but ambitious to find out and di≈øcover the immoveable and inviolable Laws and Decrees of Nature. And though he intimate, that this whole Oeconomy of Nature (which he calls, The work, that God hath wrought, from the beginning to the end) cannot be found out by man; it doth not derogate from the capacity of his mind, but is to be imputed to the impediments of Learning, &c.

There is one Interpreter (Corranus) who by Olam, World, under≈øtands the Circular motion of things for the ≈øervice of man. But I can find no ≈øuch u≈øe of the word any where; el≈øe, the ≈øen≈øe would be elegant enough, which ari≈øes from thence; viz. that this revolution being remote from our knowledge, and a ≈øecret to us; who cannot tell, what day or hour it will be: we ought not to trouble our ≈øelves about this; but make u≈øe of the pre≈øent, and refer the re≈øt to God.

Melancthon al≈øo hath an unu≈øual Interpretation; which is, that God made things ≈øo, that we ≈øhould ≈øweetly enjoy them (that he under≈øtands by placing the World in mans heart) but men make the u≈øe of them unplea≈øant, by their wandring de≈øires, by their vain ≈øolicitude,
by their diffidence; which makes them long after new things, and meddle with that which is unnece≈ø≈øary. Like M. Anthony, who when he had gotten the mo≈øt flouri≈øhing part of the Empire, could not be content; but, out of an unquiet Nature, de≈øired the whole, and ≈øo lo≈øt all. This he makes the ≈øen≈øe of the latter end of the Ver≈øe; which he thus tran≈ølates, Man cannot find out the Work of God, neither the beginning nor the end of it Therefore, as I ≈øaid ju≈øt now, it is Wi≈ødom to ≈øatisfie our ≈øelves with what we have; for the pre≈øent only is that, which is in our own power.

[e] V. 12, 13.] And ≈øo it follows in the≈øe two Ver≈øes; the ≈øen≈øe of which Gregory Nazianzen (Orat. LIII.) hath thus briefly expre≈ø≈øed, The greate≈øt Good of man, I per≈øwade my ≈øelf to be,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , cheerfulne≈øs of mind, and beneficence, or doing good to others: and this ≈øhort plea≈øure alone the Divine indulgence be≈øtows upon us, if righteou≈øne≈øs conduct all our Affairs.

[f] V. 14, 15.] And with this we mu≈øt re≈øt contented, for with all our toil≈øome thoughts, we cannot alter the cour≈øe of things: which God, he here ≈øhows, hath immutably ≈øetled; on purpo≈øe that we ≈øhould be ≈øen≈øible of a power above our ≈øelves. Which it is our Wi≈ødom to ≈øtand in ≈øuch awe of, as not to contend with it, but ≈øubmit unto it: that ≈øo we may obtain all the favour from Him, which in ≈øuch a ≈øtate of things, as his Wi≈ødom hath appointed, can be indulged to us. And here, I think, Melancthon hath very pertinently ob≈øerved, that Solomon doth not merely recite, the vain complaints and endeavours of Mankind, after the manner of Philo≈øophers and Poets: but lays down a Rule of life, as the be≈øt remedy that can be found, for our Di≈øea≈øe. Which, is not to tru≈øt to our ≈øelves, nor to indulge our own curio≈øity and appetites; but to be ≈øen≈øible of
our own infirmities, to fear God, to obey his commands, to keep within the Bounds of our vocations, to beg and expect the help of God, and to acquie≈øce in his holy will and plea≈øure.

[g] V. 16.] Unto the≈øe things it is better for us to apply our ≈øelves, than it is to endeavour to be great and mighty (which is another vain de≈øire of man, fan≈øying he can thereby keep off many evils) for few can be at the top of all; and ≈øo there mu≈øt be ≈øtill greater than we, by whom we may be oppre≈ø≈øed: And our vexation will be ≈øo much the greater, when with all our power we cannot hinder it. As for tho≈øe that are in the very highe≈øt places (if they have not that fear of God before-≈øpoken of, v. 14.) their power doth but betray them, to do the more mi≈øchief unto them≈øelves and others; and thereby encrea≈øe the mi≈øery of Mankind. This ≈øeems to be the dependance between the foregoing Ver≈øes and this. Wherein the Wi≈øe man pa≈ø≈øes to the con≈øideration of the Third thing (mentioned upon Chap. I 12.) unto which ≈øome a≈øpire, as the highe≈øt happine≈øs, viz. Greatne≈øs, Power, and Honour. Which if a man be bad, make him ≈øo much the wor≈øe him≈øelf, and the World by his means: and if he be good, will trouble him very much, to find there are many abu≈øes, which by all his power he cannot remedy. For Solomon him≈øelf ≈øaw ≈øeveral gro≈øs impieties committed (as he tells us in this Ver≈øe) even by them who were appointed to be the Guardians of mens lives, liberties and enjoyments; which he, as great a King as he was, wanted ability wholly to redre≈øs: but ≈øtill they went on ≈øo confidently in their wicked cour≈øe of perverting Judgment, that he was fain to leave them to be judged by the ≈øupreme Judge of all, God Almighty. And if it were ≈øo, in the Reign of a good and wi≈øe King; what could be hoped for, in the Reign of tho≈øe who were impious and
injudicious; as mo≈øt of the Kings of I≈ørael and Judah were? For ≈øuch pervert all things, by their covetou≈øne≈øs, ambition or folly; ≈øo that their Subjects can have no Ju≈øtice, nor enjoy any tranquility. And be≈øides, they permit (as he ≈øhows afterwards, Chap. V.) many corruptions to creep into the Divine Wor≈øhip; and ridiculous rather than religious Ceremonies to be introduced, &c. whereupon always follows a great decay of all moral Vertue.

In ≈øhort; this is a great part of the Vanity and mi≈øery, to which we are here ≈øubject; that, as Melancthon well notes, there are many things done unju≈øtly, even under ju≈øt Governours; becau≈øe they are not able to look unto all things them≈øelves, but mu≈øt manage them by other men: many of which are negligent, others wicked, and ≈øwayed by depraved affections; and yet crafty enough to cover their own guilt. Here is the only comfort, That God notwith≈øtanding pre≈øerves Government, and Political Order; ‚òú and in his time will judge, even the Kings and Judges of the Earth.

[h] V. 17.] The la≈øt words of this Ver≈øe, may, in my judgment, be thus mo≈øt literally tran≈ølated out of the Hebrew: There is a time for (judging) every purpo≈øe, and every work there, viz. in tho≈øe corrupt Courts of Judgment: every thing that hath been tran≈øacted, in the Judicatures he had been ≈øpeaking of.

[i] V. 18.] The≈øe words, which follow the former, are variou≈øly interpreted: but they have a per≈øpicuous ≈øen≈øe, if they be taken in coherence with the foregoing (as in rea≈øon they ought to be) without fan≈øying, as ≈øome have done, that they are ≈øpoken in the per≈øon of an Epicure. And ≈øo I have con≈øidered them; as intended to take down the vain opinion tho≈øe Great Men have of them≈øelves (which makes them tyrannize over their Inferiours) by repre≈øenting to them
(or rather, de≈øiring God would effectually repre≈øent to their minds) how little they differ from Bea≈øts: ≈øave only in that, which they do not at all value, or regard, viz. their immortal ≈øpirits.

The word Lebaram, to manife≈øt them, is commonly expounded of Gods manife≈øting them unto others; but I have taken it for his ≈øhowing them to them≈øelves; agreeable to the word that follows, Lireoth, that they might ≈øee, &c. The whole may be thus tran≈ølated ‚Äîthat God would clear their minds, that they may ≈øee, &c. For it comes from a Root which ≈øignifies ≈øuch an accurate ≈øeparation of one thing from another; that the difference may be per≈øpicuou≈øly di≈øcerned.

[k] V. 21.] And thus it ≈øeems al≈øo mo≈øt rea≈øonable to me, to expound this la≈øt Ver≈øe, in connexion with all the re≈øt; and to under≈øtand the fir≈øt word of it, Who; concerning tho≈øe per≈øons mentioned in the beginning of this Di≈øcour≈øe. Who among tho≈øe unrighteous Judges, &c.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Having con≈øidered the power, which many times falls into the hands of unju≈øt and cruel men; he now repre≈øents the mi≈øcrable e≈øtate of tho≈øe that are ≈øubject to them: as a further Argument of the vanity and vexation, unto which Mankind are liable in this trouble≈øome World. And having noted ≈øome of the principal mi≈øchiefs of this ≈øort (of which I ≈øhall give a di≈øtinct account in the Paraphra≈øe and Annotations upon it) he concludes the Chapter with ≈øome Animadver≈øions upon the condition of the greate≈øt, nay, and the be≈øt of Princes: who are not ≈øo happy, as the World is apt to think them.

div.p: 1. SO I returned, and con≈øidered all the oppre≈ø≈øions that are done under the ≈øun: and behold, the tears of ≈øuch as were oppre≈ø≈øed, and they had no comforter; and on the ≈øide of their oppre≈ø≈øours there was power, but they had no comforter.

1. BUT I have not yet done with the con≈øideration of the mi≈øeries which Mankind ≈øuffer; by the abu≈øe of that power, which is nece≈ø≈øarily placed in the hands of ≈øome per≈øons for the good of others (III. 16.) For, reflecting again upon it, I ob≈øerved the innumerable ways that were practi≈øed in this World, for the undoing of others; both by violence and exactions, and by fraud and calumnies (as well as by unju≈øt Decrees) whereby ≈øo many were cru≈øhed, that nothing was to be ≈øeen or heard but the tears and cries, the ≈øighs and groans of ≈øuch as lay in a de≈øolate condition, and could find no relief; no, not ≈øo much as of one to comfort them: For ≈øuch was the greatne≈øs of their Oppre≈ø≈øors, who had gotten all power into their hands; that as they could not defend them≈øelves again≈øt them, ≈øo no body el≈øe dur≈øt expre≈øs their compa≈ø≈øion towards them, much le≈øs plead for them; for fear of being ≈øerved in the ≈øame kind them≈øelves. See Annot. [a].
2. Wherefore I prai≈øed the dead which are alreadly dead, more than the living which are yet alive.

2. Which made me think it was better to be among the dead, who have made an happy e≈øcape from all the≈øe calamities, than to remain ≈øtill alive; either to ≈øuffer under this tyranny; or to live in perpetual fear of it; or to behold with great grief of heart (but without power to help them) what many mi≈øerable Wretches endure.
3. Yea, better is he than both they, which hath not yet been, who hath not ≈øeen the evil work that is done under the ≈øun.

3. Or rather (for why ≈øhould I compare the living with tho≈øe, who, though they now lie at re≈øt in their Graves, have been heretofore very ≈øorely afflicted?) much more de≈øirable, than either of the≈øe, is it not
to have come into the World at all: and ≈øo to have had no ≈øen≈øe of the mi≈øeries, which the dead have formerly felt, and the living now undergo.
4. ¬∂ Again, I con≈øidered all travel, and every right work, that for this a man is envied of his neighbour. This is al≈øo vanity and vexation of ≈øpirit.

4. For, be≈øides what they ≈øuffer from mighty Oppre≈ø≈øors, they give one another a great deal of trouble; Pride, Ambition, Emulation, Envy and Hatred reigning ≈øo uncontroulably every where among all Orders and Ranks, all Trades and Profe≈ø≈øions, that when a man hath taken a great deal of hone≈øt pains, in ≈øome u≈øeful work, and brought it to perfection; in≈øtead of gaining credit by it, and being honoured for it, his Neighbours look awry upon him: nay, he is maligned, di≈øparaged and traduced, by tho≈øe, who either cannot or will not imitate (but only carp at) his ingenious labours. So vain it is to endeavour to excel others in Art or indu≈øtry; which procure a man ill will, when he looks for thanks and commendations: and ≈øuch an affliction it is to a mans ≈øpirit, to labour hard for an ungrateful World; who are tormented by that, which ≈øhould plea≈øe them; and cannot ≈øee any worth in another, but they are vexed within them≈øelves. See Annot [b].
5. The fool foldeth his hands together, and eateth his own fle≈øh.

5. But ≈øee now (as a farther in≈øtance of the Vanity of Mankind) what u≈øe ≈øome make of this: who are ≈øo ab≈øurdly fooli≈øh, as to be utterly di≈øcouraged and to ≈øit down in perfect idlene≈øs; becau≈øe there are ≈øuch oppre≈ø≈øions on one hand from tho≈øe above them (v. 1.) and ≈øuch emulations on the other hand, from tho≈øe that are equal with them, and under them (v. 4.) A wi≈øe re≈øolution this! to do nothing, becau≈øe others do ill; not to ≈øatisfie ones ≈øelf, becau≈øe others will be di≈øplea≈øed: not to ≈øatisfie, did I ≈øay? nay, he is hunger-bitten, and eaten up with cares how to live; he hath not a Rag to his Back to cover his nakedne≈øs; having reduced him≈øelf and Family, by his lazine≈øs, to extreme penury.
6. Better is an handful with quietne≈øs, than both the hands full with travel and vexation of ≈øpirit.

6. And though he want not excu≈øes for his folly, yet they are as idle as his ≈øloth: For he ≈øen≈øele≈øly applies that common Saying to his purpo≈øe, One handful with ea≈øe, is better than two without it. Which is very true, if rightly under≈øtood; and may ≈øerve to reprove both him, and tho≈øe from whom he learns this folly: for as idlene≈øs and emptine≈øs alway go together (and therefore he in vain expects to have ≈øo much as one handful without labour) ≈øo is a moderate E≈øtate gotten hone≈øtly with moderate diligence, and enjoyed hand-≈øomely with perfect contentment; better than the greate≈øt Trea≈øures gotten by oppre≈ø≈øion or with infinite toil, and enjoyed with anxious thoughts and fretting cares, and expo≈øing a man either to the hatred or the envy of others. See Annot. [d].
7. ¬∂ Then I returned, and I ≈øaw vanity under the ≈øun.

7. Nor is this all the folly into which men fall, by the forenamed tyranny and oppre≈ø≈øion (v. 1.) but, reflecting again upon this Subject, I ob≈øerved another extreme into which they run; no le≈øs void of rea≈øon, and of ≈øatisfaction than the former.

8. There is one alone, and there is not a ≈øecond; yea, he hath neither child nor brother: yet is there no end of all his labour, neither is his eye ≈øatisfied with riches, neither ≈øaith he, For whom do I labour, and bereave my ≈øoul of good? This is al≈øo vanity, yea it is a ≈øore travel.

8. For, as ≈øome grow idle, ≈øo others grow too ≈øcraping and penurious; it being no rare thing to find a man that lives ≈øingle, and alone, without ≈øo much as a Companion, and hath neither Child, nor Brother, nor Kin≈øman, to make his Heir; and yet he ≈øets no mea≈øures, either to his labours, or to his de≈øires, but toils and craves without end: and, which is ≈øtill wor≈øe, as he can ≈øcarce find in his heart to allow him≈øelf the nece≈ø≈øaries, much le≈øs the plea≈øures of this life, ≈øo it never comes into his mind to think, who ≈øhall be the
better for all this when he dies; and what a madne≈øs it is, both to rack his mind with cares, and to pinch his Belly, and deny him≈øelf the comfort of what he hath; for the ≈øake of he knows not whom.
This al≈øo certainly is not only a ≈øen≈øele≈øs and unprofitable folly; but one of the greate≈øt plagues and torments of humane life. See Annot. [e].
9. ¬∂ Two are better than one; becau≈øe they have a good reward for their labour.

9. How much wi≈øer is he, who not only enjoys what he hath him≈øelf; but takes others into his Society, to partake of the good things, that God hath given him? For nothing is more comfortable than good Company; as nothing is more dull and melancholy, than a ≈øolitary life: And be≈øides, when two or more are adjoined together in common coun≈øel, and mutual help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, they will not only act more cheerfully; but more ea≈øily effect their de≈øign, and take the greater plea≈øure in the fruits of their labour. See Annot. [f].
10. For if they fall, the one will lift up his fellow: but woe to him that is alone when he falleth: for he hath not another to help him up.

10. Or if they have any ill ≈øucce≈øs, or fall into danger, it will only make the ≈øingular benefit of fellow≈øhip, the more plainly appear; becau≈øe they will relieve and re≈øcue one the other: but lamentable is his condition, who hath no Friend, no Companion, to reach out his charitable hand to him, when he falls (≈øuppo≈øe in o a Pit; none to comfort him, when he is ≈øick; none to te≈øtifie his innocence, when he is defamed; or, which is wor≈øe, to re≈øtore him, when by his own imprudence or negligence, he falls into a ≈øin.
11. Again, if two lie together, then they have heat: but how can one be warm alone.

11. And therefore in the very beginning of the World, God did not think fit, to let man be alone, but gave him an Help meet for him: and as two that lie together in the ≈øame Bed, cheri≈øh one another, by their mutual hear, but it is hard to be
warm alone; ≈øo do they that are ≈øtrong, undaunted, vigorous and cheerful, infu≈øe that courage and comfort, which Silver and Gold cannot give, into tho≈øe that are of a weak, timorous, dejected or melancholy ≈øpirit.
12. And if one prevail again≈øt him, two ≈øhall with≈øtand him; and a threefold cord is not quickly broken.

12. To conclude, we are never more ≈øen≈øible of the benefit of Society, than when we are a≈ø≈øaulted by a powerful Enemy; whom we cannot re≈øi≈øt alone, but by the help of a Friend may be able to overcome: for as a great many Threds twi≈øted together, are not quickly broken, though a ≈øingle one be ≈øoon ≈ønapt a≈øunder; ≈øo he that is ≈øurrounded by his Children, Friends and Neighbours, will make a better defence, and hold out longer again≈øt tho≈øe that invade his right, than that wretched man can do (v. 8.) who by loving money alone, hath deprived him≈øelf of all ≈øuch ≈øuccours.
13. ¬∂ Beter is a poor and a wi≈øe child, than an old and fooli≈øh king, who will no more be admoni≈øhed.

13. But it is not Society alone will make a man happy, without Wi≈ødom and Vertue. For who are better attended, and guarded than Kings? and yet the poore≈øt man that is, if he be wi≈øe and good, is far happier than the wealthie≈øt Prince on Earth, who fooli≈øhly abu≈øeth his power: nay, the towardly Child of a poor man, is much better than ≈øuch a King, though his greatne≈øs be made more venerable by his grey hairs: For, be≈øides that Wi≈ødom makes the poor Youth contented with his condition, though never ≈øo mean, (a Ble≈ø≈øing at which Princes hardly arrive) it render whole≈øome admonition al≈øo acceptable to him, when by his inexperience he falls into an errour; but folly makes the other impatient of all advice and coun≈øel, and the older he is, the more ob≈øtinate; becau≈øe, as his Kingly Dignity, he fan≈øies, authrizes him to do what he li≈øt, ≈øo his Age gives him a privilege of knowing better than any body can tell him, what to do. See Annot. [g].
14. For out of pri≈øon he cometh to reign, whereas al≈øo he that is born in his kingdom becometh poor.

14. By which means it comes to pa≈øs, that he who was born a mere Beggar, nay, was as poor and abject as the vile≈øt Slave, ri≈øes by his ≈øingular Prudence, Coun≈øel and Conduct unto a Throne: when he who≈øe Ance≈øtors were Kings, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed his Dominions by an Hereditary right, is de≈øerted by his Subjects, and, through his folly and wickedne≈øs, falls into ≈øuch contempt, that he not only lo≈øes his Crown, but is reduced to the greate≈øt poverty, in which he ≈øpends a mi≈øerable life.
15. I con≈øidered all the living which walk under the ≈øun, with the ≈øecond child that ≈øhall ≈øtand up in his ≈øtead.

15. Or if this happen not, yet (≈øuch is the infelicity of good Princes) I have ≈øeen a great King, left with nothing but the bare Title, and the outward State of Royalty; the hearts and affections of all the Nobles, Gentry and common people, from one end of the Kingdom to the other, enclining to his Son (or to the next Heir) that is to ≈øucceed him; unto whom they do obey≈øance, as if he were already upon the Throne, but neglect his old Father; who ≈øees him≈øelf robbed of tho≈øe honours, in which he placed his happine≈øs; and that by his own Son, who would have been more dutiful, perhaps, if he had been a private man. See Annot. [h].
16. There is no end of all the people, even of all that have been before them: they al≈øo that come after, ≈øhall not rejoyce in him. Surely this al≈øo is vanity and vexation of ≈øpirit.

16. Nor is this a thing that will have an end, but a humour ≈øo rooted in all Mankind; that, as in all preceding times (before this King and Son were born) they have been weary of that, which they have long enjoyed; ≈øo this young Prince, who is now followed with ≈øuch applau≈øe, mu≈øt not think that it will la≈øt alway: but they that come after will take as little delight in him, as the pre≈øent Generation doth in his Father; and, when he grows old, court his Son after the ≈øame fa≈øhion, as they now do him, being young.

From all which it appears, that happine≈øs is not to be found in Honour and Dignity; no, not in the very highe≈øt Pitch of it, which is the Kingly Power: for there al≈øo is not only di≈ø≈øatisfaction, but many dangers, troubles and vexatious cares, which very much di≈øturb and perplex their Spirits. div.p: [a] V. 1. oppre≈ø≈øions] There are more evils than one, that ari≈øe from the ill admini≈øtration of publick Affairs. For they are either external or internal. And the external are two; either from Superiors, or from Equals and Inferiors. Tho≈øe from Superiors he ≈øpeaks of in this Ver≈øe, and calls by the general name of oppre≈ø≈øions. [b] V. 4. envied] Tho≈øe evils which come from Equals or Inferiors, he ≈øpeaks of in this Ver≈øe, and calls by the general name of Envy; which is a word in the Hebrew, that ≈øignifies, when it is taken in an ill ≈øen≈øe, all tho≈øe vicious affections, which are the cau≈øes, or the effects of envious emulation, at the good qualities or pro≈øperity of another per≈øon. contentious or factious emulation, I. Philip. 15. Envy and ≈øtrive, i. e. invidious contention.

For ≈øome (≈øeeing the forenamed oppre≈ø≈øions; or the envy that attends upon mens indu≈øtry and good ≈øucce≈ø≈øes) grow idle and leave off all bu≈øine≈øs (expre≈ø≈øed here by folding the hands, ≈øee VI. Prov. 10.) becau≈øe it is to no purpo≈øe to get, what another may pre≈øently take away; or if he keep, it rai≈øes him other Enemies, who grudge to ≈øee him ≈øo happy.

By this means ≈øuch a man brings him≈øelf to extreme poverty: ≈øo that Phra≈øe, Eateth his own fle≈øh, ≈øignifies. [d] V. 6. better is an handful] Which though it be a very ab≈øurd re≈øolution; yet he wants not Apologies for it. Nay, as if he were the only Wi≈øe man (≈øapientum octavus, wi≈øer than ≈øeven men that can render a rea≈øon, as Bi≈øhop Sander≈øon ≈øpeaks) he utters Sentences (but it is like a Parable in the mouth of a Fool, a Speech full of rea≈øon in it ≈øelf, but witle≈øly applied) and ≈øays that better is an handful with quietne≈øs, &c. Thus ≈øome under≈øtand this ≈øixth Ver≈øe: which others take to be Solomon's advice to the envious ≈øpoken of before, or to the covetous, ≈øpoken of afterward, that

[e] V. 8. one alone] And as this is the fault on one ≈øide; ≈øo, on the other, there are tho≈øe who turn their thoughts altogether, to ≈øave what they can: pinching them≈øelves, by a penurious way of living; both that they may ≈øeem poor and not worth the ≈øqueezing; and likewi≈øe, that they may have a ≈øecret re≈øerve of unknown Trea≈øure, in ca≈øe they be oppre≈ø≈øed. One, not a ≈øecond] is properly a man without an Heir, or a Succe≈ø≈øor; as v. 15.

[f] V. 9. &c.] Upon the occa≈øion of the foregoing Ob≈øervation, v. 8. (the better to repre≈øent the folly of that ≈øotti≈øh humour, he there de≈øcribes) he ≈øets forth the benefit of Society, which Greg. Thaumaturgus here calls „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , living in fellow≈øhip, and communion together. Secondly, to pre≈øerve us in the enjoyment of that happine≈øs, when we have attained it: as he ≈øhews by three in≈øtances. Fir≈øt, To deliver us out of dangers, v. 10. Where is a Proverbial Saying, of a triple Cord, or Thread; like to which there are many in other Authors: but I forbear to fill this Paper with them, and leave tho≈øe al≈øo who have a mind to allegorical applications
of the≈øe three things, to ≈øeek for them in other Books. For my bu≈øine≈øs is only, to give a brief account of the literal ≈øen≈øe; which is this in ≈øhort: That a Companion will afford us his help and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance many ways; and, if there were no other benefit to be reaped from him, this would be an exceeding great comfort; to have one, in our adver≈øity, into who≈øe bo≈øome we may exonerate our ≈øorrows; which will be the lighter, if we ≈øee there is any Body that ≈øympathizes with us in our calamities.

[g] V. 13, 14.] And thus having repre≈øented the mi≈øerable effects of power abu≈øed to oppre≈ø≈øion: which bereaves men of the ≈øweete≈øt comforts of life; making them avoid Society: he returns to con≈øider the wretched e≈øtate of ≈øuch Oppre≈ø≈øors, though never ≈øo mighty. Both from their own folly, v. 13, 14. (where that expre≈ø≈øion is very remarkable, he is made, or becomes poor in his Kingdom, as Dr. Hammond well expounds it upon I. Matth. not. a) and from the ficklene≈øs and incon≈øtancy of the peoples affections; which creates a great many troubles even to good Governours, v. 15, 16. Where there are many difficulties in the Hebrew texts; but not ≈øuch as makes the ≈øen≈øe ob≈øcure: and an account is given of them by many Authors, and therefore I ≈øhall only note what the Lord Bacon hath ob≈øerved, for the illu≈øtration of the 15th. Ver≈øe, and what de Dieu hath noted upon the 16th.

[h] V. 15.] This Ver≈øe ≈øets out the vanity of the people; who are wont to pre≈øs and flock about the de≈øigned Succe≈ø≈øors of Princes; the root of which Vanity, ≈øaith the Lord Bacon (L. VII. Advanc. of Learn. Ch. 2. Parab. 20.) is that frenzy in the minds of men, which inclines them, with too extreme an affection, unto their own projected hopes. For the man is rarely found, that is not more
delighted with the contemplation of his future hopes, than with the fruition of what he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth. Another thing is, that novelty which is plea≈øing to man's nature, and earne≈øtly coveted: now in the Succe≈ø≈øor to a Prince (called here his ≈øecond, he that is next to him) the≈øe two concur; Hope, and Novelty. Which make more men (as Pompey ≈øaid to Scylla, and Tiberius afterward touching Macro) adore the ri≈øing, than the ≈øetting Sun. And though Princes perhaps, who are in pre≈øent po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, be not much moved with this fond humour, nor make any great matter of it (as neither Scylla nor Tiberius did) nay they ≈ømile, it is po≈ø≈øible, at the levity of men; and do not ≈øtand to fight with Dreams (for Hope is but the Dream of a man awake) yet it cannot but inwardly vex them, to ≈øee them≈øelves ≈ølighted, even by tho≈øe on whom they have be≈øtowed many benefits, merely in hope of receiving more from their next ≈øuppo≈øed Succe≈ø≈øor. For they cannot rea≈øonably expect more, perhaps, from him that now reigns; and therefore they make timely applications to the next Heir. And be≈øides, old men grow tenacious, moro≈øe and ≈øowre; whereas Youth is commonly liberal, jocound, without care, and ambitious to do great things; e≈øpecially at his entrance upon the Kingdom. This, ≈øaith another learned Writer, makes the long life of Princes, and their power, trouble≈øome and grievous, both to Courtiers and people: of which they that live at Rome, do not want ocular demon≈øtration.

There is nothing more needful for the explication of this Ver≈øe, but only to ob≈øerve, that the Child or Youth, who is here called the ≈øecond, doth not ≈øuppo≈øe another Child or Youth that is fir≈øt: but only ≈øignifie,

[i] V. 16.] The fir≈øt words of this la≈øt Ver≈øe, L. de Dieu ≈øeems to me, to have expre≈ø≈øed better than any other Interpreter: they running thus, word for word, in the Hebrew; There is no end to any people. div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Under an ill Government in the State, Religion it ≈øelf is commonly corrupted in the Church. And therefore having ≈øet forth the mi≈øeries people endure, under the oppre≈ø≈øions of an abu≈øed Power, and the extreams of folly into which it drives them; he begins this Chapter with a Correction of tho≈øe errours that are in Religion. Which is the only remedy indeed, the only comfort we have again≈øt all the troubles to which we are ≈øubject in this World: but ≈øuch is the Vanity of Mankind, they ≈øpoil their very remedy, and take away all the Vertue of that, which ≈øhould be their ≈øupport; turning it into mere Ceremony, whil≈øt their minds remain impure, and without any true ≈øen≈øe of God. For they do not con≈øider that He, who is a pure mind Him≈øelf, mu≈øt be better plea≈øed with pure thoughts and affections, compo≈øed to the ob≈øervance of his Will, and acquie≈øcence in his plea≈øure; than with all the Sacrifices and Offerings in the World, which the wicked may bring Him as well as the good.

To prevent therefore this new folly, into which men are apt to run, when they intend to cure all the re≈øt, Solomon ≈øhows all tho≈øe who would attain true tranquillity of mind; what they mu≈øt do, and what they mu≈øt avoid, in the Wor≈øhip of God. div.p: 1. KEep thy foot when thou goe≈øt to the hou≈øe of God, and be more ready to hear, than to give the ≈øacrifice of fools for they con≈øider not that they do evil.

1. 2. Be not ra≈øh with thy mouth, and let not thine heart be ha≈øty to utter any thing before God: for God is in heaven, and thou upon earth: therefore let thy words be few.

2. And, next to this, when thou make≈øt thy Prayers to God, or give≈øt Him thanks for his benefits, deliberate with thy ≈øelf beforehand, what it is fit for thee to ask of Him, or to vow unto him; and let not any ≈øudden pa≈ø≈øion, make thee incon≈øiderately, either with thy mouth or in thy mind, de≈øire what is nor fit for thee to have; or promi≈øe what is not fit for Him to receive, or thou art not able or willing to give.
