13. There is a ≈øore evil which I have ≈øeen under the ≈øun, namely, riches kept for the owners thereof to their hurt.

13. And, be≈øides all this, there is another thing which is very calamitous, and may rather be called a grievous plague, than a mere affliction; that the≈øe very Trea≈øures which men have heaped up, and pre≈øerved, with a great deal of care, from thence expecting their felicity, prove in the i≈ø≈øue their utter undoing: for I my ≈øelf have ≈øeen ≈øome of the≈øe mi≈øerable men, murthered by their Servants, or by Thieves, nay, by their own Children, that they might be Ma≈øters of the≈øe Riches; which bring them al≈øo, perhaps, at the la≈øt, into the ≈øame or the like de≈øtruction. See Annot. [m].
14. But tho≈øe riches peri≈øh by evil travail: and be begetteth a ≈øon, and there is nothing in his hand.

14. Or, if this happen not, the≈øe Riches peri≈øh (to their no ≈ømall grief and trouble) by fire; or ≈øhipwark; or bad Bargains; or ill Debtors; or tho≈øe very crafty practices whereby he ≈øeeks to encrea≈øe his E≈øtate; or by ≈øome other misfortune, or mi≈øadventure: ≈øo that his Son, whom he thought to have left po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of abundance of Wealth, hath nothing at all to ≈øupport a wretched life. See Annot. [n].
15. As he came forth of his mothers womb, naked ≈øhall he return to go as he came, and ≈øhall take nothing of his labour which he may carry away in his hand.

15. The≈øe things indeed do not always happen, but this which follows doth; that, though he die po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of all that he hath gotten; yet, he cannot carry one Farthing away with him: but in this, he and the poore≈øt Wretch are both alike, that as he came naked into this World, ≈øo he mu≈øt be ≈øtript again when he goes out of it; and, though his labour hath been great and his E≈øtate no le≈øs; yet, it is not in his power, to take along with him ≈øo much as a Winding-≈øheet; but what others plea≈øe to be≈øtow upon him.
16. And this al≈øo is a ≈øore evil, that in all points as he came, ≈øo ≈øhall he go: and what profit hath he that hath laboured for the wind.

16. This is another grievous affliction and ≈øore torment to Mankind, e≈øpecially to the Wealthy, that the things, on which they have ≈øet their hearts, cannot accompany them into the other World; for as the riche≈øt man that ever was brought nothing hither, ≈øo he can carry nothing thither; but mu≈øt leave all he hath behind him: and then what advantage hath he? what plea≈øure? wherein doth he differ from a mere Beggar? But in this only, that he hath taken a World of pains, to no purpo≈øe; for that which gives no ≈øatisfaction; and which he can hold no more than he can the Wind.
17. All his days al≈øo he eateth in darkne≈øs, and he hath much ≈øorrow, and wrath with his ≈øickne≈øs.

17. And as at Death he can find no comfort in all his Wealth, ≈øo he took as little perhaps in his life; but dwelt ob≈øcurely, and, denying him≈øelf even what he had, led ≈øuch a ≈øad, melancholy, and ≈øordid life, that his Meat, and his Drink, and the very light it ≈øelf, gave him no plea≈øure: for ≈øuch a man never thinks him≈øelf happy, but when ≈øome hope of gain ≈øhines upon him; and therefore, at other times; he pines, and grieves,
and frets, and vexes him≈øelf, at every thing, that makes and expence, or cro≈ø≈øes his covetous de≈øires and de≈øigns; in≈øomuch that the ≈øickne≈øs of his Soul appears in his pale and careful looks, and in his lean and meagre Body; which con≈øumes and wa≈øts, even by the ≈øorrow and ≈øadne≈øs, the vexation and di≈øplea≈øure of his mind. See Annot. [o].

18. ¬∂ Behold that which I have ≈øeen: it is good and comely for one to eat and to drink, and to enjoy the good of all his labour that he taketh under the ≈øun, all the days of his life, which God giveth him: for it is his portion.

18. Behold therefore the truth of that Ob≈øervation, which I have made more than once (II. 24. III. 12, 13, 22.) and now repeat again; that it is be≈øt for a man, and mo≈øt becoming, freely to u≈øe and enjoy the Riches he hath gotten by his hone≈øt labours; both for the con≈øtant ≈øupply of all the nece≈ø≈øities of Nature, and for moderate delight and plea≈øure, for the entertainment of his Friends, and the relief of his poor Neighbours; and this not for a Fit, but all the time that God is plea≈øed to continue him in this World: for this is all that falls to his ≈øhare, or that can truly be called his part, in the good things of this life; and the only way to prolong his days, and enlarge his portion in them. See Annot. [p].
19. Every man al≈øo to whom God hath given riches and wealth, and hath given him power to eat thereof, and to take his portion and to rejoyce in his labour: this is the gift of God.

19. And who≈øoever he be, whom God hath ble≈ø≈øed, not only with plenty and abundance of Worldly Goods, but al≈øo, with ≈øuch a noble and generous mind, that he is not their Slave, but truly Ma≈øter of them; being able to enjoy them innocently, and to take his full ≈øhare in them, and that with cheerfulne≈øs, and delight in doing good to others: let him be very thankful to Almighty God for ≈øo great and happine≈øs; and acknowledge it to be a ≈øingular Gift of his Bounty, wherewith he rewards his hone≈øt labours.
20. For he ≈øhall not much remember the days of his life: becau≈øe God an≈øwereth him in the joy of his heart.

20. For he that is thus highly favoured by God, will not think life tedious or irk≈øome; but (forgetting all his pa≈øt toils, and taking no care for the future) ≈øpend his time mo≈øt plea≈øantly: becau≈øe God hath given him his very hearts de≈øire, and he hath attained the ≈øcope of all his labours; in that inward tranquility of mind, or rather joy and gladne≈øs of heart, wherewith God hath compen≈øated all his pains, and te≈øtified his extraordinary kindne≈øs to him.

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p:
[a] V. 1.] To prevent, or cure that folly mentioned in the Argument of the Chapter) he advi≈øes three things about the Wor≈øhip of God. The fir≈øt of them is in this Ver≈øe; to look to the di≈øpo≈øition of their mind, when they go to Gods Hou≈øe. And this pious di≈øpo≈øition of mind, con≈øi≈øts al≈øo in three things: Fir≈øt, in frequenting the Hou≈øe of God, the place where He is wor≈øhipped: Secondly, in a reverent behaviour there; ≈øuitable to the great thoughts we have of God, and to the humble ≈øen≈øe we have of our own meanne≈øs: expre≈ø≈øed, by keeping or ob≈øerving the feet, i. e. taking care to put off their Shooes, or Sandals, as the manner was in tho≈øe Countries; and to go barefoot into the holy places; an≈øwerable to which now is, uncovering the head in our Churches, &c. as Mr. Mede well di≈øcour≈øes, in more places than one, Book II. p. 441, 546. and then, la≈øtly, in a readine≈øs of the Will to obey all the Divine Precepts as the be≈øt of Sacrifices. For this is the Sacrifice of wi≈øe and good men; and all other Sacrifices without this, are but the Sacrifices of Fools and wicked people: who are able, many times, to furni≈øh the Altar
with more Burnt-offerings, than the be≈øt of men. But they are ≈øuch Fools as not to con≈øider, that this very thing encrea≈øes their guilt; that they imagine God will be plea≈øed with the Sacrifice of Bea≈øts‚ñ™ without the Sacrifice of them≈øelves; in intire obedience to his Will. So our Tran≈ølation ≈øeems to under≈øtand the la≈øt Clau≈øe of this Ver≈øe: which may be thus al≈øo tran≈ølated, For they make no con≈øcience to do evil. It is no part of their Religion to ab≈øtain from wickedne≈øs: but fan≈øying by their Sacrifices they ≈øhall atone for that, they do not fear to commit it. To this purpo≈øe Maldonate expounds it, more plainly than any that I have read.

[b] V. 2.] Here he gives the ≈øecond Advice; which is about Prayer, and about Vows to God, or (as St. Hierom ≈øeems to take it, and to which Melancthon wholly confines it) about the Doctrines we deliver concerning God: which ≈øhould be very well con≈øidered, before we affirm any thing of Him. The two first are mo≈øt proper to the place, e≈øpecially the latter of them: both which I have comprehended in the Paraphra≈øe of this Ver≈øe.

[c] V. 3.] The rea≈øon for the foregoing Precept (of not u≈øing many words) taken from the con≈øideration of God's Greatne≈øs and our meanne≈øs (v. 2.) together with the inforcement of it in this Ver≈øe, is thus explained by St. Hierom. He requires us, that whether we ≈øpeak or think of God, we ≈øhould not venture beyond our ability; but remember our imbecillity; and that, as far as the Heaven is di≈øtant from the Earth, ≈øo much do our thoughts fall ≈øhort of the excellence of his Nature. And therefore our words ought to be very moderate: for as a man‚ñ™ that is full of thoughts, commonly dreams of tho≈øe things, whereof his head is full: ≈øo he that attempts to di≈øcour≈øe much of the Divinity, falls into folly. Or rather thus, Our words ought therefore to be few; becau≈øe even tho≈øe things,
which we think we know, we ≈øee through a Gla≈øs, and in aenigmate; and we do but dream of that, which we fan≈øie we comprehend. So that when we have ≈øaid a great deal (and to the purpo≈øe, as it ≈øeems to us) the Conclu≈øion of our Di≈øputation is mere folly.

And ≈øo much, we may be certain, he ≈øugge≈øts unto us, that in a multitude of words ≈øpoken unto God (as I rather under≈øtand it) there mu≈øt needs be many of them, as idle as mens thoughts are in a Dream. For the third Ver≈øe ≈øounds thus in the Hebrew, For a Dream proceeds from (or by) a multitude of toil≈øome bu≈øine≈øs; and the voice of a Fool from (or by) the multitude of words. That is, if a man have a multitude of cares in his mind, all the day, they will produce ≈øtrange, extravagant, or di≈øtracted Dreams in the Night: and, in like manner, if a man utter abundance of words, without con≈øideration and due weighing what he ≈øaith to God, many of them mu≈øt needs be fooli≈øh; whether they be Vows, or whether they be Prayers unto him (or whether they be Di≈øcour≈øes concerning Him; for we may refer it, if we plea≈øe, to all.) And the ≈øen≈øe will not much differ, if that Prepo≈øition, which we tran≈ølate from, be tran≈ølated with; in this manner, As Dreams come with a multitude of bu≈øine≈øs (i. e. bring before the mind, in a confu≈øed manner, what we have been doing, or thinking of, all day) ≈øo a Fools voice comes with a multitude of words, i. e. he utters a great deal of incoherent, confu≈øed ≈øtuff, &c. Or thus, the voice of a Fool comes in a multitude of words. And then the ≈øen≈øe will run thus: As a multitude of bu≈øine≈øs tires a man, and makes him but dream at la≈øt about it (and therefore he had better leave off, before he be unfit to attend it) ≈øo when a man enlarges him≈øelf too far in his Prayers or Di≈øcour≈øes of God) he doth but babble in a Conclu≈øion; and therefore had better be ≈øhorter.

[d] V. 4.] And now follows the third Advice, about the performing of Vows that have been made. Which is double; fir≈øt, not to delay the performance, nor put it off from time to time (which is the Subject of this Ver≈øe) le≈øt we be tempted, at la≈øt, not to perform our Vow at all; which is the ≈øecond thing: of which he ≈øpeaks in the next words, ver. 5. and 6. where he cautions again≈øt excu≈øes, which men are apt to make for not being as good as their intentions. Greg. Thaumaturgus hath expre≈ø≈øed both excellently, in a few words (alluding to the Hebrew word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ which ≈øignifies to complete) „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . A promi≈øe being made by a Vow, let it receive its perfection (or completion) by performance: and that with all ≈øpeed, as ≈øoon as it is due. For a Vow is an imperfect ≈øort of thing till it be made good: it hath only the beginning of a good thing, and wants its fini≈øhing; which if it have not, it becomes ugly and odious. For God loves not (that is, hates) to be ≈øo dealt withall, as if He did either not under≈øtand, or not mind what we ≈øay to Him: or would put up that affront which the poore≈øt man cannot but re≈øent. Who looks upon him≈øelf, as, not only abu≈øed but, de≈øpi≈øed; when men give him fair words, which either have no meaning, or deceive him when he depends upon them. This Solomon repre≈øents in the 5th. Ver≈øe, as far wor≈øe, than promi≈øing nothing at all; in which men may be unkind, but in this they are unju≈øt.

[e] V. 6.] And he pre≈ø≈øeth it further in this Ver≈øe; where by Malach Angel, there are tho≈øe that under≈øtand that particular Angel, which is ≈øuppo≈øed by ≈øome (but cannot be certainly proved) to attend upon every particular per≈øon; others under≈øtand the Prie≈øt, who is God's Mini≈øter: but I have followed Mr. Mede (Book II. p. 438.) who takes Angel here collectively, for more than one (as Tree is put for Trees, Leaf for Leaves, III. Gen. 2, 7.) which
attended upon the Divine Maje≈øty in his hou≈øe, where the Vow, he is here ≈øpeaking of, was made (ver. 1.) Which Angelical Mini≈øtry in God's hou≈øe was repre≈øented to the Jews, by filling all the Curtains of the Tabernacle with the Pictures of Cherubims, XXVI. Exod. 36, 37; and by carving the in≈øide of the Walls of Solomon's Temple, with the ≈øame, 1. King. VI; and by the Ark of the Te≈øtimony, being over≈øpread with two mighty Cherubims (having their Wings lifted up, and their Faces looking down towards it, and toward the Mercy-Seat) called the Cherubims of Glory, i. e. of the Divine pre≈øence, IX. Heb. 5. And all to ≈øignifie, that where God's ≈øacred Memorial is, there the Ble≈ø≈øed Angels, out of Duty, give their attendance. And therefore the LXX. I ob≈øerve, in this place, in≈øtead of before the Angel, have „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , before the face, or pre≈øence of God: who≈øe Mini≈øters the Angels were, and before whom the Vows men engaged them≈øelves in, being made; they were Witne≈ø≈øes al≈øo and Avengers of their excu≈øes, or of their delays, to make them good.

As for the Vulgar Tran≈ølation of tho≈øe words [it is an errour;] which is this, there is no Providence; I have taken no notice of it; becau≈øe it doth not ≈øeem to be the genuine meaning: for why ≈øhould a man make any Vows; who believes no Providence over him? Unle≈øs we will ≈øay, that he might alter his Opinion afterwards; and ≈øo we may put both ≈øen≈øes together, thus: I was in an errour, there is no Providence; and therefore I need not trouble my ≈øelf about my Vows.

[f] V. 7.] In the≈øe words he concludes his Di≈øcour≈øe about Religion, with a repetition (as ≈øome take it) of the third Ver≈øe: a little varied and enlarged. Which may be thus paraphra≈øed, according to our Tran≈ølation: To ≈øumm up all that concerns this matter; Since in a multitude of words, as well
as Dreams, there mu≈øt needs be much vanity; therefore have a greater reverence of God, than to ≈øpeak any thing ra≈øhly, or to make larger promi≈øes to Him, than thou art truly willing to make good.

In the Hebrew the words run thus: But from a multitude of Dreams (or when Dreams are multiplied) both vanity and words are multiplied; therefore fear thou God. Which may have this meaning; they do but merely dream of God, and are not awakened to a lively ≈øen≈øe of Him; who make either tho≈øe vain excu≈øes, or tho≈øe idle promi≈øes: of which thou maye≈øt not be guilty, po≈ø≈øe≈øs thy ≈øoul with an awful dread of his Maje≈øty. This is exactly agreeable to the Hebrew; if we take vanities to relate unto the excu≈øes of ignorance or error before mentioned; and Words unto Promi≈øes: and by multitude of Dreams under≈øtand, a great many conceptions concerning God; more like Dreams, than waking thoughts of Him.

Interpreters explain the words many other ways; whom the learned Reader may con≈øult: I have followed my own conjectures: And ≈øhall al≈øo propound another Tran≈ølation of the words, which ≈øeems to me very natural and ea≈øie; which is this: When, in abundance, Dreams, and vanities, and words, are multiplied; then fear thou God. That is, have a great care of thy ≈øelf, and let the dread of God overawe thee le≈øt thou offend, when thy head is hot and full of Dreams, and vain imaginations; which di≈øpo≈øe thee to ≈øpeak abundantly.

[g] V. 8.] As the foregoing Ver≈øe concluded his Di≈øcour≈øe about Religion; ≈øo this concludes the Third General Head, whereby he demon≈øtrates the vanity of all things; begun III. 16. Which he here admoni≈øhes us, ≈øhould not too much di≈øturb, much le≈øs quite a≈øtoni≈øh us: becau≈øe God will ≈øet all right, in his
due time. So he began it, III. 17. and ≈øo he here ends it, in this Ver≈øe. Which hath ≈øome difficulty in the la≈øt part of it; which we tran≈ølate, He that is higher than the highe≈øt, &c. Word for word, High above the high ob≈øerveth. But „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ in Hebrew, never ≈øignifies ≈øimply above; but always from above, or from on high: and therefore ≈øo ≈øhould be tran≈ølated here, He that is high, from on high ob≈øerveth. And then the only Que≈øtion is, who is meant by the high; whether God or his Vicegerent; the King here on Earth. I have expounded it of the latter; becau≈øe otherways the ≈øame thing mu≈øt be ≈øaid over again immediately. Which is not unu≈øual indeed in Scripture; but where there is no nece≈ø≈øity of it, and where the words will better bear another ≈øen≈øe, they are not to be ≈øo con≈øtrued. And the la≈øt word of the Ver≈øe, will no way be ≈øo plain; as by referring it, both to the high per≈øon mentioned before, and to all his inferior Potentates and Judges; whom he ob≈øerves from on high; that is, from his Throne, or from his Seat of Judgment. Where he ought to call them to an account, and examine any complaints that are made again≈øt them: or if he do not both he and they are ob≈øerved by the ≈øupreme Judge of all; and ≈øhall be accountable to Him, whether they will or no.

[h] V. 9.] And now he ≈øeems in this next Ver≈øe, to make a tran≈øition to the IVth. General Head (mentioned in the beginning) concerning the Vanity of tho≈øe; who place their happine≈øs, in getting and heaping up a great deal of money.

It is an ob≈øcure Ver≈øe, both in its connection, and in ≈øome of its Phra≈øes: and therefore is diver≈øly expounded by Interpreters. To help out the connection, I have made bold to preface a little, and al≈øo to add ≈øuch a Conclu≈øion, in my Paraphra≈øe upon it, as I took to be mo≈øt agreeable to what follows, and to
what went before. I have expre≈ø≈øed al≈øo both ≈øen≈øes of the la≈øt Clau≈øe, which we render, the King is ≈øerved by the Field; but may more literally be tran≈ølated, the King is a Servant (or is, addicted) to the Field. For anciently the greate≈øt per≈øons did not think it below them to follow Husbandry (who≈øe ju≈øt prai≈øes Cicero hath given in his Offices, but e≈øpecially in his Book de Senectute) as we are taught by the Examples of Hiero, Philometor, Attalus, Archelaus, Cyrus the younger in prophane Story; and by the Example of King Uzziah in Scripture, 2 Chron. XXII. 10. Which did not at all abate their courage, or dull their Wits; but only made the one more patient of toil and labour, and the other more ≈øolid and more ≈øerious. Whence it is that we find the greate≈øt Captains among the Romans, ≈øuch as Camillus, Regulus, Fabius, Cato, Cincinnatus, were fetcht from the Plough: as Gideon among the I≈øraelites was from the Thre≈øhing-floor; and Eli≈øha called to the high Office of a Prophet, as he was driving one of the twelve Ploughs, his Father had going in the Field.

And therefore Maldonate's Tran≈ølation of the≈øe words is not to be de≈øpi≈øed; who (and he alone, as far as I can find) thinks they are capable of being rendred thus: By following Husbandry diligently, a man may grow ≈øo rich as to become a King. Melancthon alone tran≈ølates the whole Ver≈øe thus, The King in the Earth, is above all for the Tillage of the Field. Where Solomon, ≈øaith he, di≈øtingui≈øhes a King from a Tyrant. A Tyrant depopulates his Country, and lays all wa≈øte; a good King cheri≈øhes his people, e≈øpecially hone≈øt Husbandmen and Farmers: and loves to ≈øee them thrive, together with all good Arts. The Vulgar Latine, I ≈øuppo≈øe, aimed at ≈øomething of this; though it be taken otherwi≈øe by tho≈øe that follow it. Agreeable to
which is this memorable Pa≈ø≈øage in a Per≈øian Writer quoted by Mr. Pocock (in his Notes upon Abul Faragii p. 202, 203.) that in that Country they kept a ≈øolemn Fea≈øt every Year; wherein the King de≈øcended from his Throne, laid a≈øide his Royal Apparel, threw the Veil from his Face, and conver≈øed with the mo≈øt ordinary people, even with Country Swains and Husbandmen: with whom he ate, ≈øaying; I am one of you; nor can the World ≈øub≈øi≈øt without Tillage, which is performed by your pains; and that Tillage ≈øub≈øi≈øts, it is owing to the King; ≈øo that neither of us, being able to ≈øub≈øi≈øt without the other, we are, as it were, individual Brethren.

There are tho≈øe that comprehend Pa≈øtorage, as well as Tillage, under the≈øe words; becau≈øe the antient Patriarchs were Shepherds. But there is no need of this; and Husbandry or Gardening was far more ancient: even as old as Adam; and after the Floud we find Noah thus employed; as I≈øaac al≈øo was in ≈øucceeding times.

[i] V. 10.] The latter end of this Ver≈øe, runs thus in the Hebrew Text: Who ≈øo loveth (viz. Silver) reaps no fruit of his abundance: i. e. doth not enjoy it, as St. Hierom expounds it; which is very often the mi≈øerable condition of worldly-minded men.

[k] V. 11.] The latter end of this Ver≈øe al≈øo, is capable of contrary ≈øen≈øes; which I have expre≈ø≈øed in the Paraphra≈øe; but ≈øhall not give an account of here, becau≈øe I ≈øee the≈øe Annotations already grow too large. For which cau≈øe I will not note particularly every thing that is ob≈øervable in the following Ver≈øes; but only touch upon ≈øome of them, under this Ob≈øervation, That he ≈øeems to demon≈øtrate the vanity of that ≈øort of happine≈øs, which men place in Riches, from Ten Con≈øiderations. The two fir≈øt are contained
in the tenth Ver≈øe, That the de≈øires of ≈øuch men are un≈øatiable; and the more un≈øatiable they are, the le≈øs they enjoy of what they have.

The third and fourth in the 11th. Ver≈øe, that if they will enjoy it, the more they have, the more others mu≈øt al≈øo have of it; and the plea≈øure of this is very ≈ømall; being no more, than to behold a great many people eat and drink at their Co≈øt.

[l] The fifth, v. 12th, That their Servants commonly ≈øleep more ≈øweetly than they. For ≈øo Haofed (which we tran≈ølate labouring man) ≈øignifies one that ≈øerves; that undertakes work for another; or any way mini≈øters unto him.

[m] The ≈øixth, That their Riches expo≈øe them to the danger even of their life; by poy≈øon, or by open violence, v. 13. Where the fir≈øt words R√°a chole, ≈øore evil, import ≈øuch an evil as makes one ≈øick, when he thinks of it; e≈øpecially when he fears it. For the Hebrew word Chalah always carries in it the Notion of ≈øickne≈øs and weakne≈øs; and that ≈øometimes accompanied with pain and torment (as in the ca≈øe of Hezekiah, XXXVIII. I≈øai. 1.) and proceeding from a deadly wound; as in the ca≈øe of Ahab, 1 King. XXII. 34. It may therefore be tran≈ølated here a tormenting or a deadly evil, or an evil that di≈øables a man, and makes him ≈øo feeble and langui≈øhing, that he is unfit for any thing. For the LXX. frequently render the Noun that comes from hence, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ : See v. 17. of this Chapter.

[n] And ≈øeventhly, Though they e≈øcape the≈øe dangers, there are many other ways whereby their Riches may be lo≈øt; which ≈øeem to be included in that Phra≈øe. v. 14. injan ra, an evil bu≈øine≈øs, or matter. Which may ≈øignifie, as well the way of their peri≈øhing; as that they peri≈øh with the great grief and affliction of him that lo≈øeth them. Whether that way be, by their very merchandice in the way of their trade;
or by their own frauds and ≈øubtilties in traffick, whereby they over-reach them≈øelves; or la≈øtly, by other accidents, as we call them; ≈øuch as Fire, Storms, &c.

And then follows the 8th, That he leaves his Son a Beggar; which is no ≈ømall trouble to them both, he having bred his Son in expectation of an E≈øtate, which never comes to him; or if it do, neither Father nor Son can enjoy it longer than their lives, v. 14, 15. [o] And whil≈øt they live (which is the la≈øt, v. 17.) they ≈øpend their time, perhaps, either in filthy lu≈øts (as Gregory Thaumaturgus under≈øtands tho≈øe words, eateth in darkne≈øs) with vile Harlots; or in wretched niggardice, and ≈øuch ≈øordid penuriou≈øne≈øs that the Mi≈øer even eats up him≈øelf; taking no joy, no comfort in any thing that he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øeth. So darkne≈øs ≈øignifies, being oppo≈øed to light and Scripture: which denotes joy and gladne≈øs; and thus the LXX. here explain it by adding a word, in darkne≈øs, and in mourning. It may refer al≈øo to his di≈ømal habitation (to which I have had re≈øpect in the Paraphra≈øe) in ≈øome bye place, where he hopes no body can find him; or in a Room, who≈øe Windows are ≈øhut up and barred for fear of Thieves.

The la≈øt Clau≈øe of this Ver≈øe, runs thus word for word in the Hebrew: Sorrow is multiplied (or there is much ≈øorrow) and ≈øickne≈øs, and wrath: the force of which I hope I have expre≈ø≈øed in the Paraphra≈øe: and ≈øhall only note, that the first word ≈øorrow (as was ob≈øerved Chap. I.) includes in it indignation, together with heavine≈øs: and the next word ≈øickne≈øs, includes in it pain and angui≈øh, as was ob≈øerved before: and the la≈øt word (ketzeph) wrath, denotes the highe≈øt commotion of that ≈øort. For being applied
to the Sea, it ≈øignifies ≈øuch a boiling rage, as makes it foam. There is another word indeed which we render hot di≈øplea≈øure: but this is joined with it (XXXVIII. P≈øal. 1.) as equivalent to it, or the effect of it.

[p] From all which he concludes this Chapter, as he had done his Di≈øcour≈øe upon the foregoing Subjects, with this Meditation (which ≈øome call ≈øententia intercalaris) that the greate≈øt Ble≈ø≈øing a man can enjoy in this life: is, to have an heart to u≈øe what God hath given him, for his own hone≈øt plea≈øure; with due acknowledgments to God, and charity to others, v. 18, 19.20. Where (v. 19.) there are two words to expre≈øs abundance of worldly goods, as I have paraphra≈øed them. The la≈øt of them neka≈øim is larger than the former, comprehending all manner of Goods (Cattel and all) which a man gathers together. For it ≈øeems, by a tran≈øpo≈øition of Letters, to be derived from kanas to collect or gather (Chap. II. 8.) from which comes the Latin word cen≈øus; the revenues, which a man is e≈øteemed to have, and accordingly is rated and pays Sub≈øidies.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: The fir≈øt ten Ver≈øes, at lea≈øt, of this Chapter, are a continuation of the ≈øame Argument he handled in the latter part of the foregoing: And therefore ought to be connected with it. For they ≈øet forth the vanity of Riches, in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a covetous Wretch: who only increa≈øes the number of unhappy men in this World; being never the better for any thing he enjoys, as he ≈øhows in the Conclu≈øion of the Chapter.

div.p: 1 THere is an evil which I I have ≈øeen under the ≈øun, and it is common among men:

1. BUT alas! this Divine benefit, tho' above all others, is coveted by very few: for I have ob≈øerved this mo≈øt wretched, mi≈øerable humour reigning among Mankind; which, though it be the greate≈øt mi≈øchief is grown ≈øo common, that it hath over≈øpread the face of the whole Earth.) See Annot. [a].

2. A man to whom God hath given riches, wealth, and honour, ≈øo that he wanteth nothing for his ≈øoul of all that he de≈øireth, yet God giveth him not power to eat thereof, but a ≈øtranger eateth it: this is vanity, and it is an evil di≈øea≈øe.

2. When a man is ble≈ø≈øed by God, with ≈øuch abundance of Money and Goods, and heighth of Honour, that he need not, unle≈øs he will, want any thing which his large≈øt de≈øires can wi≈øh ≈øhould admini≈øter to his plea≈øure; yet ≈øo great is his ingratitude to God, and his uncharitablene≈øs to men, that for the≈øe and other ≈øins, God denies him the power to enjoy the≈øe Gifts of his Bounty; to which he is a Slave, rather than their Ma≈øter: for he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes them, as if they were not his own, but kept by him, for ≈øome body el≈øe; and tho≈øe not his Children, nor his Kindred, but a mere Stranger perhaps; who (either in his life-time, or after he is dead) devours all that he hath ≈øaved. What can be more ≈øen≈øele≈øs than this? Nay, what ≈øorer Plague can infe≈øt Mankind? See Annot. [b].

3. ¬∂ If a man beget an hundred children, and live many years, ≈øo that the days of his years be many, and his ≈øoul be not filled with good, and al≈øo that he have no burial, I ≈øay, that an untimely birth is better than he.

3. Unle≈øs it be this, that one of this ≈øort of men, being ble≈ø≈øed al≈øo with abundance of Children, and with an exceeding long life; yet thereby is made only ≈øo much the more, and ≈øo much the longer mi≈øerable: being ≈øo ≈øolicitous for Po≈øterity that he hath no heart to take the comfort of any thing he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes at pre≈øent; no, nor ≈øo much as to take order for his decent Funeral, when he
is dead; but he goes out of the World without any notice that he hath lived in it. Of ≈øuch an one I pronounce, That an Abortive, which came into the World before its time, is not ≈øo de≈øpicable as he. See Annot. [c].
4. For he cometh in with vanity, and departeth in darkne≈øs, and his name ≈øhall be covered with darkne≈øs.

4. For though in this they are both alike, that they come into the World to no purpo≈øe; and go our of it ≈øo ob≈øcurely, that no body minds their departure; and leave no memory behind them, that they have been in it; See Annot [d].
5. Moreover he hath not ≈øeen the ≈øun, nor known any thing: this hath more re≈øt than the other.

5. Yet in this they differ, that an Abortive, having never ≈øeen the light of the Sun, much le≈øs been acquainted with any thing in this World, had no de≈øire to enjoy that of which it was perfectly ignorant, and was as utterly in≈øen≈øible of grief and pain, as it was of joy and plea≈øure: Whereas this mans un≈øatiable de≈øires, carrying him after every thing he ≈øees, torment his Soul with anxious thoughts, care and labour; which not only make him pine away with grief for what he cannot get, but deprive him of the comfort of what he hath. And how much better is it, never to live at all, than to live only to di≈øquiet a mans ≈øelf with re≈øtle≈øs ≈øolicitude of mind, and toil≈øome pains of body: for that which he can neither keep, nor part withal, with any contentment?
6. ¬∂ Yea, though he live a thou≈øand years twice told, yet hath he ≈øeen no good: do not all go to one place?

6. Men are ≈øo fond of life indeed, that becau≈øe the one lives long, and the other not at all, they imagine the former to be incomparably more happy: but let us ≈øuppo≈øe this covetous Wretch to live more than as long again, as the olde≈øt man that ever was; what is he the better for it, when his greedy de≈øires, not ≈øuffering him to enjoy his Goods, multiply his mi≈øeries equally to his years? Which will expire al≈øo at la≈øt, and then, what are his Riches able to do for him? can they privilege him
from going down into the Grave, and rotting there like the Abortive? See Annot. [e].
7. All the labour of man is for his mouth, and yet the appetite is not filled.

7. And while he lives, to what purpo≈øe is his re≈øtle≈øs labour? Seeing if he de≈øire only what is nece≈ø≈øary, it is ea≈øily provided; and having Food and Rayment, a man may be contented: and if he extend his de≈øires further, they are infinite; and therefore can never meet with any ≈øatisfaction.
8. For what hath the wi≈øe more than the fool? what hath the poor, that knoweth to walk before the living?

8. For let a man be, otherways, never ≈øo wi≈øe as well as rich, yet if he bridle not his de≈øires he is little better than a Fool: and he that is poor, but hath ≈øo much under≈øtanding, as to know how to behave him≈øelf among men ≈øuitably to his condition, and to be contented therewith, is incomparably the wi≈øer, and the happier man. See Annot. [f]
9. ¬∂ Better is the ≈øight of the eyes, than the wandring of the de≈øire: this is al≈øo vanity and vexation of ≈øpirit?

9. It being much better to enjoy what a man hath at pre≈øent, than to live upon the hopes of that which, his ravenous de≈øires continually pur≈øue: which ≈øure, is a very fooli≈øh thing, and another great part of the mi≈øeries of humane life; that men are ≈øtill craving more, when they know not how to u≈øe what they have already; and neglecting what they po≈ø≈øe≈øs, wi≈øh for that, which perhaps they cannot get; or if they do can give them no more ≈øatisfaction than what they po≈ø≈øe≈øs. See Annot. [f].
10. That which hath been, is named already, and it is known that it is man: neither may he contend with him that is mightier than he.

10. And what if a man have already arrived at great renown (as well as Riches) ≈øtill it is notorious, that he is but a man, made out of the Du≈øt: and therefore weak, and frail, and ≈øubject to many di≈øa≈øtrous events; which it is not po≈ø≈øible for him, by his mo≈øt anxious cares, to prevent; or, by
his Power and Wealth, to throw off when he plea≈øes. See Annot. [g].
11. ¬∂ Seeing there be many things that increa≈øe vanity, what is man the better?

11. And ≈øince there are ≈øo many things, and of great con≈øideration, that adde to the natural uncertainty which attends all worldly enjoyments, what can a man promi≈øe him≈øelf from all his cares? and how frivolous are his hopes? And how ≈øen≈øele≈øs are they, when they will not ≈øuffer him to enjoy any thing, for fear of dimini≈øhing that heap, which they would fain encrea≈øe? See Annot. [h].
12. For who knoweth what is good for man in this life, all the days of his vain life which he ≈øpendeth as a ≈øhadow? for who can tell a man what ≈øhall be after him under the ≈øun?

12. For (be≈øide all that hath been ≈øaid) there is this great mi≈øchief will ≈øtill remain, that if he ≈øhould attain his hopes, he cannot tell, whether it would not have been better for him to have been di≈øappointed: for alas! what man is there that hath skill enough to know, whether that eminent ≈øtation (for in≈øtance) to which he a≈øpires, will prove ≈øo good for him, as the private condition wherein he is? and the ≈øame doubt may be made of all other things, which he de≈øires in this ≈øhort life: which pa≈ø≈øes away in≈øen≈øibly, but very ≈øwiftly; and ends in the like uncertainty, what ≈øhall become of a mans Family and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, which he leaves behind him, when he departs our of this World. See Annot. [i].

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p:
[a] V. 1. common] Covetous Wretches, it ≈øeems, were no rare Creatures in tho≈øe days, but the Nation of the Jews abounded with them; being of the ≈øame humour they are now, ≈øcraping up Riches by right or wrong, which they ≈øcarce ever enjoy. But I have expre≈ø≈øed al≈øo the other ≈øen≈øe of the word Rabba,
which ≈øignifies great (VI. Gen. 5.) as well as many or frequent.

[b] V. 2. riches, &c.] He de≈øcribes in this Ver≈øe the ridiculou≈øne≈øs, as well as the mi≈øery, of this penurious humour; by the example of a man who wants nothing, and yet wants all that he hath: being like one that ≈øtands up to the Chin in Water; but fears to take a ≈øip to quench his thir≈øt. For to tho≈øe two words, riches and wealth (mentioned in the 19th. Ver≈øe of the foregoing Chapter) he here adds a third, to expre≈øs the greate≈øt plenty, viz. glory. Which is more comprehen≈øive than the other; including in it all tho≈øe goodly things, which may do a man credit, and rai≈øe him to a ≈øplendid condition in this World. For ≈øo Laban's Sons call the ample Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions which Jacob had got in their Fathers ≈øervice, all this glory (XXXI. Gen. 1.) or ≈øub≈øtance, as ≈øome render it: which made him (as we now ≈øpeak) a ≈øub≈øtantial man; for it denotes any thing that hath weight in it, and makes a man to be valued.

Evil di≈øea≈øe] That which was called Raa choleh, a ≈øore evil, Chap. V. 13, 16. is here called choli ra, an evil di≈øea≈øe, ≈øad ≈øickne≈øs, or grievous torment. Which is only an inver≈øion of the words, the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe being ≈øtill pre≈øerved.

[c] V. 3 days of his years, &c.] He ≈øeems to repre≈øent in this Ver≈øe an higher degree of that evil di≈øea≈øe, by the example of one, who hath not only great ≈øtore of money, and lands, and honour; but al≈øo abundance of Children; and ≈øuch firm health, that he lives to a great Age. Which is expre≈ø≈øed by two Phra≈øes which we tran≈ølate thus, live many years, ≈øo that the days of his years be many: but to avoid tautology, the latter Clau≈øe ≈øhould be thus tran≈ølated, and the days of his years be abundantly ≈øufficient: ≈øo many, that he cannot rea≈øonably expect, or de≈øire more. For thus rab ≈øignifies
in many places, where we tran≈ølate it enough, XXIV. Gen. 25. ≈øtraw and provinder enough: XXXIII. Gen. 11. I have enough, my Brother. And yet this man thus abundantly provided for a long happine≈øs, doth no good either to others, or to him≈øelf, with what he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes: but grutches even the expences of a Funeral, after he can hold his Riches no longer. So I understand tho≈øe words, he have no burial. Which are generally understood, I confe≈øs, of lying neglected, without any interment: which the Hebrews (every one knows) lookt upon as a great Judgment: (≈øee XXII. Jer. 19.) and ≈øo Anton. Corranus glo≈ø≈øes upon the≈øe words; By the ju≈øt Judgment of God, ≈øuch Wretches, who would not feed the poor while they lived, become the Food of Dogs, or Crows when they are dead.

[d] V. 4. he cometh in] is born. With vanity] or in vain, to no purpo≈øe. Which ≈øome refer to the covetous Wretch, others to the Abortive, before-named: But I have referred to both. For this makes the clearest ≈øen≈øe; if in the next Ver≈øe (v. 5.) we ≈øuppo≈øe that he compares the≈øe two together, and prefers the latter before the former; as he plainly doth in the conclu≈øion of it.

[e] V. 6. ≈øees no good] To ≈øee is to enjoy as the Phra≈øe is u≈øed in many places: particularly XX. Levit. 17. XVII. S. John 24. And the ≈øen≈øe of this Ver≈øe is, That the life of a covetous man is ≈øo far from making him happier, than he who never lives at all; that if he ≈øhould live as long again as Methu≈øalem, he would only be ≈øo much the more wretchedly mi≈øerable. For when he hath tired him≈øelf with labour, he hath not taken one step towards ≈øatisfaction: which he might have had with le≈øs pains, if he had taken the right cour≈øe to it, ver. 7.

[f] V. 8. what hath] There is ≈øo great a difficulty in this Ver≈øe, that I did not know how to connect it with the foregoing; but by taking the latter part of the Sentence, as if Solomon had ≈øaid, What compari≈øon is there between him (viz the man before named) and the poor that knows how to walk before the living? i. e. the poor man who hath ≈øo much skill, as to know to live well, is infinitely to be preferred before him; who≈øe Wi≈ødom ≈øtill leaves him ≈øuch a Fool, that it doth not re≈øtrain his ≈øuperfluous appetites. And this ≈øuits well with the next words (v. 9.) where the ≈øight of the eyes, being oppo≈øed to the wandring of the de≈øire; it is rea≈øonable to take it for the fixedne≈øs of a mans mind, to re≈øt ≈øatisfied in what is before him: that is, in things pre≈øent.

Or the words may admit of this con≈øtruction (which is come into my mind, ≈øince I wrote the Paraphra≈øe) What excellence is there in the Wi≈øe man (that is, in the opinion of the wretch before-mentioned, there is none) more than in a Fool, e≈øpecially if he be poor, &c. That is, to all other mi≈øeries of the≈øe rich Churls, this is commonly added, That they are very ignorant of what is mo≈øt truly valuable; having no e≈øteem of the wi≈øe≈øt man in the World, no more than a of a Fool. Nay, they prefer a rich Fool, before a poor Wi≈øe man: who knows how to carry him≈øelf ≈øo decently, that he is not afraid to appear before any man living. This is a great ≈øotti≈øhne≈øs (v. 9.) and breeds no le≈øs ≈øorrow; to be led by blind Appetites, and not by Rea≈øon and Judgment. For ≈øo the first words of the ninth Ver≈øe, may be interpreted: Better it is to under≈øtand aright, than to follow after ones de≈øires.

[g] V. 10. That which hath been] The ≈øence that I have given of the beginning of this Ver≈øe (taking the fir≈øt word for an Interrogation, and name for
renown, as is common in Scripture) ≈øeems to me to be the mo≈øt ≈øimple; and mo≈øt agreeable to the whole Di≈øcour≈øe. And it is that which Melancthon hath expre≈ø≈øed in the≈øe words, Although a man grow famous, yet it is known that he is but a man; and he cannot contend with that, which is ≈øtronger than him≈øelf. That is, he cannot govern events. But I ≈øhall mention two other Interpretations, which ≈øome give of it. One is this, As he was made at fir≈øt, ≈øo his Name was given him; i. e. the Name of Adam, ≈øignifying that he was taken out of the Earth, and therefore mortal. The other is this; He that hath been, his Name is called already; that is, his memory is aboli≈øhed together with him≈øelf. This is Maldonate's ≈øen≈øe; but is not agreeable to the Hebrew Phra≈øe, his Name is called; for that in the Scripture ≈øignifies rather the contrary, viz. fame, and honourable mention, as I have expre≈ø≈øed it word for word out of the Hebrew, in the Paraphra≈øe. The common Interpretation may be found in all commentators, which is this; that God hath appointed what every man ≈øhall be; whether rich or poor, &c. and therefore it is in vain for them to contrive, as they do, to be other than what they are: For it is to endeavour to alter that which is immutably ≈øettled by the Almighty.

[h] V. 11. ≈øeeing there be] This Ver≈øe ≈øumms up all this matter about Riches; or, as others will have it, the whole foregoing Di≈øcour≈øe, concerning all tho≈øe four things, wherein men place their happine≈øs: wherether Wi≈ødom, Plea≈øure, Honour, or Wealth. Which draw ≈øo many, and ≈øo great (for the Hebrew word includes both) inconveniences along with them; as ≈øufficiently demon≈øtrate a man is ≈øtill to ≈øeek for the ≈øatisfaction of his de≈øires, if he look no further.

And ≈øo they would have the la≈øt Ver≈øe, to be an Introduction to the following Di≈øcour≈øe in the next Chapter: where he ≈øhows, wherein that true and ≈øolid happine≈øs lies, which Mankind vainly pur≈øue in the forenamed enjoyments. But I have connected it with what goes before in this Chapter: as the Particle (for) in the beginning of it, ≈øhows it ought to be.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Having di≈øcour≈øed, in the foregoing part of this Book, of the vain cour≈øes men take to make them≈øelves happy; be now ≈øeems to proceed to pre≈øcribe the be≈øt remedies that can be found, against that vanity to which we are ≈øubject: by ≈øetting down many wi≈øe Precepts for our direction, and conduct, ≈øupport, and comfort in a trouble≈øome World. Where, it is confe≈ø≈øed that, our happine≈øs can be but imperfect; yet ≈øo much we may attain as to be well ≈øatisfied, and not vex our ≈øelves that we cannot make things more certain and constant; nor di≈øpo≈øe men to be more ju≈øt and equal to us than they are.

And if we examine the following Particulars, we ≈øhall find they are comprehended in this General Direction; the change of our mind, thoughts and opinions: which must be quite altered; ≈øo that tho≈øe things which now look like Paradoxes, must be judged the greatest Wi≈ødom. Such are all the Doctrines that begin this Chapter (quite oppo≈øite to the common Opinions of the World) that a good name is to be preferred before precious Ointment, and the day of ones death, before ones birth-day: mourning before fea≈øting; ≈øadne≈øs before laughter; rebukes before commendations; the end
of a thing before the beginning of it; a patient ≈øuffering ≈øpirit, before a ≈øtout haughty mind; Wi≈ødom before riches, &c. The≈øe and ≈øuch like are the Maxims of true Wi≈ødom and Piety, which mu≈øt be learnt; in order to the ≈øettlement of our minds in peace and tranquility: notwith≈øtanding the vanity that is in all things.

div.p: 1. A Good name is better than precious ointment; and the day of death than the day of ones birth.

1. BUT, though there be ≈øuch uncertainty in all other things, yet a Good Name, which a man gets by a vertuous life, is la≈øting and durable: And as the Con≈øcience of well-doing gives a greater plea≈øure to the mind for the pre≈øent, than the mo≈øt fragrant Ointment can do to the ≈øen≈øes of voluptuous men, ≈øo the fame of it will remain after he is dead; and he will ≈øtill live in a good report, when all tho≈øe ≈øen≈øual joys expire, like the vapour of the Ointment, which is ≈øoon di≈øper≈øed and lo≈øt after it is poured out: And therefore if we would be happy, we ought to order our life in ≈øuch a manner, that Death, which Fools and wicked men fear, may be welcome to us; and only let us out of the troubles, into which we are brought at our birth. See Annot. [a].
2. ¬∂ It is better to go to the hou≈øe of mourning, than to go to the hou≈øe of fea≈øting; for that is the end of all men, and the living will lay it to his heart.

2. And, that it may befriend us, it is our Wi≈ødom to think often of it; and con≈øequently, chu≈øe rather to conver≈øe with things that will make us ≈øerious, than with tho≈øe which will make us merry: to go, for in≈øtance, into the Company of tho≈øe, who are mourning for the dead, rather than of tho≈øe, who are fea≈øting for joy that a Child is born into the World: For in the mid≈øt of tho≈øe plea≈øures we are apt to be di≈ø≈øolute and to forget our ≈øelves: but that ≈øad ≈øpectacle enclines us naturally to be con≈øiderate, and di≈øpo≈øes our mind to humility, mode≈øty, gentlene≈øs, ≈øobriety and charity: when, in one we ≈øee the fate of all; and we follow him to his Grave, who a little while agone, perhaps, was as vigorous and ≈øtrong as our ≈øelves, See Annot. [b].
3. Sorrow is better than laughter: for by the ≈øadne≈øs of the countenance the heart is made better.

3. Sadne≈øs, therefore, and ≈øorrow, is much more profitable for us than mirth and jollity (as we ≈øee in tho≈øe ≈øevere and ≈øtern rebukes, which make men ≈øorrowful for their faults) becau≈øe that grief which makes a man look ≈øadly, whether it be for his own ≈øins, or other mens calamities, is apt to do his Soul good; by giving him a right under≈øtanding of God, and of him≈øelf, and of all things el≈øe. But they that di≈ølike my connection, must rest ≈øatisfied (as far as I can ≈øee) with that of Corranus (which hath more colour for it, than any other) who takes this Ver≈øe to be a Preface to what the Wi≈øe man had to add concerning the ≈øubtil Arts of Women to draw men in, if they be not exceeding cautious. Their wits being ≈øo ver≈øatile, their cunning ≈øo ≈øly, and their allurements ≈øo many, that he profe≈ø≈øes he found them inexplicable; though he had ≈øpared no pains to penetrate into them. This he makes the ≈øen≈øe of ver. 23, 24, 25.

[t] V. 26.] And then, in this Ver≈øe, Solomon gives an account of the danger they are in; who ≈øuffer them≈øelves to be in≈ønared by the Arts of naughty Women (who are ≈øo numerous, that he advi≈øes him, who would be good, to be very cautious how he enters into familiarity with that Sex) who have brought ≈øore calamities upon the greate≈øt men; ≈øuch as Sam≈øon, David and Paris, and many other be≈øides Solomon him≈øelf. The next Ver≈øe I have made to relate to that. The two words we tran≈ølate ≈ønares and nets (to which he compares her heart, i. e. her invention, devices, &c.) both ≈øignifie nets. Only the former ≈øignifies the Nets of Hunters; the latter, the Nets (or Draggs rather of Fi≈øhermen, (XXVI. Ezek. 5.) as the LXX. di≈øtingui≈øh them. The former indeed is applied al≈øo to Fi≈øhes, in this Book, IX. 11. and therefore the truer difference perhaps is, that the former ≈øignifies finer, the latter cour≈øer, but stronger Nets: ≈øuch as cannot be broken, but will certainly de≈øtroy; as the Root, from whence Cherem comes, denotes. Both the≈øe words are in the Plural Number to denote, the va≈øt multitudes that they catch; and the innumerable ways they have to entangle them, and hold them fa≈øt.

[u] V. 28.] Gregory Thaumaturgus interprets this Ver≈øe altogether of their Cha≈øtity; after this manner: I have found a cha≈øte man, but never a cha≈øte woman: And, indeed, of that he is ≈øpeaking, which makes this ≈øen≈øe not unrea≈øonable: though I have not ≈øo re≈øtrained it, nor do I think this is to be lookt upon, as the true Character of Women, in General, in all Ages, and Countries; but of ≈øuch only as Solomon was acquainted withal; and of tho≈øe in that, and the neighbouring Nations; e≈øpecially of Women there excelling in beauty, which commonly betrayed them to their ruine, and to the ruine of others; without an extraordinary Grace to pre≈øerve them.

[x] V. 29.] In the beginning of this Ver≈øe, Melancthon thinks, Solomon ≈øpeaks not of the fir≈øt creation of man, but of the Rule of mens actions, which God propo≈øed to them: The ≈øen≈øe being, as if he had ≈øaid, God in≈øtituted a good Order how men ≈øhould behave them≈øelves in all things; but they contrive how to go beyond their Bounds. As David, for in≈øtance, had many Wives of great beauty; but he would not be content without another mans. Antony. had a great power, but he would be a Monarch: which is the fault of many other Great Men.

This I have not altogether neglected; and al≈øo taken notice of de Dieu's Interpretation of the la≈øt words of the Ver≈øe, Men ≈øought out the thoughts of the great or mighty: taking Rabbim for Magnates. That is, not contented with his own condition, he affected to be like the Angels, nay like God.

Maimonides refers it to the evils and mi≈øeries man draws upon him≈øelf, here in this World: under≈øtanding by che≈øchbonoth (inventions) mans fooli≈øh rea≈øonings, whereby he precipitates him≈øelf, into all the evils he endures. For he thinks he wants this and that, when he doth not: and he thinks this and the other thing makes him mi≈øerable, which hath no hand in it. But we may ≈øay as Malachi doth (I. 9.) this hath been by means of your own ≈øelves; and as this Wi≈øe man el≈øewhere (Prov. XIX. 3.) The fooli≈øhne≈øs of man perverteth his way; and his heart fretteth again≈øt the Lord. More Nevochim, Pars III. Cap. 12.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p:
In this Chapter the Wi≈øe man pur≈øues the de≈øign of the former. Wherein he having given ≈øeveral Advices, as a proper remedy for the vanity and trouble we find in all things (the principal of which are ≈øeriou≈øne≈øs, mindfulne≈øs of our mortality, integrity, meekne≈øs, patience, prudence, in not exa≈øperating men when we can avoid it, caution in conver≈øation with Women) he now adds ≈øeveral other of no le≈øs moment; which have re≈øpect not only to private, but al≈øo to publick per≈øons. And they amount to this (that I may give as ≈øhort a Summary as I can of the Chapter) to ≈øhow how happy we all ≈øhould be, if both Subjects, and Princes al≈øo would be advi≈øed and con≈øiderate. But if they be not, good men ≈øhould make them≈øelves le≈øs mi≈øerable, by not being either too much di≈øturbed at it, or giving any publick di≈øturbance; much le≈øs by di≈øbelieving Providence, though they do not ≈øee the World governed, as they would have it, to the encouragement of the good, and the puni≈øhment of the bad: but to enjoy what they can hone≈øtly, in the pre≈øent condition wherein they are: and be contented and ≈øubmit to the Divine Government (though we do not under≈øtand it) when any alteration comes: and not add this affliction unto all the rest, anxiou≈øly to enquire into
tho≈øe things, of which we are not able to give an account.

div.p: 1. WHO is as the wi≈øe man? and who knoweth the interpretation of a thing? a mans wi≈ødom maketh his face to ≈øhine, and the boldne≈øs of his face ≈øhall be changed.

1. THere is no man ≈øo happy, as he that is wi≈øe enough to under≈øtand, and to live by the≈øe Rules: But let that man remember al≈øo, that as true Wi≈ødom gives the greate≈øt comfort, confidence and courage to him≈øelf, ≈øo it is apt to make him kind and gentle unto others; And therefore let no man pretend unto it, unle≈øs it di≈øpo≈øe him unto ≈øuch Vertues: For the deeper in≈øight he hath into men, and bu≈øine≈øs, and things, and the better able he is to ≈øolve all doubts and difficult Ca≈øes, and thereby ≈øatisfie both him≈øelf and other men; the more friendly, courteous and affable ≈øhould he be to all; and the more humble, meek and gentle al≈øo: Which is far more Maje≈øtical, and will gain him greater reverence, than au≈øterity, ≈øurline≈øs, and pride. See Annot. [a].
2. I coun≈øel thee to keep the kings commandment, and that in regard of the oath of God.

2. And let no man think I have re≈øpect merely to my ≈øelf, in what follows, becau≈øe I am a King; but look upon this as a principal Point of Wi≈ødom, both for his own, and for the publick ≈øafety; to live in dutiful Obedience to the Kings Edicts, and Commands, which do not thwart the Laws of God: and that, not merely for fear of his di≈øplea≈øure, and the penalty of the Law, if it be broken or neglected; but out of re≈øpect to God, who≈øe Mini≈øter he is; and whom his Subjects called to witne≈øs unto the ≈øincerity of their hearts, when they ≈øwore true faith and allegiance to him. See Annot. [b].
3. Be not ha≈øty to go out of his ≈øight: ≈øtand not in an evil thing, for he doeth what≈øoever plea≈øeth him.

3. Let not thy pa≈ø≈øion tran≈øport thee to ≈øhow the lea≈øt di≈øre≈øpect to him, much le≈øs to refu≈øe his Commands unmannerly, or to do any thing that may throw
thee out of his favour; but, if thou ha≈øt offended him, let thy next care be not to per≈øi≈øt ob≈øtinately in thy errour, but to humble thy ≈øelf and beg his pardon: not imagining thou can≈øt flee ≈øo fa≈øt from his anger that it ≈øhall not reach thee; for his power is ≈øo large, that it will, one time or other, lay hold on thee and puni≈øh thee. See Annot. [c].
4. Where the word of a king is, there is power: and who may ≈øay unto him, What doe≈øt thou?

4. For the Kings Commands are backt with Power; ≈øo that, if he give Sentence again≈øt thee, his Officers are ready to do Execution immediately: never examining whether it be right or wrong; but holding them≈øelves obliged to do as he bids them. And indeed who may que≈øtion him, or call him to an account, that hath no Superior? Or who can controul him, that hath all the power of the Kingdom in his hands? See Annot [d].
5. Who≈øo keepeth the commandment ≈øhall feel no evil thing: and a wi≈øe mans heart di≈øcerneth both time and judgment.

5. Therefore, not only for Con≈øcience ≈øake, but, for thy own ≈øafety and ≈øecurity yield obedience to the Kings Commandment; for ≈øo thou ≈øhalt avoid the trouble both of thy mind and of thy body: And if thou pretende≈øt to Wi≈ødom, ≈øhow it, not in oppo≈øing him and contending with him but, in a prudent declining what thou can≈øt not hone≈øtly do; and in ob≈øerving and taking the fitte≈øt Sea≈øon, and in the mo≈øt inoffen≈øive and winning manner, to in≈øinuate good advice, when the King commits an errour. See Annot. [e].
6. ¬∂ Becau≈øe to every purpo≈øe there is time, and judgment; therefore the mi≈øery of man is great upon him.

6. For want of which ≈øort of prudence men ≈øuffer very much: becau≈øe there is a certain ≈øea≈øon for, and a certain manner of, doing every thing; which if it be not under≈øtood (and it requires no ≈ømall pains to be able to di≈øcern it) or not embraced, it is not only impo≈ø≈øible to be done, but many and great inconveniences in≈øue upon that over≈øight, or neglect. See Annot. [f].
7. For he knoweth not that which ≈øhall be: for who can tell him when it ≈øhall be?

7. For no man can be ≈øure that the like opportunity will return again: future things being ≈øo much in the dark, that neither he, nor any one el≈øe can inform him what ≈øhall be hereafter; or when that will come, which in the cour≈øe of things may probably be expected. See Annot. [g].

8. There is no man that hath power over the ≈øpirit to retain the ≈øpirit: neither hath he power in the day of death: and there is no di≈øcharge in that war, neither ≈øhall wickedne≈øs deliver tho≈øe that are given to it.

8. But let no Prince, though never ≈øo great, pre≈øume hereupon to abu≈øe his Power to Tyranny, becau≈øe he hath no Superiour to controul him; but remember the≈øe things following. Fir≈øt, that though he command over mens bodies, yet he hath no dominion over their minds and ≈øpirits; nor can he hinder them from thinking what they plea≈øe, no more than he can the Wind, from blowing where it li≈øteth: and next, that he cannot command them long; for Death will come, and irre≈øi≈øtibly ≈øeize on him, as well as on the meane≈øt man: nay, he cannot rule the Chances of War, nor promi≈øe him≈øelf certain Victory in the day of Battel: or if he have had a great while good ≈øucce≈øs, yet neither his policy, nor his power, ≈øhall be able always to defend him from the vengeance that will be taken, of the inju≈øtice, cruelty, and impiety which he exerci≈øes in his Government. See Annot. [h].
9. All this have I ≈øeen, and applied my heart unto every work that is done under the ≈øun: there is a time wherein one man ruleth over another to his own hurt.

9. There is no rea≈øon therefore to be ≈øo much as ambitious of great power; for in the view I have taken of all manner of things in this World, which I have weighed al≈øo and con≈øidered duly, I have ob≈øerved that ≈øometime unlimited power breaks it ≈øelf in pieces: and the Dominion to which a man is promoted, ends in his own ruine, as well as theirs
whom he pillages and tyrannically governs. See Annot. [i].
10. And ≈øo I ≈øaw the wicked buried, who had come and gone from the place of the holy, and they were forgotten in the city where they had ≈øo done: this is al≈øo vanity.

10. And, among other things, I al≈øo ob≈øerved ≈øuch wicked men carried to their Graves, who had been honoured as gods while they lived, becau≈øe they were God's Mini≈øters, and ≈øate in the Judgment-Seat, in that very place where He him≈øelf is pre≈øent; but were no ≈øooner gone, but they were forgotten, in that very City where they had enjoyed ≈øuch high Authority: ≈øo vain is the Pomp wherein Great Men live, and wherein they are buried; which vani≈øhes together with them, and, if they were not good in their place, is no more remembred. See Annot. [k].
11. Becau≈øe ≈øentence again≈øt an evil work is not executed ≈øpeedily; therefore the heart of the ≈øons of men is fully ≈øet in them to do evil.

11. But the≈øe Ob≈øervations move not vain men, who look no further than their pre≈øent pro≈øperity. For though God hath pronounced a dreadful doom again≈øt all wicked men, and e≈øpecially tho≈øe that abu≈øe their Power unto tyranny over others; yet becau≈øe execution is not pre≈øently done upon them, but they live in all earthly ≈øplendor, both they, and others al≈øo, by their example, grow more audaciou≈øly pre≈øumptuous in their wickedne≈øs; and think of nothing but doing mi≈øchief, by rapine, and all manner of iniquity in the World. See Annot. [l].
12. ¬∂ Though a ≈øinner do evil an hundred times, and his days be prolonged, yet ≈øurely I know that it ≈øhall be well with them that fear God, which fear before him:

12. Not con≈øidering or believing this, which I am a≈ø≈øured of, as an undoubted truth, that though ≈øuch a powerful Sinner commit innumerable ≈øpoils upon his poor Subjects, and no harm befal him a long time; yet, as God will make tho≈øe good men an amends who≈øe reverence
to his Maje≈øty makes them chu≈øe rather to ≈øuffer than to ≈øin; and, notwith≈øtanding all their oppre≈ø≈øions, maintain their integrity, and continue in awful obedience unto Him, and unto their Governours: See Annot. [m].
13. But it ≈øhall not be well with the wicked, neither ≈øhall he prolong his days, which are as a ≈øhadow; becau≈øe he feareth not before God.

13. So he will take a time to puni≈øh that impious Tyrant becau≈øe he de≈øpi≈øes God and his Providence, and fears not his Divine vengeance: Nor are we without Examples of ≈øuch men, who have ha≈øtned their own ruine; and by their violence ≈øhortned their Reign; and vani≈øhed away ≈øuddenly, like a ≈øhadow.

14. There is a vanity which is done upon the earth, that there be ju≈øt men unto whom it happeneth according to the work of the wicked: again, there be wicked men to whom it happeneth according to the work of the righteous: I ≈øaid that this al≈øo is vanity.

14. Such Examples, indeed, do not deter them from wickedne≈øs, becau≈øe they ≈øee In≈øtances on the other ≈øide (which is an afflicting con≈øideration) that vertuous men ≈øometimes fall into ≈øuch mi≈øeries, as the wicked rather de≈øerve to ≈øuffer; and, on the contrary, tho≈øe impious men enjoy all the pro≈øperity, which one would think, belongs only to the righteous: This, I have acknowledged already, is the lamentable condition of things, and a great part of the trouble of this World; to which I have given the be≈øt ≈øatisfaction I could, III. 17. V. 8. See Annot. [n].

15. Then I commended mirth. becau≈øe a man hath no better thing under the ≈øun, than to eat, and to drink, and to be merry: for that ≈øhall abide with him of his labour, the days of his life, which God giveth him under the ≈øun.

15. And mu≈øt again commend that advice wherewith I concluded one of the≈øe Di≈øcour≈øes (III. 22.) that this ought neither to di≈øcourage a man in vertuous proceedings, nor make him careful and ≈øolicitous
about events; but only move him, in the fear of God (of which I ju≈øt now ≈øpake, v. 11.) to be merry whil≈øt he may: For there is nothing better, than ≈øoberly and freely to enjoy the pre≈øent good things, which the bounty of God be≈øtows upon us; with thankfulne≈øs to Him, and charity to others: For when a man, by his pains and labour, hath gotten a great E≈øtate, this is all that he can call his; God having only lent him what he hath, for his pre≈øent u≈øe, while he tarries here in this life; and then he mu≈øt re≈øign it unto others, and give an account, how he hath u≈øed it, unto Him. See Annot. [o].
16. ¬∂ When I applied mine heart to know wi≈ødom, and to ≈øee the bu≈øine≈øs that is done upon the earth: (for al≈øo there is that neither day nor night ≈øeeth ≈øleep with his eyes.)

16. In this therefore re≈øt ≈øatisfied, and do not trouble thy ≈øelf with curious inquiries, Why things are admini≈øtred with ≈øuch inequality, as is beforementioned: for I have travelled, as much as any Body, in that di≈øqui≈øition, and, with great application of mind, have made a mo≈øt diligent ≈øearch into the cau≈øes and rea≈øons, of the whole management of affairs here in this World (my mind being one of tho≈øe, that is as eager and greedy of Knowledge, as others are of Riches; for which they toil all day, and take little re≈øt in the night.) See Annot. [o].

17. Then I beheld all the work of God, that a man cannot find out the work that is done under the ≈øun: becau≈øe though a man labour to ≈øeek it out, yet he ≈øhall not find it; yea further, though a wi≈øe man think to know it, yet he ≈øhall not be able to find it.

17. But this was all the ≈øatisfaction at which I could arrive, That the Providence of God, without all doubt, governs every thing in this World; but why He ≈øuffers the wicked to pro≈øper, and the vertuous to be oppre≈ø≈øed by them; why he doth ≈øomerime ≈øpeedily cut off a wicked Tyrant, and ≈øometimes defer the execution ≈øo long, that he lives to do a World of mi≈øchief, and yet goes perhaps to his Grave in peace (v. 10.) it is impo≈ø≈øible
to give a full account: For there is little or nothing that any man can know of the ≈øecrets of his coun≈øels, or indeed of any other of his Works; which are in≈øcrutable by us, though a man take never ≈øo much pains to find them out; nay, though the wi≈øe≈øt man in the World make it his con≈øtant bu≈øine≈øs, he will be ≈øtill forced to confe≈øs his ignorance; and the height of his knowledge will be to know, that God's ways are pa≈øt finding out.

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p: [a] V. 1.] To the advices he had given in the foregoing Chapter, he now adds ≈øome new ones; the fir≈øt of which is this; that the Wi≈ødom which will make us happy in this World, mu≈øt not make us moro≈øe and ≈øupercilious, ≈øevere and rigorous; but kind and benign, gentle and ea≈øie. And the more we know, the more humble we ought to be: and, by the very cheerfulne≈øs and plea≈øantne≈øs of our countenance, invite others to us; and not by our frowning, forbid them, or make them afraid to approach us.

This I take to be the meaning of the fir≈øt Ver≈øe; in my Paraphra≈øe upon which, I have had re≈øpect to ≈øeveral acceptations of the ≈øeveral Words, which it will be too long here to give an account of. They that will con≈øult Interpreters will find how they vary; and therefore I ≈øhall only mention the Expo≈øition of Melancthon upon the latter part of the Ver≈øe (which is not commonly known) which following the LXX, he thus tran≈ølates: Wi≈ødom is the light of a mans countenance; but a pertinacious (or impudent, ob≈øtinate) per≈øon is worthy of hatred. Which he explains in this manner, that Wi≈ødom which can judge aright, when ≈øeverity is profitable, or when lenity will do be≈øt, when it is fit to make War, when
to be quiet; brings a man great gladne≈øs; but a pertinacious per≈øon, who is ≈øtiff and ob≈øtinate in his Opinion; and will not hearken to tho≈øe that give him good coun≈øel, but follows the motions of his own anger and obeys his pa≈ø≈øions, de≈øtroys him≈øelf and others. As the pertinacious humour, for in≈øtance, of Pericles and Demon≈øthenes was mo≈øt pernicious unto all Greece.

[b] V. 2.] This pertinacious humour ≈øhows it ≈øelf ofttimes, in oppo≈øing the Sovereign Authority: whereby men create to them≈øelves and others, great troubles in this World. And therefore Solomon advi≈øes men in the next place (de≈øiring them not to di≈ølike the coun≈øel becau≈øe a King gives it) to live in dutiful ≈øubjection to their Prince; as a ≈øingular means of leading a happy life. For it is hard to ≈øay, whether the Prudence and Ju≈øtice of a Sovereign, in ruling well; or the humble and peaceable ≈øpirit of the people in complying with the e≈øtabli≈øhed Orders; contribute most to the publick Welfare. Certain it is, that it is much ≈øafer and ea≈øier (as well as more honest) to ≈øubmit and be quiet, than to contend and un≈øettle the peace of Kingdoms; though Princes do not govern as they ought.

Melancthon makes this Ver≈øe to contain two Precepts (as the LXX al≈øo ≈øeems to do) in this manner: Ob≈øerve the Commandment of the King; and the word of the Oath of God. A Sentence, ≈øaith he, exceeding worthy of con≈øideration and remembrance: in which he commands us to ob≈øerve the Command of the King; but with this re≈øtriction, that we ob≈øerve the Law of God, and do nothing contrary unto that. For he calls the Law the Oath of God; becau≈øe God made the Sanction of it, in promi≈øes and threatnings with an Oath. But this Interpretation wholly neglects one word in the Hebrew, viz. al: and it draws both dibrath and ≈øhebuath Elohim from their
ordinary and u≈øual ≈øen≈øe, to a meaning that is forced and strained. For which rea≈øon another Expo≈øition is not natural; which makes this indeed one Precept; but instead of taking the latter part of it for an obligation to ob≈øerve it, turns it into a re≈øtriction of it; in this manner: Keep the Kings Commandment, but according to the Oath of God; that is, as far as Religion and the Faith we owe to the great Lord of all will ≈øuffer.

This is true, but not the true ≈øen≈øe of the Hebrew word for Oath; which ≈øome would have relate to the Covenant made with God in Circumci≈øion; which is still further off from the bu≈øine≈øs than the Notion which Melancthon had of it. Our Tran≈ølation is the plainest and most literal; be obedient to the King, and that in regard (or becau≈øe of the matter) of the Oath, to which God is a Witne≈øs, and a ≈øevere Revenger of the breach of it. From which a modern Interpreter doth not much vary: who≈øe words it will not be unprofitable to ≈øet down in this place; which run thus in Engli≈øh. Regard the Kings mouth, i. e. Do what≈øoever comes out of his mouth; what≈øoever he commandeth and appointeth, out of that Authority which he hath by Divine Ordinance: and chiefly the intention of the Oath of God (≈øo he tran≈ølates the latter part of the Ver≈øe) "that is the Oath whereby every one citeth God as his Witne≈øs and Judge, that with a good Con≈øcience he will obey the King; becau≈øe God hath ≈øo commanded. Thus Joh. Coch. Which Oath is either tacit the very being in the condition of a Subject, carrying with it (as the late Primate of Armagh ≈øpeaks) by implication, a ≈øilent Oath of Fidelity and due Obedience) or expre≈øs, in the direct Form of an Oath, which Princes have, for their better ≈øecurity, been wont to exact of their Subjects. There is an ancient Form, ≈øtill remaining
in Vegetius, of the Oath wherein the Souldiery bound them≈øelves to the Chri≈øtian Emperours: By God, and by Chri≈øt, and by the holy Gho≈øt, and by the Maje≈øty of the Emperour; which, next after God, was to be loved, and honoured. L. 2. Cap. 5. Where he adds this remarkable rea≈øon for it; becau≈øe to him, when he hath remarkable the Name of Augu≈øtus, faithful Devotion is to be performed, and all vigilant ≈øervice paid, as unto a pre≈øent and corporeal God. The violation of which Oath, though made to an Heathen Prince, how heinou≈øly God takes; even as a de≈øpi≈øing of an Oath made to him≈øelf, and a breach of his own Covenant, tho≈øe terrible threats do ≈øufficiently demon≈øtrate (XVII. I and what follows: ≈øhowing that it is a ≈øhort Form of Speech, to be ≈øupplied by ≈øome ≈øuch word as this, I ≈øay, or I command, or coun≈øel; or rather charge thee. Some may think that I have dilated too much upon this Ver≈øe: but they may be plea≈øed to con≈øider how u≈øeful, if not nece≈ø≈øary it is, at this time, when men begin again to plead the lawfulne≈øs of re≈øi≈øtance. [c] V. 3.] The fir≈øt word in this Ver≈øe is capable of ≈øeveral ≈øen≈øes, which I have endeavoured to expre≈øs in the Paraphra≈øe. For it originally ≈øignifies ≈øuch a pa≈ø≈øion and perturbation (particularly that of anger
and terror) as makes a man precipitant in his motions: being tran≈ølated ≈øometimes by „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and ≈øometimes by „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ in the LXX: And the meaning of the Wi≈øe man is, that in pur≈øuance of the foregoing coun≈øel (v. 2.) we mu≈øt take care, if we de≈øire to live happily, to ≈øuppre≈øs our pa≈ø≈øions; and not to ≈øhow the lea≈øt di≈øcontent with the Government: e≈øpecially not ha≈øtily and ra≈øhly to fling our ≈øelves (as we ≈øpeak) in a fume, out of the Kings pre≈øence, on any occa≈øion: much le≈øs receive his Commands with impatience; or, which is wor≈øt of all, incur his just di≈øplea≈øure by ≈øullen di≈øobedience. For though we may think to e≈øcape the effects of it, we ≈øhall find our ≈øelves deceived: Princes having long arms (as the Phra≈øe is) to reach tho≈øe that offend them; though they flee never ≈øo far from them. [d] V. 4.] And it is further enlarged in this Ver≈øe: where Symmachus tran≈ølates the first words thus, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , for the Command of the King is authoritative; carries ≈øuch authority with it, that it will be executed. And ≈øo it follows, in the end of this Ver≈øe, Who may ≈øay unto him, What doe≈øt thou? i. e. fir≈øt, Who hath any authority to call him to an account? as much as to ≈øay, none hath, but God alone. According to that of an eminent Rabbi (quoted by the forenamed Primate in the entrance of his Book about Obedience) No Creature may judge the King, but the Holy and Ble≈ø≈øed God alone. To allow the people (either collective, or repre≈øentative) to have power to do it, is to make them Accu≈øers,
Judges and Executioners al≈øo, in their own cau≈øe; and that against their Sovereign. Nor ≈øecondly, Can any man ≈øafely attempt it; but he ≈øhall meet with puni≈øhment either here or hereafter. Which is no new Doctrine, but the ≈øame with that of St. Paul (as Luther here honestly notes) they that re≈øi≈øt, ≈øhall receive to them≈øelves damnation; which none ≈øhall be able to avoid. Therefore it is ≈øafe≈øt ≈øimply to obey Magi≈øtrates. Which he repeats again upon v. 7. A man cannot do better than ≈øimply to obey. So Preachers, ≈øaith he, ≈øhould exhort the tumultuous and ≈øeditious. For judgment, vengeance, or puni≈øhment, is ordained and decreed by God, to all the di≈øobedient: which none ≈øhall e≈øcape. And thus much the Author of Natures Dowry is forced to acknowledge from the evident light he ≈øaw in this place; that the ≈øcope of the words is, that as we tender our own ≈øafety, we ought not to with≈øtand the Magi≈øtrate in his Edicts, which are con≈øonant to the Word of God. And it is Wi≈ødom, ≈øaith he (out of Eli≈øha Gallico an Hebrew Interpreter) in a private man, when the Magi≈øtrate enjoins what is repugnant to God's Will, to remove out of his Dominions, rather than conte≈øt with him. [e] V. 5.] From whence he again concludes it is the mo≈øt prudent cour≈øe, as well as mo≈øt hone≈øt, to comply with tho≈øe that have authority over us, in a dutiful obedience, or humble ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion. Wherein he ≈øuggests that the wi≈øest thing we can do, when Princes require any thing grievous unto us; is not to rebel; but, to watch the fitte≈øt opportunities to petition for redre≈øs: and that after ≈øuch a manner as may not give offence: So I have expounded time, and judgment, in this, and in the next Ver≈øe.

[f] V. 6.] For the truth is, a great part of the happine≈øs of our life, depends upon our di≈øcretion in ob≈øerving and chu≈øing, the fittest opportunity for every thing, and the right manner of doing it. [g] V. 7.] If the Hebrew reading would bear it, the Vulgar Tran≈ølation (which the Syriack follows) of this Ver≈øe, hath given an excellent rea≈øon, why a man is at ≈øuch a lo≈øs to di≈øcern what is fit for him to do upon all occa≈øions (e≈øpecially how to direct his behaviour towards Kings) Becau≈øe he knows little of what is pa≈øt; and le≈øs, or rather nothing, of what is future. Luther refers it wholly to the mi≈øerable condition of a Rebell, in this manner, He de≈øires various things and hopes for mighty matters by his di≈øobedience, but is lamentably deceived. [h] V. 8.] Hence he takes occa≈øion to give ≈øome good Advice to Princes them≈øelves (which ≈øeems to me the plainest ≈øen≈øe of this Ver≈øe) not to abu≈øe their Power, becau≈øe none can withstand them, or ≈øo much as question them: but to remember how weak they are upon many accounts; and therefore ought to be moderate in their Government, if they intend to live happily. P≈øal. 49. and there the Mi≈ølachat of evil Angels, ≈øeems to be a Company of Angels, ≈øent with a Commi≈ø≈øion to do the Execution there mentioned) which is too late to i≈ø≈øue in the day of Battel, if

„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the King commands with Authority, thus tran≈ølate the fir≈øt words of this, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , but no man (no not the King him≈øelf) hath authority in all things; for example, not over the ≈øpirit of a man. [i] V. 9.] This, and the following Ver≈øe, agree very well with that Expo≈øition which refers v 8. to Princes: who ≈øometimes are advanced to rule over others, to their own hurt. So we tran≈ølate the la≈øt words of this Ver≈øe; which Luther (who is not alone in that Opinion) will have ≈øtill to belong to Subjects, over whom a Prince is ≈øometimes placed to be a Scourge unto them. [k] V. 10.] This Ver≈øe I have taken wholly to belong to wicked Rulers; becau≈øe all the ancient Tran≈ølations do ≈øo, as well as our Engli≈øh. Though mo≈øt of the modern Interpreters will have the fir≈øt part of the Ver≈øe to refer unto wicked Governours, and the latter part unto good; who≈øe memory is aboli≈øhed, when the other (≈øo bad is mankind) are extolled and honoured: For which I ≈øee no rea≈øon, but look upon it as contrary to the de≈øign of the Wi≈øe man, in this place; and therefore I have rejected it.

The place of the Holy] may be expounded divers ways; but it ≈øeems to me mo≈øt natural, to take it for a Periphra≈øe of the Place of Judgment (mentioned III. 16.) in which the Judges ≈øu≈øtained the Per≈øon of God: who was in their A≈ø≈øembly, and judged in the mid≈øt of them, LXXXI. [l] V. 11.] From hence he takes occa≈øion to ≈øhow what is the very root of mens malicious and incurable wickedne≈øs. [m] V. 12, 13.] Yet this is not to be understood, he here ≈øhows, without exception; but ≈øometimes the Divine Ju≈øtice proceeds to quick execution. [n] V. 14.] Here he di≈øcovers the other root of mens
incurable wickedne≈øs, viz. the examples they ≈øee of, tho≈øe who live vertuou≈øly, and yet live mi≈øerably. [o] V. 15.] Notwithstanding which, the Wi≈øe man advi≈øes him that would live as happily, as the state of things here will permit, not to grow ≈øullen at this (v. 15.) much le≈øs to doubt of God's good Providence; nor to be disturbed, though we are not able to give a rea≈øon, why vertuous men ≈øuffer very much, when the wicked at the ≈øame time e≈øcape. That word in the Hebrew which we tran≈ølate becau≈øe though, is found only in this place; but from the I. Jo≈øhua 7. (where it is found in compo≈øition) the Doctors conclude it ≈øignifies, for that, or becau≈øe of; and ≈øo the meaning here is, that a man ≈øhall not be able by all the labour and pains he can take;
