div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: This Chapter begins where the foregoing ends; the Wi≈øe man proceeding ≈øtill to ju≈øtifie what he had ob≈øerved, about the mo≈øt puzling Que≈øtion in the World: Why the good and bad fare all alike, without any con≈øtant vi≈øible di≈øtinction? His re≈øolution, cautions, remedies, about this matter, will appear ≈øo plainly in the Paraphra≈øe and Annotations, which I ≈øhall annex to it, that I will give no large account here of this Chapter; but only note that the ≈øumm of it is this: That the confu≈øion of things here below, ≈øhould not move us to di≈øcontent; much le≈øs incline us to irreligion: but rather di≈øpo≈øe us, with thankfulne≈øs and ≈øobriety, to enjoy freely that portion of good things, while we have them, which God hath given us. Neither ≈ølackning our diligence, nor trusting to it alone; but depending on Gods wi≈øe Providence, which, notwithstanding that ≈øeeming confu≈øion, governs all events: di≈øappointing many times the most likely and applauded means; and again ≈øucceeding the most unlikely and contemptible. Which ≈øhould move us to commend our ≈øelves and concerns unto God; and then, above all things, to value and study true Wi≈ødom and Prudence, in the management of all Affairs: as far excelling mere power, of which we are fooli≈øhly ambitious.

div.p: 1. FOR all this I con≈øidered in my heart even to declare all this, that the righteous, and the wi≈øe, and their works are in the hand of God: no man knoweth either love or hatred, by all that is before them.

1. THis is no ra≈øh A≈ø≈øertion, for I Solomon affirm again (VIII. 16.) I have deeply con≈øidered all that belongs to this matter, with earne≈øt de≈øire and endeavour to give a clearer account, and fuller re≈øolution of it, than this, which is all I can ≈øay: that though good men and prudent are under the care of God (which mu≈øt ≈øatisfie them in all events) by who≈øe ≈øpecial Providence, both they and their undertakings and affairs, are approved, directed, governed and defended; yet (≈øuch a Secret there is in it) they prove ≈øometimes ≈øo un≈øucce≈øsful, that no man can know by any thing that befals them, or others, how God ≈øtands affected towards them: but will conclude very fal≈øly, if he judge that God loves him who hath all that his heart de≈øires; or that he hates him, who is ≈øorely afflicted. See Annot. [a].

2. All things come alike to all, there is one event to the righteous and to the wicked; to the good and to the clean, and to the unclean: to him that ≈øacrificeth, and to him that ≈øacrificeth not: as is the good, ≈øo is the ≈øinner: and he that ≈øweareth, as he that feareth an oath.

2. For there is no certain and con≈øtant di≈øtinction made between one man and another, in the de≈øtribution of things in this World; but they all fare alike, e≈øpecially in publick calamities: a righteous man, for in≈øtance, peri≈øhes in a Battel as well as the wicked; he that keeps him≈øelf pure and undefiled dies in a Pe≈øtilence, as well as the filthy and unclean; he that wor≈øhippeth God in ≈øincerity and truth ≈øuffers by Storms, Shipwracks and Inundations, &c. as well as a prophane per≈øon or an Hypocrite; and on the contrary a Bla≈øphemer of God, nay a perjured Wretch pro≈øpers and thrives, as much as he that dreads the holy Name of God, and dare not ra≈øhly, much le≈øs fal≈øly, take it into his mouth. See Annot. [b].

3. This is an evil among all things that are done under the ≈øun, that there is one event unto all: yea, al≈øo the heart of the ≈øons of men is full of evil, and madne≈øs is in their heart while they live, and after that, they go to the dead.

3. This (it mu≈øt be acknowledged) is one of the mo≈øt grievous things in this lower World, that all things being thus blended together without any di≈øtinction, ≈øome draw from thence this lewd and wild Conclu≈øion, That there is no difference between Vertue and Wickedne≈øs; and therefore take the greate≈øt licence to do evil confidently and boldly all their life long: pur≈øuing their own lu≈øts and pa≈ø≈øions ≈øo furiou≈øly, that they ha≈øten their end; and Death, which ≈øpares no Body (but is the mo≈øt common of all other things) ≈øeizes on them, before they think of it. See Annot. [c].
4. ¬∂ For to him that is joined to all the living, there is hope; for a living dog is better than a dead lion.

4. But who would chu≈øe to be a Companion of the≈øe mad men, who run them≈øelves ≈øo fa≈øt out of all hope? which ≈øtill remains (in the mid≈øt of all our changes here) as long as a man remains in the number of the living; but is lo≈øt when he is dead: in which re≈øpect the meane≈øt and mo≈øt contemptible per≈øon here in this World, hath the advantage of the greate≈øt King, when he is gone out of it. See Annot. [c].
5. For the living know that they ≈øhall die: but the dead know not any thing, neither have they any more a reward, for the memory of them is forgotten.

5. For while men live and are well, they have ≈øen≈øe and reli≈øh of ≈øuch things as they po≈ø≈øe≈øs; and, knowing they mu≈øt die, are taught thereby to u≈øe them with a ≈øober freedom: becau≈øe when they are gone from hence they become perfect Strangers to all things here, and can no longer enjoy and benefit of their labours (IV. 9.) the fruit of which falls into the hands of other men, who never ≈øo much as think what is become of them.
6. Al≈øo their love, and their hatred, and their envy is now peri≈øhed; neither have they any more a portion for ever in any thing that is done under the ≈øun.

6. 9. Live joyfully with the wife whom thou love≈øt, all the days of the life of thy vanity, which he hath given thee under the ≈øun, all the days of thy vanity: for that is thy portion in this life, and in thy labour which thou take≈øt under the ≈øun.

11. ¬∂ I returned and ≈øaw under the ≈øun, that the race is not to the ≈øwift, nor the battel to the ≈øtrong, neither yet bread to the wi≈øe, nor yet riches to men of under≈øtanding, nor yet favour to men of skill, but time and chance happeneth to them all.

[a] Ver≈øe 1. Though Solomon had often, and thoroughly con≈øidered that Que≈øtion, mentioned in the Argument of this Chapter; yet he could come to no re≈øolution about it, but this: That it ought not to ≈øhake our belief of God's love to vertuous men (which is expre≈ø≈øed
in that Phra≈øe, in the hand of God; wherein are included all the effects of his kindne≈øs and care) and that we mu≈øt not judge men to be good or bad, by what befals them in their outward e≈øtates. So tho≈øe words are mo≈øt naturally interpreted, A man knoweth not love or hatred, &c. Which ≈øome indeed refer unto men, not unto God, in this ≈øen≈øe: No man knows certainly what is be≈øt for him, in this World; and con≈øequently cannot tell what he ≈øhould de≈øire, and what deprecate, of all the things that are before him. For tho≈øe things, which he hates and is aver≈øe unto, may be as good for him as tho≈øe which he loves, and wi≈øhes to enjoy. To this purpo≈øe Maldonate. Or thus, No man knows whether that which he loves, or that which he hates ≈øhall befal him; but all things are before them: that is are appointed how they ≈øhall be, antecedent to the will of men. Thus Eben Ezra. And there are tho≈øe who interpret that Phra≈øe before them, in this manner: They ≈øee the good and evil which befals them, but cannot fore≈øee it till it come upon them. And ≈øome joyn both together thus, Neither the favour nor disfavour of men, neither their approving or oppo≈øing what we do, is any certain mark that we are good or bad.

But I have followed that ≈øen≈øe which ≈øeemed to me mo≈øt ≈øimple and mo≈øt coherent with the re≈øt of the words. As for that Doctrine which many great Writers in the Roman Church have built upon this Text, that no man can be certain whether he be in the favour of God or no, while he is in this life; Melancthon truly calls it, Interpretatio Monachorum; the Interpretation of the Monks; who di≈øtorted the words of Solomon, and wreathed them to their own dotages. For it is madne≈øs, ≈øaith he in another place (in his Treati≈øe of Good Works) to ≈øay, that we know not whether Murderers and Adulterers are worthy of God's hatred,

[b] V. 2.] For this next Ver≈øe plainly ≈øhows, that he ≈øpeaks of ≈øuch notes of God's favour or hatred, as men are very de≈øirous he would make; by putting a difference between good and bad men, in external things. The difference of the ≈øeveral expre≈ø≈øions u≈øed here in this Ver≈øe, for good men and bad, I have explained, as well as I could, in the Paraphra≈øe. And they that would ≈øee Examples of the ≈øame event to every one

[c] V. 3.] In this and the following Ver≈øes, he ≈øhows the ill u≈øe men make of the foregoing Ob≈øervation; and their folly therein. As for tho≈øe that fan≈øie the Wi≈øe man would here contradict him≈øelf in what he ≈øaid Chap. [d] There is little difficulty in the following Ver≈øes; where there are ≈øeveral pa≈ø≈øages which ≈øhow, that Solomon is not repre≈øenting the ≈øen≈øe of tho≈øe who believe nothing after this life; but hath re≈øpect only to the ≈øtate of men here in this World, as he ≈øaith expre≈øly in the conclu≈øion of v. 6. [f] V. 9.] Here is a new Proof, that this is not the Speech of Voluptuaries; for they love not to be confined to a Wife; as Solomon here advi≈øes his happy man to be: making her his Partner in all the joys and comforts he hath; as ≈øhe will be in his grief and ≈øorrows.

[h] V. 11.] But after all that we can do, he advi≈øes to a faithful dependance upon God and his good Providence: and not upon our own ≈øtrength or Wi≈ødom. By which Advice he reproves that old Saying, Faber qui≈øque Fortunae ≈øuae; Every man makes his own Fortune: "Which (as the Lord Bacon ≈øpeaks in a Di≈øcour≈øe, touching helps to the intellectual Powers: we ought to look upon as an in≈øolent and unlucky Saying: except it be uttered as an hortative or ≈øpur to correct ≈øloth; and (I may add) to excite us to watchfulne≈øs, in laying hold-of all opportunities, and neglecting no occa≈øions of doing our ≈øelves good. For otherwi≈øe, if it be believed as it ≈øounds, and a man enters into an high imagination that he can compa≈øs and fathom all accidents, and a≈øcribes all ≈øucce≈ø≈øes to his own drift and reaches, and the contrary to his errours and ≈øleepings, it is a prophane Speech, and it is commonly ≈øeen that the Evening-Fortune of that man is not ≈øo pro≈øperous, as of him that, without ≈ølacking his indu≈øtry, attributeth much to Felicity and Providence above him.

It is no impertinent inference which Corranus makes from the≈øe words, That all the things which the ≈øwift, the valiant, and the re≈øt of the per≈øons here mentioned
≈øeek, being their end, of which they frequently mi≈øs; it is an Argument that the happine≈øs of man con≈øi≈øts not either in Fame, or Victory, or eating and drinking, or riches, or the favour of others; but in contentment with ≈øuch things as we have, and God ≈øhall think good for us, in his wi≈øe Providence.

[i] V. 12.] Which hath given us many Examples of men, who incited by fal≈øe per≈øwa≈øions, and fooli≈øh hopes, dreamt of good events; when in the mid≈øt of their cour≈øe, they were oppre≈ø≈øed with great calamities. But Solomon here teaches us to con≈øider, how infinitely the wi≈øe Providence of God excels our greate≈øt wit and cunning, and can more ea≈øily over-reach all our
Coun≈øels, and overturn our well-laid de≈øigns, than we can out-wit the ≈øilly Birds and Fi≈øhes.

[k] V. 13, &c.] Which ≈øhould not di≈øcourage wi≈øe and regular Proceedings; but only make us refer our ≈øelves unto God: who, as He thus di≈øappoints the mo≈øt probable hopes, ≈øo, at other times makes men ≈øucce≈øsful, when they have no hope at all. As Solomon here ≈øhows in the following Ob≈øervation, v. 13, 14. Upon which St. Hierom glo≈ø≈øes in this manner: It hath been often ≈øeen, that a ≈ømall City and few Inhabitants, being be≈øet by an Army of innumerable Enemies, and be≈øieged ≈øo ≈øtraitly, that they were in danger, if not otherways, to peri≈øh by Famine; were, on a ≈øudden, contrary to all mens-expectation, delivered by a mean per≈øon, who having more Wi≈ødom than all the wealthy, great, powerful and proud Citizens, thought of a way to ≈øave them, when they gave them≈øelves for lo≈øt; and effected that al≈øo, of which they utterly de≈øpaired. And yet, O the ungrateful forgetfulne≈øs of Mankind! after the Seige was rai≈øed, after the liberty of their Country was re≈øtored, there was no body thought of this poor man, no body gave him thanks for their ≈øafety: but all honoured the rich, who in their danger could do them no ≈øervice.

[l] V. 15.] Which ≈øets forth, as the Lord Bacon ob≈øerves upon this Ver≈øe (L. 8. de Aug. Scient. C. 2. Parab. 21.) the depraved and malignant Nature of Mankind. Who in extremities and ≈øtraits, commonly flee to men of wi≈ødom and courage; whom before they de≈øpi≈øed: but ≈øo ≈øoon as the Storm is over, they become unthankful Wretches to their Pre≈øervers. Machiavel, not without rea≈øon, propounds the Que≈øtion, Whether ≈øhould be mo≈øt grateful to well-de≈øerving per≈øons, the Prince or the People? but in the mean time he taxeth
them both of ingratitude. Though this doth not ari≈øe merely from the ingratitude of the Prince, or the people alone; but there is added too oft to this the envy of the Nobility: who in ≈øecret repine at the event, though happy and pro≈øperous, becau≈øe it proceeded not from them≈øelves. Thus Themi≈øtocles was ≈øerved (as Luther here ob≈øerves) who having performed great things for his Citizens, was ba≈øely requited by them. Nay, David him≈øelf was ≈øoon forgotten, who had been the greate≈øt Benefactor to I≈ørael: ten of who≈øe Tribes ≈øoon renounced all dependance on his hou≈øe, and fell off quite from their ≈øubjection to it. So that to do good to the World, ≈øaith he, is to throw away the benefits we be≈øtow; or to ca≈øt Gold into Dung, and Pearls before Swine. [m] V. 16.] The beginning of this Ver≈øe may be illu≈øtrated out of Dion Pru≈øaeus (Orat. 2. de Regno) who ob≈øerves that Agamemnon wi≈øht rather for ten ≈øuch grave Coun≈øellors as Ne≈øtor, than ≈øo many valiant Youths as Ajax and Achilles,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ Where he ≈øhows al≈øo how great the power of Oratory is to ≈øubdue mens minds.

[n] V. 17.] Yet it mu≈øt be added, that the be≈øt and ≈øafe≈øt Coun≈øels, cannot be ≈øo much as heard or regarded, though never ≈øo wi≈øe, till peoples ≈øtraits have
made them humble, ≈øad and ≈øerious; as Aben Ezra expounds this 17th. Ver≈øe: The words of the Wi≈øe are de≈øpi≈øed by the people, when they are in pro≈øperity, but when they are in di≈øtre≈øs (almo≈øt fami≈øhed by ≈øuch a Seige as is before-mentioned) and ≈øilenced by fear and grief; then they li≈øten greedily and diligently. Which Melancthon expre≈ø≈øes better; The words of the Wi≈øe are heard by the ≈øilent: i. e. by ≈øuch as do not rage with any de≈øire; but ≈øeek the truth, and what is whole≈øome for them. This, and another obvious ≈øen≈øe of the Words, I have expre≈ø≈øed in the Paraphra≈øe; but have taken little notice of this, which ≈øeems not ≈øo near the meaning: that it is better to hearken to wi≈øe men, who per≈øwade to peace, than to tumultuous ≈øpirits, who incite ≈øilly people unto War.

He that rules among Fools, is an Hebrai≈øm for a great Fool: or we may understand it of one who≈øe authority ≈øways much among Fools, or of a fooli≈øh Commander. [o] V. 18.] All Authors furni≈øh us with abundance of Examples of the truth of the la≈øt Clau≈øe of the la≈øt Ver≈øe: but I ≈øhall only briefly mention a little of Melancthon's Glo≈øs upon the place. There are Ve≈ø≈øels of wrath, and Ve≈ø≈øels of mercy. The Ve≈ø≈øels of wrath are unhappy men, who bring de≈øtruction upon them≈øelves and others, though ≈øometimes they be great and wi≈øe per≈øons: According to that of Solon, Commonwealths are overturned by great
and excellent Wits. Such were Ahaz, Zedekiah, Cataline, Anthony and others. And in the Church, Samo≈øatenus, Arius, Manichaeus, and many other pernicious Doctors. Of all which Solomon ≈øays, One Sinner de≈øtroys much good,

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: The ≈øumm of this Chapter is, That, as true Wi≈ødom and Vertue is the only thing that can give us tranquility: ≈øo that part of it which teaches us to govern our tongue, and to behave our ≈øelves dutifully towards our Governours (though they do not manage things to our content, nor to the general good) conduces more unto it, than men are willing to believe. For this is, in a manner, the ≈øcope of the whole Chapter, to make every one ≈øen≈øible of the great Ble≈ø≈øing of Government; e≈øpecially of good Government: and that therefore they ought to bear with all manner of grievances; as a le≈øs mi≈øchief than the want of Government, by Rebellion again≈øt it. Which begins, in undutiful Di≈øcour≈øe: the folly and danger of which he admirably repre≈øents; with many other things tending to our pre≈øent peace and ≈øettlement.

div.p: 1. DEad flies cau≈øe the ointment of the apothecary to ≈øend forth a ≈øtinking ≈øavour: ≈øo doth a little folly him that is in reputation for wi≈ødom and honour.

1. AND the Wi≈øer or better any man is, ≈øo much the more cautious ought he to be, in all his words and actions; if he mean to pre≈øerve that credit, e≈øteem and authority in the World, which give him great advantages of doing good. For as dead Flies, though very ≈ømall Creatures, falling into a Pot of Ointment, and bur≈øting there, corrupt that precious Compo≈øition, which the Apothecary hath made with excellent Art; ≈øo that it turns the Per≈øume into a ≈øtink: in like manner doth a ≈ømall errour, or mi≈øcarriage blemi≈øh him, who was highly valued for his Di≈øcretion and Vertue; and the lea≈øt ≈øordid action de≈øtroys his reputation, who was honoured for his noble way of living. See Annot. [a].
2. A wi≈øe mans heart is at his right hand; but a fools heart is at his left.

2. It is hard indeed to be thus circum≈øpect; but herein a truly Wi≈øe mans worth is di≈øcovered, that his judgment never fails him in the greate≈øt difficulties: wherein he not only re≈øolves aright, and takes things by the right handle; but is ready al≈øo in the execution of what he de≈øigns, and manages his Affairs with ea≈øe, and with dexterity: whereas a Fool both mi≈øtakes in his aim, and fumbles al≈øo in the ea≈øie≈øt bu≈øine≈øs; which he handles ≈øo awkerdly, and untowardly, that it commonly mi≈øcarries. 3. Yea al≈øo when he that is a fool walketh by the way, his wi≈ødom faileth him, and he ≈øaith to every one that he is a fool.

3. And though he would di≈ø≈øemble his folly, and endeavour to ≈øeem wi≈øe, he is ≈øo far from his aim; that in every thing he doth, whether great or ≈ømall, he openly betrays his want of judgment: nay, by his very gate and behaviour, as well as by his words and actions, he tells every Body (as plainly as if he ≈øaid it in ≈øo many words) that he is a Fool: Which appears in nothing
more, than in his holding all for Fools, in compari≈øon with him≈øelf. See Annot. [c].
4. If the ≈øpirit of the ruler ri≈øe up again≈øt thee, leave not thy place; for yielding pacifieth great offences.

4. But a mans Wi≈ødom hath ≈øeldom a greater tryal, than when his Prince is angry with him, and perhaps treats him hardly; which incen≈øes a Fool, and makes him leave the Court, if not grow factious and rebellious: But it is better and ≈øafer Advice to keep in the ≈øtation, wherein thou art, and to do thy Duty faithfully; with a patient, but yet pen≈øive ≈øpirit: For nothing ≈øo appea≈øes a Princes offended mind, as to give way to his fury by mild and gentle words, and by mode≈øt, humble and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive behaviour; whereby a man al≈øo prevents a World of ≈øins, into which he throws him≈øelf, if he yield unto di≈øloyal thoughts. 5. There is an evil which I have ≈øeen under the ≈øun, as an errour which proceedeth from the ruler.

5. 6. Folly is ≈øet in great dignity, and the rich ≈øit in low place.

6. In advancing I mean (which I have too often ob≈øerved) the mo≈øt witle≈øs, carele≈øs men, and of ba≈øe condition; or ≈øuffering ≈øuch who are noted for nothing but their folly, and their vices, to creep up to the mo≈øt eminent Dignities and Offices: and in the mean time depre≈ø≈øing noble per≈øons, or making no account of them, though indowed no le≈øs with all excellent Qualities, than with Riches and Honour. 7. I have ≈øeen ≈øervants upon hor≈øes, and princes walking as ≈øervants upon the earth.

7. 8. Which foul indignities, notwith≈øtanding, a wi≈øe and vertuous per≈øon ≈øhould chu≈øe rather to wink at, and patiently endure, than think of moving any publick di≈øturbance; for ≈øuch coun≈øels are extremely hazardous, and commonly end in the ruine of tho≈øe that give them: according to that known Proverb among us, which admoni≈øhes us how dangerous it is, to pur≈øue our own de≈øires and pa≈ø≈øions violently (e≈øpecially again≈øt Kings and Princes) whereby men, in a heat, forgetting their own contrivances, have run them≈øelves into that very ruine, as Hunters do into the Pit, which they prepared for others: and that other common Saying, which warns us not to overthrow the well-≈øetled Laws and Cu≈øtoms of Church or State; for that is like the breaking down a Hedge: wherein as a Serpent many times lurks which gives him that attempts it a deadly bire; ≈øo they frequently draw upon them≈øelves their own de≈øtruction, who pull down the ancient Government. 9. Who≈øo removeth ≈øtones, ≈øhall be hurt therewith: and he that cleaveth wood, ≈øhall be endangered thereby.

9. We abound with 9. We abound with Proverbs to this purpo≈øe: Which teach us that the giving publick di≈øturbance, by invading the Rights of others (e≈øpecially of Kings) and endeavouring to change the Form of Government, is like removing the Boundaries of Lands; which rai≈øes great troubles or like the taking much pains to pull down a Building without

10. This is ≈øufficient to ≈øhow, how unprofitable all our endeavours are without true judgment. See Annot. [k].
11. Surely the ≈øerpent will bite without inchantment, and a babler is no better.

11. But of all other men he is the mo≈øt dangerous, who ≈øpits his Venom ≈øecretly again≈øt his Governours; ≈ølandering and traducing all their actions in his private Di≈øcour≈øes, and thereby enraging peoples minds again≈øt them; and giving them a more grievous wound than if they were ≈øtabbed with a Weapon: For that may be prevented, or healed afterwards, but this is like the biting of the mo≈øt deadly Serpent, which ≈øtopping its ear to all inchantments, poy≈øons both inevitably, and incurably. 12. The words of a wi≈øe mans mouth are gracious: but the lips of a fool will ≈øwallow up him≈øelf.

12. See here again the wide difference between a Wi≈øe man and a Fool. The former of which by his vertuous Di≈øcour≈øe wins every ones (e≈øpecially his Princes) favour; and doth good to tho≈øe with whom he conver≈øes:

13. The beginning of the words of his mouth is fooli≈øhne≈øs: and the end of his talk is mi≈øchievous madne≈øs.

13. And the more he talks, in the greater Danger he is: For, though he begin only with ≈øen≈øele≈øs and impertinent ≈øtuff, he heats him≈øelf before he hath done into a rage; and then minds not either how injurious his Di≈øcour≈øe is unto others, or how mi≈øchievous unto him≈øelf.
14. A fool al≈øo is full of words: a man cannot tell what ≈øhall be; and what ≈øhall be after him, who can tell him?

14. No, though he be admoni≈øhed of it he cannot de≈øi≈øt. For he abounds with words, and while he thinks to mend the matter, he makes it wor≈øe; adventuring to talk not only of things Civil, but of things Sacred; and not only of things pre≈øent, but of things pa≈øt al≈øo, nay, of things to come: In which wi≈øer men than he have little or no skill; and yet the le≈øs he knows, the more con≈øident and bold he is; when he doth not ≈øo much as fore≈øee the evil he is bringing upon him≈øelf, by his fooli≈øh prating. 16. ¬∂ Wo to thee O land, when thy king is a child, and thy princes eat in the morning.

16. What a mi≈øerable condition then, is that poor Country in, which abounds

17. Ble≈ø≈øed art thou, O land, when thy king is the ≈øon of nobles, and thy princes eat in due ≈øea≈øon, for ≈øtrength, and not for drunkenne≈øs.

17. And, on the contrary, the happine≈øs of that Nation is inexpre≈ø≈øible, who≈øe King is not only of an illu≈øtrious Family, de≈øcended from the mo≈øt ancient Nobility; but, having had ingenuous and liberal Education, doth not degenerate from their Heroical Vertue: which teaches him to place ≈øuch Officers under him, in their ≈øeveral ≈øtations, as make plea≈øure wait upon bu≈øine≈øs; which they fir≈øt di≈øpatch, and then refre≈øh them≈øelves; not to exce≈øs, but to fit them≈øelves to return to their bu≈øine≈øs again. 18. ¬∂ By much ≈ølothfuln≈øs the building decayeth, and through idlene≈øs of the hands the hou≈øe droppeth through.

18. 20. div.head: ANNOTATIONS.

[a] Ver≈øe 1.] He ≈øeems, in the first words of this Chapter, to pro≈øecute what he had ≈øaid in the la≈øt Clau≈øe of the foregoing; ≈øhowing how much good one Fool may ≈øpoil, by the great mi≈øchiefs that en≈øue one fooli≈øh action: whereby a man, otherwi≈øe famed for Wi≈ødom, utterly lo≈øes his reputation. So most Interpreters
understand the latter part of the Ver≈øe; which Melancthon, following the Vulgar, interprets quite contrary; that a little folly, or rather folly for a little while, is better than Wi≈ødom and Glory: That is, ≈øeeming folly, like that of Fabius, who was condemned for his ≈ølow proceedings, and thought a cowardly Fool; is better than Wi≈ødom which makes a glorious ≈øhow, but doth not conduct things ≈øo ≈øafely as that Captain did.

But this Expo≈øition agrees not at all with the Similitude, whereby Solomon illu≈øtrates what he here ≈øaith concerning Folly. Which is that of dead, or rather venomous Flies (for the Hebrew Phra≈øe Flies of death may better be tran≈ølated deadly, than dead Flies) which though very little Animals, yet falling into a Pot of precious Ointment, ≈øpoil it all when they putrefie: and not only take away the delicate ≈øcent, but turn it into a filthy, noi≈øome stink. For a Fly is ob≈øerved to be both foedum & foetidum Animalculum; e≈øpecially ≈øome ≈øort of them, which ≈øeem here to be particularly denoted by the Word Zebube: being not merely bred out of filth, and delighting to live in it, but leaving behind them ≈øuch a humour as is very offen≈øive to the ≈ømell, and kills tho≈øe Creatures into whom they thrust their ≈ønouts. From whence the God of the Ekronites had his Name of Baal zebub (2 Kings I. 2.) which if it were given him by his Wor≈øhippers, ≈øignified his power to de≈øtroy tho≈øe venomous Flies which infe≈øted the Inhabitants of that Country: if by the I≈øraelites, expre≈ø≈øed their contempt of him, as a mean, and a filthy, ≈øordid Idol. For therefore St. Hierom thinks the Prophet I≈øaiah compares the Egyptians to a Flie, VII. 18. not only becau≈øe they were a weak people, but propter ≈øordes Idololatriae, by rea≈øon of the ≈øordid filthine≈øs of their Idolatry: which was a great reproach to their famed Wi≈ødom: and

I cannot here omit the reflection, which the Lord Bacon hath made upon the≈øe words (L. VIII. de Augment. Scient. C. 2. Parab. 11.) that the ca≈øe of men eminent for Vertue, is very hard, and mi≈øerable; becau≈øe their errours, though never ≈øo ≈ømall, are by no means pardoned. But as in a pure Diamond, of great lu≈øtre, the very lea≈øt ≈øpeck or ≈ømalle≈øt cloud ≈øtrikes the eye, and affects it with a kind of trouble; which in a gro≈ø≈øer Stone would ≈øcarce be ob≈øerved: ≈øo in men of ≈øingular abilities, the lea≈øt infirmities are pre≈øently e≈øpied, and become the matter of mens di≈øcour≈øe, and are per≈øtringed with a heavier cen≈øure; which in men of meaner parts or rank would either pa≈øs without notice, or ea≈øily procure pardon. Therefore a little folly in a very wi≈øe man, a ≈ømall ≈øin in a very hone≈øt man, and a ≈ølight indecency of manners in a man of courtly and elegant behaviour, much derogates from their fame and reputation. So that it would not be the worst cour≈øe for excellent per≈øons, if they would mingle ≈øome ab≈øurdities (≈øo it may be done without guilt) with their actions: that they may maintain a kind of liberty to them≈øelves, and confound the Notes and Characters of ≈ømaller defects.

[b] V. 2.] From hence Solomon takes occa≈øion to repre≈øent more largely, how much men ≈øuffer by their folly, and what advantages Wi≈ødom gives them: and treats of both, with re≈øpect, not only to mens private, but to the publick good. And fir≈øt he ≈øhows what a difference there is between a wi≈øe man and a Fool, in the management of any bu≈øine≈øs. So I have interpreted this Ver≈øe, which may be al≈øo thus paraphra≈øed, A Wi≈øe man always takes
hone≈øt cour≈øes; but a Fool turns into bye ways. Thus Greg. And quotes a famous Pa≈ø≈øage of Lactantius (which I find in his In≈øtitutions, L. VI. Cap. 2.) concerning the Letter Y, unto which the Pythagoreans re≈øembled the cour≈øe of humane life. In which there is a time, when a Youth finds his way cleft, as that Letter is; into two parts or ways; and he ≈øtands doubting unto which he ≈øhould incline. If he be ≈øo wi≈øe as to take the right hand way, he is happy; if the other, he is mi≈øerable. Which ≈øen≈øe Grotius follows; the right hand is the way of Vertue; the left, the way of Vice. Unto which we may reduce that of the Chaldee Paraphra≈øt, The heart of the wi≈øe inclines to the Law of God, which was given from God's right hand; the Fool to Silver and Gold, which are the gifts of the left.

But if this had been the ≈øen≈øe, it would have been more proper to have ≈øaid, the Wi≈øe mans heart is on the right hand; not on his right hand; which is much different: and therefore I have omitted this in the Paraphra≈øe (though I thought good to mention it here) and taken no notice of many other Glo≈ø≈øes; particularly that of Melancthon's, which ≈øeems ≈øomething nearer to the ≈øen≈øe: The wi≈øe man hath power over his affections (the right hand being the ≈øtronge≈øt, and the in≈øtrument of action in most men) and can moderate them, as occa≈øion requires:

I will add this that the meaning may be: A Wi≈øe man hath his Wi≈ødom always at hand; to direct him what to do, in publick or in private bu≈øine≈øs; whether he have to do with Friends or Enemies; in adver≈øity, as well as in a pro≈øperous e≈øtate (his mind being ju≈øt like the right hand, which we u≈øe readily, upon all occa≈øions, for all manner of actions) but a Fool is to ≈øeek; and knows not which way to turn him≈øelf, &c. [c] V. 3.] And agrees with what follows, in this Ver≈øe, the fir≈øt Words of which ≈øignifie as much as, Moreover, a Fool is ≈øo ≈øilly, that he cannot hide it. There is another ≈øen≈øe of the la≈øt Words of the Ver≈øe, be≈øide that in our Tran≈ølation; which I have not neglected: becau≈øe the Words will bear the ≈øen≈øe of the Vulgar; viz. The LXX (as St. Hierom ob≈øerves) ≈øeem wide from the ≈øen≈øe, who tran≈ølate it thus: All that he thinks is very vain. [d] V. 4.] And then Solomon proceeds to give a particular in≈øtance of this Folly and Wi≈ødom; e≈øpecially
in the Publick State and Government. Where it is great folly for a Governour to carry him≈øelf haughtily, and furiou≈øly; but if he do, it is no le≈øs folly in his people to oppo≈øe him with the like pa≈ø≈øions; and not rather to be patient and peaceable: which is the ≈øen≈øe of v. 4. Which ≈øome take for a Coun≈øel to Governours; others to the Subject. They that under≈øtand it as Coun≈øel to Governours, tran≈ølate it ≈øome of the≈øe ways: If the ≈øpirit of a Governour come upon thee, that is, if thou art fitted for Government, and advanced unto Dignity, behave thy ≈øelf humbly; and admini≈øter all things with great lenity: for that is the be≈øt way, to heal publick Di≈øtempers. Or thus, If thou art made a Prince, di≈øcharge this Office diligently, and with vigilance: for if thou art remi≈øs and carele≈øs, it will make thee fall into great errours. Or, as ≈øome will have it, in this manner, Thou ha≈øt a de≈øire to be in authority, ≈øuppre≈øs it; or if it be offered thee, accept not of it: a private life is better; and le≈øs ≈øubject to the occa≈øions of ≈øin and danger. And ≈øome tran≈ølate it thus, If thou art in ≈øingular favour with the Governour, keep thy ≈øtation notwith≈øtanding; and be not ambitious of Preferment, &c. Which is Coun≈øel unto Subjects; and by ruach (≈øpirit) of the Ruler, mo≈øt do not under≈øtand his favour, but his anger: and then al≈øo it may be taken in a different ≈øen≈øe from that in our Tran≈ølation (making it ≈øtill an Advice to him that is in Authority) that if anger come upon him, he ≈øhould reflect, and con≈øider the ≈øtation wherein he is; le≈øt this pa≈ø≈øion make him act undecently, and tran≈øport him into great ≈øins.

But the greate≈øt part of Interpreters, taking the Ver≈øe to be Coun≈øel to a Subject, in ca≈øe he incur the di≈øplea≈øure of his Prince, I have followed that ≈øen≈øe; which is almo≈øt agreeable to the coherence. And I
have interpreted that Advice, not to leave his place, as mo≈øt do, for not quitting the Duty of a Subject: but have taken in al≈øo the mo≈øt ingenious Interpretation of the Lord Bacon. Who makes this a Political Advice to Courtiers; not to relinqui≈øh their Place and Office, nor to retire from the execution of their Charge, as many do when they ≈øee their Prince angry with them. Which ari≈øes partly out of an impatience of di≈øgrace; partly le≈øt they ≈øhould make the wound bleed afre≈øh, by coming into the pre≈øence; partly that their Prince may ≈øee how ≈øorrowful, and humble they are: which makes them think fit to withdraw them≈øelves from their employments; nay, to re≈øign perhaps the Offices and Dignities them≈øelves into the Princes hands.

p.q: But Solomon di≈øallows this way of Cure, as hurtful and prejudicial; and that upon very good grounds. For fir≈øt this cour≈øe, doth too much publi≈øh the di≈øgrace it ≈øelf: from whence both Enemies and Enviers grow more bold to hurt; and Friends more timorous to help. Secondly, By this means it comes to pa≈øs, that the wrath of the Prince, which, if it had not been made publick, would have died perhaps of it ≈øelf, becomes now more fixt: and having begun to overthrow the man, is carried on to his utter ruine. And la≈øtly, this retiring ≈øavours ≈øomething of a malignant humour; that is fallen out with the times: which heaps the mi≈øchief of indignation, upon the mi≈øchief of ≈øu≈øpicion.

The proper Precepts therefore for a Cure, are the≈øe; which he thinks are contained in the la≈øt Words, Pliant demeanour pacifies great offences. Fir≈øt, Above all things not to ≈øeem in≈øen≈øible or not ≈øo affected, as in Duty he ought to be; for the Princes di≈øplea≈øure; either through
≈øtupidity or a ≈øtubbornne≈øs, and pride of ≈øpirit. That is, Let his countenance be compo≈øed, not to a ≈øullen and contumacious, but to a grave and mode≈øt pen≈øivene≈øs; and in all manner of employments, let him ≈øhow him≈øelf le≈øs plea≈øant and cheerful than he was wont to be. Which, it may be expedient al≈øo that, ≈øome Friend or other ≈øhould repre≈øent to the Prince; and in≈øinuate ≈øea≈øonably, with what ≈øen≈øible grief he is inwardly afflicted. Secondly, Let him carefully avoid all, even the lea≈øt occa≈øions, whereby either the thing it ≈øelf, which was the fir≈øt cau≈øe of the indignation may be revived; or the Prince apprehend a new occa≈øion to be di≈øplea≈øed with him again, or, upon any account what≈øoever, to chide him before others. Thirdly, Let him with all diligence ≈øeek, on the other ≈øide, all manner of occa≈øions, wherein his ≈øervice may be acceptable to his Prince; that both he may ≈øhow a prompt and forward affection to redeem his forepa≈øt offence; and his Prince may understand, what a good Servant he is likely to lo≈øe, if he thus cast him off. There is another Great Man, of our own, who ≈øeems to take this for an Admonition, not to be fal≈øe-hearted, by flinching from our station, when mighty men frown upon us. [I] V. 11.] In the Expo≈øition of this al≈øo there is much variety; according as the Hebrew Phra≈øe Ma≈øter of the tongue, is expounded, either of a mere Babler, and loo≈øe Talker; or of a Backbiter and Slanderer. Fir≈øt, that as the faire≈øt Sun that ever ≈øhone will ≈øet, and the Night follow it; ≈øo the mo≈øt merry life will have an end, and then we mu≈øt lie down in our Graves, longer than we have lived, without the lea≈øt glimp≈øe of the≈øe joys: and ≈øecondly, that while we live, nothing which we expect hereafter can give us more contentment, than what we enjoy at pre≈øent; and will ≈ølide away al≈øo as fa≈øt, and leave us altogether un≈øatisfied, unle≈øs we have done ≈øome good with it. 9. ¬∂ Rejoyce, O young man, in thy youth, and let thy heart chear thee in the days of thy youth, and walk in the ways of thy heart, and in the ≈øight of thine eyes: but know thou, that for all the≈øe things God will bring thee into judgment.

alway carry in mind, I might give him full liberty, to be as jocund and merry as his frolick Age enclines him; to bani≈øh melancholy thoughts; and, while he hath the briske≈øt ta≈øte of them to invent all manner of plea≈øures for his entertainment; denying him≈øelf nothing that he de≈øires, and gratifying all his ≈øen≈øes: It is this, that he mu≈øt give a ≈øtrict account of all his actions unto God; who will deal well with him, if he have kept him≈øelf within his Bounds, and enjoyed only lawful plea≈øures, with thankful acknowledgments unto Him, but will puni≈øh him for all his extravagances, and forgetfulne≈øs of Him, with torments infinitely greater than all his ≈øinful delights. And this, be it known to thee, who≈øoever thou art that reade≈øt this, is a certain truth. See Annot. [i].
10. Therefore remove ≈øorrow from thy heart, and put away evil from thy fle≈øh; for childhood and youth are vanity.

10. And therefore by the thoughts of this, I advi≈øe thee al≈øo, to ≈øuppre≈øs and bani≈øh that fiercene≈øs, rage, ≈øadne≈øs, fretting and vexation, with all ≈øuch like perturbations of mind, unto which, in the heat of thy blood, thou art ≈øubject, when any thing cro≈ø≈øes thee (≈øuppo≈øe when thou art only reproved for thy faults) and let no filthy de≈øires, which then are ≈øtrong, and would plunge thee in all wickedne≈øs, ≈øtay with thee: For, if ≈øuch care as this be not taken to lay re≈øtraints upon him, there is nothing more ≈øen≈øele≈ølly fooli≈øh, ra≈øh, incon≈øtant and forward to ruine it ≈øelf, than Man in his Childi≈øh Youth: when he is in the dawning, as we call it, of his days, and comes fir≈øt acquainted with the plea≈øures of this World. div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p:
[a] Ver≈øe 1.] Charity being the Subject of his Di≈øcour≈øe in the fir≈øt ≈øix Ver≈øes of this Chapter (as was
ob≈øerved in the Argument) he begins with the proper object of it: tho≈øe who, as our Saviour ≈øpeaks (XIV. Luke 14.) are not likely to recompence us again. Thus this fir≈øt Ver≈øe (about which there are various conceits) I think may be mo≈øt naturally expounded. And it is a very ancient Expo≈øition, as appears by the Words of Gregory Thaumaturgus; which are the≈øe in Engli≈øh: It is ju≈øt to communicate unto others, &c. for, though for the pre≈øent it may ≈øeem to be lo≈øt, (and thrown away, as we ≈øpeak) like the bread that is ca≈øt upon the water; yet, in proce≈øs of time thy love to Mankind will appear not to be unprofitable and without fruit. And after the ≈øame manner Greg. Nazianzen in after-times (Orat. XIX. pag. 298.) ≈øpeaking of the liberality of his Father to the Poor; ≈øaith, He proceeded upon this Maxim: That it is much better, for the ≈øake of tho≈øe who may be worthy, to give to tho≈øe who are unworthy, than for fear of be≈øtowing our Charity upon the unworthy, let worthy people want it. To which that ≈øeems (≈øaith he) to belong, which we read in Solomon [Ca≈øt thy bread upon the water] Which is not thrown away and quite lo≈øt, in the account of him that ju≈øtly e≈øtimates things; but is ≈øent thither where all that we do is laid up; and ≈øhall in due ≈øea≈øon meet us again, though we think not of it.

And, to ≈øtrengthen this, it is ob≈øerved by ≈øome, that water, in Scripture ≈øignifie, great affliction and mi≈øery, XVIII. P≈øal. 17. LXVI. 12. And therefore the ≈øen≈øe of the Proverb is not, of ≈øowing in a fertile Ground, by the Rivers; or in a Soil well watered, from whence men naturally expect a fruitful Crop (as ≈øome expound it) but of ≈øowing (i. e. giving alms) there, from whence we expect no fruit; no more than if we threw the Seed in a rapid River;
in which it is carried away, no body knows whither, and ≈øeems utterly lo≈øt.

And ≈øo it may be applied al≈øo to ungrateful people; as I have touched in the Paraphra≈øe: and I ≈øhall not trouble the Reader with other Expo≈øitions, which may be found in mo≈øt Commentators; only naming this of Maldonate (which agrees well enough with that which I have followed) give to the poor, who≈øe mi≈øeries are ≈øo great that their faces are all wet and be≈ømeared with tears. And though there be many of them, be not ≈øparing, if thou art able to receive them; for waters ≈øignifie ≈øometime a multitude of people, in the Scripture Language. But that's the ≈øen≈øe of the next Ver≈øe; and therefore upon the face of the waters, is as much as upon tho≈øe, who will be gone pre≈øently, like the Waters of a River; and never bring any thing back to us, to reward us: if they do, is more than could be expected.

As for the Word Bread it ≈øignifies any benefit, whereby the poor may be ≈øupported: e≈øpecially all ≈øorts of Food (1 Sam. XIV. 24. where it comprehends honey, and every thing that was edible) more particularly, that Food which is made of Corn, III. Gen. 19. and from thence ≈øignifies Corn it ≈øelf, of which Bread is made, XXVIII. I≈øai. 28. And ≈øo St. Hierom here expounds it; agreeable to what I ≈øaid above, of ≈øowing ≈øeed in the Water.

[b] V. 2.] And as in the fir≈øt Ver≈øe he hath re≈øpect to the quality of the per≈øons, unto whom we are to give; ≈øo here to the number of them, and the quantity of our Alms: which is expected perhaps by a great multitude. Yet let not that damp it (≈øaith he) out of a fancy that it will undo us, to relieve them all: but, if we be able, let us help them; and though more ≈øtill come when we have extended our Charity according to our utmo≈øt ability, let us rather go beyond
it (as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith the Macedonian Chri≈øtians did, 2 Cor. VIII. 3.) than let mi≈øerable Creatures peri≈øh. Thus Greg. Nazianzen ≈øeems to under≈øtand the≈øe Words Seven, yea eight. Seven is a complete number; eight added to it denotes ≈øomethings above that which we account perfection. His Words are the≈øe, that his Father gave not only,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , out of his ≈øuperfluity: but
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , out of his nece≈ø≈øaries: according to the pre≈øcription of Solomon, Give a portion not only to ≈øeven; but if an eighth came, he was not here ≈øparing: but much more ready to give, than others are to get. In ≈øhort, he means give mo≈øt liberally
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , as Greg. Thaumaturgus here expre≈ø≈øes it, not ≈øparingly, but profu≈øely, I omit other Glo≈ø≈øes upon the Ver≈øe; and the Critici≈øm which ≈øome make upon the Word portion: which they think alludes, to what was ≈øent from Fea≈øts unto the poor, or tho≈øe that were ab≈øent; of which there is no certainty. I will only note, that here again Solomon contradicts the Vulgar Principle upon which covetous Wretches move; and directs the quite contrary. They think all is lo≈øt, that is given away in Charity: no ≈øuch matter, ≈øaith the Preacher (v. 1.) the fruit of it will be found hereafter, beyond what can be imagined. O, ≈øaith the covetous man again, I know not what will be hereafter: now I have enough, but in the latter end of my life I may want; and therefore it is be≈øt to ≈øave whil≈øt I may. No, ≈øaith the Preacher, for that very rea≈øon, give; becau≈øe thou knowe≈øt not what may be hereafter; when that may be taken away from thee, which now thou wilt not be≈øtow upon needy people, &c.

[c] V. 3.] In this Ver≈øe, he illu≈øtrates both the Duty, and the rea≈øon of it. The former by the Clouds, which are a fit Emblem of Charity: the ≈øecond, by the Trees; which can bring forth Fruit no longer
than they continue joined to their Root; from which being ≈øeparated, they bear no more, nor can be fixed to their Root, as the Clouds may be filled with Water, again. So I have interpreted the latter part of this Ver≈øe: which Grotius under≈øtands as if it meant no more than the foregoing: Do good to men without di≈øtinction; like him who, when he cuts down a Tree, regards not which way it falls. I omit other Interpretations, and ≈øhall only mention Maldonate's Glo≈øs upon this Ver≈øe, which is ingenious enough. He urges us, ≈øaith he, to do good, while, we live, by two Rea≈øons. Fir≈øt, From the profit of it, becau≈øe we ≈øhall receive more than we give; like the Clouds, which receive from the Earth but a thin Vapour; which they return to it in mo≈øt copious Showres. The ≈øecond, From the impo≈ø≈øibility of being in a capacity to do good when we are dead; for then, like a Tree, we mu≈øt continue as we are when Death ≈øeizes us‚ñ™ and never be re≈øtored to our former condition again. Corranus alone (as far as I can find) expounds the latter part thus, in his Annotations: A Tree in what place ≈øoever it is planted, there abides, and brings forth Fruit: and ≈øo ought we to help others by all manner of means: in what≈øoever place or time we live. And he takes North and South, for all Parts of the World. If any think fit to apply this, unto the unalterable condition wherein we mu≈øt remain in the other World (like a Tree cut down, which if it fall toward the North, cannot change its po≈øiture, and turn to the South) they cannot follow a fitter Glo≈øs upon the Words, than this of Luther's. If the Lord find thee in the South; that is, fruitful and rich in good works, it will be well: but if in the North; that is, barren, of good works, it will be ill with thee. How≈øoever thou art found, ≈øo
thou ≈øhalt be judged; and ≈øo thou ≈øhalt likewi≈øe receive.

[d] V. 4.] And then follows here an Admonition to take the fir≈øt opportunity of doing good; and not to deferr it becau≈øe now it may ≈øeem un≈øea≈øonable, and we fan≈øie it may do better another time. Which the Lord Bacon extends unto all other things, as well as Alms. There is no greater, or more frequent impediment of action (≈øaith be, in the Conclu≈øion of the Fir≈øt Chapter of the VIIIth. Book of Advancement of Learning) than an over-curious ob≈øervation of decency; and of that other Ceremony, attending on it, which is too ≈øcrupulous election of time and opportunity. For Solomon ≈øaith excellently, He that ob≈øerveth the Wind, &c. We mu≈øt make opportunity, oftner than find it.

And thus that great Prince Xerxes (otherwi≈øe not very prudent, ≈øpeaks very di≈øcreetly in Herodotus (L.VII.) Be not fearful of all things; nor con≈øider every thing minutely: for if in the con≈øidertion of bu≈øine≈øs, thou wilt weigh every thing alike, thou ≈øhalt never be able to do any thing. And thus Melancthon under≈øtands this place, As events are not in our power (which he takes to be the meaning of v. 3.) ≈øo he that will have certain and circum≈øcribed events (that is, ≈øuch and ≈øuch things come to pa≈øs) before he act, will never attempt any thing.

And ≈øo a great Divine of our own expounds it; If we will ≈øu≈øpend our re≈øolution, till we can bethink our ≈øelves, of ≈øomething free from all inconveniencies; in mo≈øt of our deliberations, we ≈øhall never re≈øolve upon any thing at all: God having ≈øo tempered things, that every commodity hath its incommodiou≈øne≈øs, every conveniency ≈øome inconvenience attending it; which many times, all the
wit, and indu≈øtry of man is not able to ≈øever. Bi≈øhop Sander≈øon's Sermon upon 1 Corinth. X. 23. p. 245.

Saint Hierom al≈øo elegantly accommodates the≈øe Words to negligent Pa≈øtors; who will not preach, but when the people are very de≈øirous to hear; and there is a fair Gale breathing to favour their de≈øign. And gives this Advice to us, Do not ≈øay, this is a fit time, that is unprofitable: for we are ignorant, what is the way, and what is the will of the Spirit, which di≈øpen≈øeth all things.

[e] V. 5.] In this Ver≈øe he ≈øeems to pur≈øue the ≈øame Metaphor of the Wind, which blows uncertainly; and no body knows whence, nor from what cau≈øes. And therefore from our ignorance of that, and indeed of all other things, which we are here conver≈øant withal; of our own Soul, for in≈øtance, (which our Tran≈ølators under≈øtand by the Word Ruach, Spirit) and of our own Body or of that vis formatrix, how it goes about its Work, to make this Body of ours in the Womb, which may po≈ø≈øibly be meant by Spirit, XXXIII. Job 4. CIV. P≈øal. 30.) Solomon per≈øwades us not to pre≈øume to know how God intends to order the cour≈øe of this World, in his over-ruling Providence; and therefore to do our Duty, and leave events to Him.

[f] V. 6.] Imitating the Husbandman (with which Metaphor he began this Di≈øcour≈øe, and now concludes it) who not knowing which will pro≈øper, ≈øows both early Corn and late. So Symmachus under≈øtands this Ver≈øe, to be an allu≈øion to tho≈øe that ≈øow ≈øome very forward Seed; which perhaps may hit, when that which is ≈øown at the ordinary time doth not: Or perhaps both may ≈øucceed and bring forth Fruit, to their great enriching. Others take morning and evening, only to ≈øignifie all times.

[g] V. 7.] I have continued this Ver≈øe with the foregoing; and ≈øuppo≈øed (what all Interpreters do in the third and fourth Ver≈øes) that the compari≈øon is imperfect: there being only the „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ (as Hermogenes ≈øpeaks) the Propo≈øition of the Sentence, and the „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ (that which an≈øwers unto it) left to be made by the Reader: Which I have ≈øupplied from the ≈øen≈øe of the whole foregoing Di≈øcour≈øe in this Chapter.

Others think a new Di≈øcour≈øe here begins for the Conclu≈øion of the whole Book; and that after all he had ≈øaid of happine≈øs, he advi≈øes every one to think of another life, and not expect to find it in this.

Or, as ≈øome under≈øtand him, his meaning is, Now you have ≈øeen, wherein happine≈øs doth not, and wherein it doth con≈øi≈øt; therefore do not either imagine there is none at all here in this World, or that it is greater than really it is: But take a middle cour≈øe, which I have ≈øhown you, and look upon this life as having plea≈øure in it, but not ab≈øolutely perfect; yet ≈øuch as our condition will permit; begun here, and to be completed in another World.

[h] V. 8.] The beginning of this Ver≈øe I have expounded according to the Hebrew, where the Words run thus, as St. Hierom him≈øelf tran≈ølates them, If a man live many years, let him rejoyce in all the≈øe things, &c. And the latter part of the Ver≈øe, I have ≈øuppo≈øed, contains two Motives to moderation in our pre≈øent enjoyments, and to make us think of doing ≈øome good with them, as the highe≈øt plea≈øure of all. Becau≈øe they will have an end, when we can no longer enjoy them; and becau≈øe, while we have them, they run away apace, as all that follows will do; and leave us empty and di≈ø≈øatisfied, unle≈øs we have made a good u≈øe of them: upon which we may reflect, when they are gone, with ≈øome plea≈øure.

[i] V. 9.] To tho≈øe Motives, he here adds the mo≈øt con≈øiderable thing of all: which is expounded two ways by Interpreters. Some taking the≈øe Words as a permi≈ø≈øion, under ≈øuch re≈øtraints as he mentions in the end of the Ver≈øe: others, as ironically and ≈øarca≈øtically (as the Greek Phra≈øe is ≈øpoken; by way of mockage, and bitter ≈øcoff. The two fir≈øt Phra≈øes (rejoyce, and let thy heart cheer thee) incline to the former way; being commonly u≈øed in a good ≈øen≈øe: the two la≈øt (walk in the ways of thy heart, and in the ≈øight of thy eyes) unto the other way, being commonly u≈øed in a bad. Therefore the ≈øcope of the place, and the coherence mu≈øt determine it. And as the LXX and St. Hierom go the first way; ≈øo it agrees best, in my opinion, with what went before; and therefore ≈øo I have paraphra≈øed it. And con≈øidering that they are two different Words in the beginning of the Ver≈øe, which we tran≈ølate as if they were the ≈øame (viz. young man, and youth) I have not done ami≈øs, I think but expre≈ø≈øed them more ≈øignificantly, by the≈øe Words, childi≈øh youth. And ≈øo they are distingui≈øhed in the last Ver≈øe; where that Word which here we tran≈ølate youth, we more truly tran≈ølate childhood: which goes before youth.

[k] V. 10.] Here I have followed the judgment of St. Hierom; who under anger (or grief) comprehends all the perturbations of the mind: and under evil of the fle≈øh, all the hurtful plea≈øures of the Body. And accordingly I have expounded the whole Ver≈øe, with re≈øpect to the danger Youth is in, by the fiery motions of both ≈øorts: the former of which incline men to imitate the Wild Bea≈øts; the other ≈øink them, into the condition of the dullest Brutes.

The word we here tran≈ølate youth ≈øignifies the peep of day, in our Language; the appearing of the morning: and therefore is to be understood of our entrance
upon the most plea≈øant time of our life. Which, as well as childhood, is but vanity; that is, pre≈øently vani≈øhes (as ≈øome will have it) and will be ≈øoon gone: or rather, Childhood and Youth, ≈øignifying all that is done in that Age of our life; the meaning is, it is an Age of great levity, folly and indi≈øcretion, &c.

And therefore, as Luther ob≈øerves, the great care of mankind ≈øhould be to ≈øea≈øon Youth with right Opinions and a good ≈øen≈øe of things; and then it is not to be denied all plea≈øures, of which it is very de≈øirous; much le≈øs ≈øhut up from the very ≈øight of them, for it abbhors ≈øolitude. And this is to begin at the wrong end of Education; which mu≈øt be applied fir≈øt to the mind, not to the Body: And when the Mind is well tinctured, the Body will be ea≈øily governed. That is, neither follow filthy plea≈øures; nor be carried away with furious pa≈ø≈øions, &c. The benefit of which will be un≈øpeakable; for they that live plea≈øantly and quietly in Youth, are likely to arrive at and enjoy a comfortable Old Age.
Some begin the XIIth. Chapter at this Ver≈øe, and others begin it with the foregoing: but I have followed our Tran≈ølation, and the mo≈øt Interpreters.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p:
He continues his Advice to young men, (begun in the two la≈øt Ver≈øes of the foregoing Chapter) wi≈øhing them to ≈øea≈øon their minds with ≈øuch an early ≈øen≈øe of God, and of their obligations to Him, that it might govern them in all their ways; and be a comfort to them in Old Age, which (by a long de≈øcription of it) he ≈øhows will be a melancholy time at
be≈øt. After which Di≈øcour≈øe, he concludes the Book, with a brief ≈øumm of the ≈øcope and de≈øign of it; in≈øerting ≈øomething concerning the Author, which might di≈øpo≈øe the Reader to attend the more heedfully, unto the conclu≈øion of the whole matter.

div.p: 1. REmember now thy Creatour in the days of thy youth, while the evil days come not, nor the years draw nigh, when thou ≈øhalt ≈øay, I have no plea≈øure in them:

1. THE be≈øt Coun≈øel therefore that I can give ever man is this, That he would awaken, and pre≈øerve in mind perpetually, an awful ≈øen≈øe of God; unto whom he is ≈øo deeply indebted that he received his very Being from Him; and therefore let him apply him≈øelf faithfully and affectionately to his ≈øervice, in his mo≈øt vigorous Age, as ≈øoon as ever he can con≈øider that he is not his own, but God's, who formed him in his Mothers Womb, took him thence, and brought him up to be a man: Do not deferr this weighty bu≈øine≈øs, till thou art ≈øick, or all thy faculties ≈øo broken by the infirmities of Old Age, that though it la≈øt ≈øeveral years, yet they ≈øhall prove flat and dull, irk≈øom and redious to thee: and no plea≈øure at all left in them, but only the remembrance of a well-≈øpent-life; without which, in≈øtead of thanking God, thou wilt be apt to do nothing, but complain; or groan under the weight of one evil or other that falls upon thee. See Annot. [a].
2. While the ≈øun, or the light, or the moon, or the ≈øtars be not darkned, nor the clouds return after the rain:

2. For what joy can a man have, or what mi≈øery can he be without (and therefore what folly is it not to think of God before that time) when the natural heat and vigour is quite ≈øpent, and all the powers and faculties of Soul and Body in ≈øuch a langui≈øhing condition, that he is altogether unfit for the Offices of piety; particularly for the acknowledgment of God's benefits, the very remembrance of which is ≈ølipt out of his mind, or he hath but a dull perception of them: being no more ≈øen≈øible of the benefit of the Sun it ≈øelf, when it gives the brighte≈øt light, than
he is of the Moon or the Stars; but the day is as ≈øad, and as full of pains and heavine≈øs to him, as the night: and there is no end of them, no intermi≈ø≈øion; but they ≈øucceed one another, as the Clouds do in a rainy Sea≈øon, when one is no ≈øooner emptied, but another is gathered, and ready to di≈øcharge it ≈øelf in Showers. See Annot. [b].

3. In the day when the keepers of the hou≈øe ≈øhall tremble, and the ≈øtrong men ≈øhall bow them≈øelves, and the grinders cea≈øe becau≈øe they are few, and tho≈øe that look out of the windows be darkned.

3. Is this a proper time to be alloted to the ≈øervice of God, when a man cannot ≈øerve him≈øelf? his hands being ≈øtruck with a Pal≈øie, and made unable either to feed or defend his Body; his feet bending under the weight of it, having lo≈øt their power to ≈øupport him; his teeth likewi≈øe ≈øo rotten, or worn away, or fallen out, that they cannot thew his Meat; and the ≈øight of his eyes, which were wont to ≈øhow him things at a great di≈øtance, now ≈øo failing him, that he cannot know one man from another, though they ≈øtand hard by him. See Annot. [c.]
4. And the doors ≈øhall be ≈øhut in the ≈øtreets, when the ≈øound of the grinding is low, and he ≈øhall ri≈øe up at the voice of the bird, and all the daughters of mu≈øick ≈øhall be brought low;

4. Is this the time to gain acceptance with God, when he is de≈øpi≈øed by men; and excluded the publick A≈ø≈øemblies, becau≈øe his voice is ≈øo low, that no Body can hear him? Nay, his Lips look as if they were clo≈øed, and fall ≈øo inward, that he can but mumble, by rea≈øon of the lo≈øs of his Teeth, the weakne≈øs of his Lungs, and the defect of other In≈øtruments of Speech: Nor can he recruit him≈øelf as he was wont by re≈øt; for ≈øound ≈øleep departs from his eyes, and he wakes as early as the Birds, but is not plea≈øed at all with their Songs: his hearing being ≈øo dull and flat, that he is not moved by the be≈øt Mu≈øick in the World; though he li≈øten and incline his ears unto it, with never ≈øo much diligence. See Annot. [d].

5. Al≈øo when they ≈øhall be afraid of that which is high, and fears ≈øhall be in the way, and the almond-tree ≈øhall flouri≈øh, and the gra≈øhopper ≈øhall be a burden, and de≈øire ≈øhall fail: becau≈øe man goeth to his long home, and the mourners go about the ≈øtreets:

5. For joy and all ≈øuch plea≈øant pa≈ø≈øions being fled away, melancholy fear alone remains; which makes him ≈øcarce dare to tread in the Highway, much le≈øs, (his head is ≈øo giddy) to go up a Pair of Stairs; nay, he thinks him≈øelf un≈øafe in the ≈øtronge≈øt Fortre≈øs: Such is the feeblene≈øs of Old Age, which looks venerably by its Grey Hairs, but they are an early ≈øign of approaching death; and are made contemptible by his crumpled Shoulders, Hips and Back: which as they are of them≈øelves a ≈øufficient Load, ≈øo are relieved and ≈øupported by no bodily plea≈øures; the very de≈øires of which now fail him: for there is but a very ≈øhort ≈øtep between him and his Grave; unto which if he be carried with the u≈øual Solemnities, it is all his Friends can do for him. 6. Or ever the ≈øilver cord be loo≈øed, or the golden bowl be broken, or the pitcher be broken at the fountain, or the wheel broken at the cistern.

6. Remember therefore thy Creator, while the noble Faculties of ≈øen≈øe and motion remain intire, and are ≈øtrong and lively; for the time will come (and that will be very unfit for this, or indeed any other bu≈øine≈øs) when they will be totally di≈øabled: the Nerves, for in≈øtance, will ≈øhrink up and be di≈øpirited; the Brain it ≈øelf, and all tho≈øe precious Ve≈ø≈øels wherein it is contained, be of no u≈øe at all unto thee: For the very Fountain of Life, the Heart, will fail, and the Veins and Arteries no longer carry the Blood round the Body; but the motion will cea≈øe, by the decay of that power, which now thru≈øts it forward in a contitinual Circulation. 7. Then ≈øhall the dust return to the earth as it was: and the ≈øpirit ≈øhall return unto God who gave it.

7. And then, what remains, but that the Soul and Body being
parted, they go to their ≈øeveral Originals? The Body, tho' now ≈øo fair a Fabrick, to the Earth out of which it was taken (according to that ancient Doom pa≈ø≈øed upon it, Du≈øt thou art, and unto du≈øt thou ≈øhalt return) but the Soul unto God, to be judged by him, according to what it hath done in the Body, ≈øince He ≈øent it thither. 8. ¬∂ Vanity of vanities, ≈øaith the preacher; all is vanity.

8. And if this be the Conclu≈øion of all our labours, I have rea≈øon to conclude this Book as I began it, and li≈øten I be≈øeech you again, to him, who proclaims nothing to you but what he hath proved in this Di≈øcour≈øe; that there is no ≈øolid ≈øatisfaction to be found in any thing here below; where all things are both full of care and trouble, as well as uncertain and peri≈øhing: and therefore it is the height of folly, to take great thought for this pre≈øent life; and to lay up nothing for the life to come. 9. And moreover, becau≈øe the preacher was wi≈øe, he ≈øtill taught the people knowledge; yea, he gave good heed, and ≈øought out, and ≈øet in order many proverbs.

9. Perhaps you may ≈øtill think otherwi≈øe; and therefore I have this now to add (and ≈øo ≈øhall ≈øumm up all I have ≈øaid) that I am as likely to judge aright, as another man; being indued with Wi≈ødom from above, by an extraordinary gift of God (1 Kings III. 12. IV. 30, &c.) who≈øe Goodne≈øs al≈øo I have imitated, in communicating my knowledge freely unto others: Nay, (knowing that by ≈øloth or envy the greate≈øt Wi≈ødom may be lo≈øt) the more I under≈øtood, the more diligent I was in informing others; Nor did Divine illuminations make me either neglect my own Studies, or other mens inventions, but I li≈øtned unto all from whom I might hope to learn any thing; and both weighed what they ≈øaid, and al≈øo made an exact ≈øearch into things my ≈øelf: of which, that not only the pre≈øent Age, but Po≈øterity al≈øo might reap the benefit, I have gathered together, and aptly di≈øpo≈øed and fitted to all capacities, abundance
of excellent pithy Sentences, for in≈øtruction in Wi≈ødom and Vertue (1 Kings IV. 32.) See Annot. [i].
10. The preacher ≈øought to find out acceptable words, and that which was written was upright, even words of truth.

10. Thus I, that preach the≈øe things, have employed my pains, in ≈øeeking (with no le≈øs diligence than covetous men do for money) both the mo≈øt plea≈øant, and the mo≈øt u≈øeful, and mo≈øt certain Knowledge: and having found what I ≈øought, I may ≈øafely affirm that, Nothing is ≈øaid by me, but what ought to be mo≈øt acceptable, being apt to give the greate≈øt contentment and delight: Nothing written by me, but what I found in the Divine Writings, or is ≈øo exactly agreeable thereunto, that it is a ≈øtraight and faithful Rule of life: there is nothing frivolous, or doubtful in them; but they contain the mo≈øt ≈øolid Wi≈ødom, as ≈øure and true as truth it ≈øelf. See Annot. [k].
11. The words of the wi≈øe are as goads, and as nails fa≈øtned by the ma≈øters of a≈ø≈øemblies, which are given from one ≈øhepherd.

11. And there is the ≈øame power in them (as there is wont to be in all the acute Sayings of tho≈øe that are wi≈øe and good) to excite and ≈øtir up the minds of ≈ølothful men to the practice of Vertue; that there is in a Goad to prick the dull Oxe forward, to draw the Plow: Nor do they only ≈øting and move the mind for the pre≈øent; but are apt to ≈øtick as fa≈øt in the memory, as Nails do when they are driven into a Board: and to collect al≈øo the thoughts, affections, and re≈øolutions unto one certain end; e≈øpecially when they are fa≈øtned by the skilful hand of tho≈øe who rule the A≈ø≈øemblies of God's people; and are ruled them≈øelves by one and the ≈øame ≈øupreme Governour, who≈øe Holy Spirit directs them all. 12. And further, by the≈øe, my ≈øon be admoni≈øhed: of makeing many books there is no end, and much ≈øtudy is a wearine≈øs of the fle≈øh.

12. Therefore, my Son (or who≈øoever thou art that ≈øhall read the≈øe things, who≈øe happine≈øs I wi≈øh as my own) be advi≈øed by me, and
not only believe the≈øe things, but re≈øt contented with ≈øuch u≈øeful Knowledge; and do not trouble thy ≈øelf, either in compo≈øing or reading many Books: For all that is needful to in≈øtruct men how to be happy, may be comprized in a few wi≈øe Precepts, and if thou extende≈øt thy de≈øires beyond this, thou may≈øt turn over infinite Volumes, which are encrea≈øing continually; and ≈øerve only to di≈øtract thy mind, and tire thy ≈øpirits, and impair thy health; but yield little profit, after the expence of a great deal of pains and time. 13. ¬∂ Let us hear the conclu≈øion of the whole matter, Fear God, and keep his commandments: for this is the whole duty of man.

Let us draw up all then, that can be ≈øaid in this matter, into as ≈ømall a compa≈øs as is po≈ø≈øible: If thou would≈øt be happy, pre≈øerve in thy mind ≈øuch an awful ≈øen≈øe of God, as to have a greater regard to Him, both as thy Creator and Governour, and as thy Judge, than to any thing in this World; and, dreading his di≈øplea≈øure, not only wor≈øhip Him religiou≈øly, but ob≈øerve all His Commandments: For, as unto this all men are bound, ≈øo in this con≈øi≈øts all their Duty, and their whole happine≈øs; and therefore they ought to make this their main bu≈øine≈øs, and employ their be≈øt endeavours in it. As they would with all ≈øeriou≈øne≈øs, did they but believe and remember, what is mo≈øt certainly true, That, though now the wicked and the good ≈øometimes fare alike, yet, there will be a notorious di≈øtinction one day, made between them; when God (who≈øe knowledge nothing can e≈øcape, and out of who≈øe memory nothing can ≈ølip) will pa≈øs an exact Sentence upon every thing we do here in this World, though never ≈øo ≈øecret and known to none but Him≈øelf: and then no evil thing, though only de≈øigned and never actually committed, ≈øhall go unpuni≈øhed; and no good thing, though only heartily intended for want of power to accompli≈øh it, ≈øhall be unrewarded.
