div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p: [a] Ver≈øe 1.] From the con≈øideration of what he had ≈øaid in the Conclu≈øion of the foregoing Chapter, that Youth is attended with folly, and folly attended with de≈øtruction (as Greg. Thaumaturgus excellently explains tho≈øe Words) he begins this with the mo≈øt weighty Le≈ø≈øon: which ought to be perpetually inculcated, and beaten into the mind and memory of young men, viz. That they would reflect ≈øo far as to con≈øider, who gave them their being; and what, upon that account, they owe unto Him: who as He is the ≈øole Author of all things that give us any delight; ≈øo He is of all the abilities and faculties, which make us capable to take plea≈øure in them; and the ≈øole Di≈øpo≈øer likewi≈øe of all opportunities, that bring us and tho≈øe Delights together.

All this may well be comprehended in the Word Creator (if this place be compared with XL. I≈øai. 28. XLV. 7.18. LXV. 17, 18.) Which being in the Hebrew a Word of the Plural Number, ≈øome from thence draw the My≈øtery of the Holy Trinity: which I cannot certainly, ≈øay is here intended, becau≈øe it is very ordinary in the Scripture to put the Plural for the Singular; e≈øpecially when God is ≈øpoken of. Thus when the I≈øraelites had made the golden Calf, they ≈øaid, The≈øe are thy Gods, O I≈ørael, &c. (≈øo we tran≈ølate it, XXXII. Exod. 4.) as if there had been more Gods than one in that Calf. But it ≈øhould be tran≈ølated, This is thy God, O I≈ørael; as appears by what follows, which brought thee out of the land of Egypt: ≈øignifying they wor≈øhipped in this Image Him, who had wrought that great deliverance for them. And thus Jonathan there under≈øtands it; and Theodoret upon 1 Book of Kings, Que≈øt. 10,

More places, like to this, are ob≈øerved by Bochartus (L. II. de Animal. Sacr. C. 34. P. 1.) in whom the Learned Reader may find many ≈øuch Latine Words, that are only of the Plural, not Singular Number. And I will only mention one remarkable place, (which he might have added) 1 Sam. XXVIII. 9. where the Woman ≈øays, ≈øhe ≈øaw Gods a≈øcending out of the Earth: and Saul thereupon asks her, What form is he of? under≈øtanding ≈øhe ≈øaw a ≈øingle per≈øon.

But what ever becomes of this, we Chri≈øtians (to whom this My≈øtery is now plainly revealed) ought when we read ≈øuch places as the≈øe, to think of the obligations we have unto God the Father, God the Son, and God the Holy Gho≈øt, into who≈øe Name we are baptized. And not only to con≈øider ≈øuch things as are above-mentioned; but to be moved and affected with them (for that is here included in the Word Remember) according unto their weight and importance.

And to do this betime, the fir≈øt thing we do; becau≈øe the days of our youth, are our be≈øt and choice≈øt days (as the Word in the Hebrew ≈øignifies; whence in 2 Sam. VI. 1. where David is ≈øaid to gather all the cho≈øen men, the LXX hath „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the young men in I≈ørael) in which we are apt to take the greate≈øt delight in our ≈øelves, or in any thing truly delightful: our ≈øpirits being then most fre≈øh, lively and vigorous. So that the mea≈øure of our delight, whether in our ≈øelves or in any thing without us, being then truly taken, it would constrain us unto an equal delight in Him who is the Author of both and unto a corre≈øpondent gratulation for them. Whereas, if we deferr this remembrance till Old Age come upon us, when life grows a burden, and the wonted delights of it are either irk≈øome or in≈øipid (unplea≈øant, or without all taste or reli≈øh) our thankfulne≈øs
for them will be but faint; our gratulation worthle≈øs; our Devotion cold and lumpi≈øh: as Dr. Jack≈øon excellently glo≈ø≈øes upon the≈øe Words, B. XI. upon the Creed, C. 33. Which, he had expre≈ø≈øed long before, more briefly in his Treati≈øe of Faith, Chap. 8. p. 125; thus, The Inventory of what we have received from God in our Creation, ≈øhould be taken in tho≈øe days wherein we mo≈øt delight; becau≈øe then the Characters of his Ble≈ø≈øings be≈øtowed upon us, and their true worth, are mo≈øt fre≈øh and ≈øen≈øible in all our faculties: well knowing, that if we deferr this Survey till Old Age, in which life it ≈øelf becomes a burden, our return of thanks for fruition of it, and the unplea≈øant appertinencies, will be but wearyi≈øh. And plainer still in his II. Book upon God's Attributes, Ch. XI. p. 95. Then the Prints of God's Creative Power, are mo≈øt fre≈øh in our Nature; and might tran≈ømit a fairer Copy, and truer e≈øtimate of the Creator's Goodne≈øs unto Old Age, than Old Age can take any, &c. Which I have repeated the oftner, in ≈øeveral forms of ≈øpeech, in hope that one or other of them may touch the heart of young men, and excite them by frequent reflection upon the pre≈øent comforts of health and strength, upon the activity of their Body, the quickne≈øs of their ≈øen≈øe and ≈øpirit, to ingro≈øs them deeply in their memory; before the evil days come.

So Solomon calls our decrepit Old Age; both becau≈øe they are void of all plea≈øure, as he ≈øaith in the following Words; and becau≈øe they are attended likewi≈øe with ≈øo many inconveniences and mi≈øeries, that it is hard to number them. But he gives us ≈øome account of them, in his admirable De≈øcription of decrepit Age, v. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6: which abundantly confirms that ≈øpeech of Cicero in his Book de Senecture,
that Old Age proves ≈øo odious unto mo≈øt men, ut Onus ≈øe Aetna gravius dicant ≈øu≈øtinere, that they complain of a load that lies heavier than Mount Aetna upon them.

[b] V. 2.] The≈øe infirmities he demon≈øtrates to be very great, becau≈øe decrepit Age con≈øi≈øts in the univer≈øal decay of the whole frame of Nature: Which I take to be the meaning of the Sun, the light, the Moon and Stars, being darkned. For as in a Body Politick, the extinction or falling down of the≈øe ≈øignifies, in the Prophetical Language, the ≈øubver≈øion of that frame of Government (as, to omit abundance of other places, may be ≈øeen in what I≈øaiah ≈øaith concerning Egypt, XXXII. 7, 8.) ≈øo the darkning of the≈øe in the Natural Body of man, ≈øignifies, in my judgment, its total decay and nearne≈øs to a di≈ø≈øolution: the tumbling (as we ≈øpeak) of an Old Man into his Grave; like a ruinous old hou≈øe which can ≈øtand no longer; for ≈øo the Metaphor is carried on, v. 3. And then the return of Clouds after the Rain, refers to the di≈ømal condition a man is in at that time: when one trouble treads upon the heels of another: which is no ≈øooner gone, but the like, or a new one, comes in its room. And ≈øo the Words may be tran≈ølated, The Clouds return, and after that the Rain: that is, there is a ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of mi≈øery, of grief, pain, or weakne≈øs, drawing on one another. There are ≈øome who apply the darkning of Sun, Moon and Stars, to the mind of man (as one would think, indeed, he ≈øhould ≈øay ≈øomething of that; and all the following de≈øcription belonging wholly to the Body, we mu≈øt find it here or not at all) but ≈øtill I conceive that he intends only in general, to ≈øignifie the failing of the mind in all its faculties and powers; without a re≈øpect to ≈øome particular di≈øtinct faculty in each of the≈øe Words. But they who think the inward
powers are here intended, are not content to re≈øt in ≈øuch a general meaning; but will have ≈øomething in particular ≈øignified, by every one of them. And then they do but gue≈øs, which gives me the liberty to interpo≈øe my conjectures al≈øo: that by the Sun may be meant the Soul it ≈øelf; by the Light, its Under≈øtanding; by the Moon, the Will; by the Stars, all the Nations in the Mind and Memory, with all the affections and pa≈ø≈øions in the Will: ju≈øt as Sun, Moon, and Stars, in Jo≈øeph's Dream, ≈øignified his Father, and Mother, and Brethren. And ≈øo the ≈øen≈øe of this Ver≈øe is, the Mind of man grows feeble in all its powers; the Under≈øtanding dim≈øighted, the Memory forgetful; the Rea≈øon weak and childi≈øh (giving ≈øuch a feeble light, that it can neither direct our ≈øelves nor others) the Will li≈øtle≈øs in all its de≈øires, dull about our greate≈øt concerns, wavering and incon≈øtant in all its re≈øolutions, &c.

But I judge it more rea≈øonable, as I ≈øaid, to re≈øt in the Interpretation fir≈øt mentioned (which I am ≈øure is agreeable to the holy Language in other places) that hereby is only repre≈øented in general, the univer≈øal decay of the faculties of the upper part of man, his Soul. Which ≈øen≈øe I have comprehended together with the other in my Paraphra≈øe: and not neglected this, in which others acquie≈øce, that the≈øe Words ≈øignifie the mi≈øeries an Old man feels, both night and day. As for tho≈øe who hereby under≈øtand the dimne≈øs of the eyes, it being expre≈ø≈øed afterward, v. 3. I have taken no notice of their ≈øen≈øe: But another there is, which is worth mentioning. For the meaning may be, There is nothing but darkne≈øs: i. e. a mo≈øt uncomfortable condition; like that, when the Heavens are clouded day and night (as they were in St. Paul's Voyage, XXVII. Acts 20.) and when one Cloud hath ≈øpent it ≈øelf in the Tempe≈øt, another immediately ≈øucceeds it.

[c] V. 3.] As in the foregoing Ver≈øe he gave a general de≈øcription of the decay of the whole Body (and of the internal faculties of the mind together therewith) ≈øo here he enters into the Particulars. And conceiving the Body to be like an Hou≈øe or Tabernacle (unto which it is frequently compared, not only in the Scripture, but all other Authors) he re≈øembles the Shoulders, Arms and Hands, to the Keepers of the Hou≈øe: becau≈øe by them we defend our ≈øelves from dangers; admini≈øter both Food and Phy≈øick; exerci≈øe all manner of Arts and Manufactures (as we call them) as long as they have any ≈øtrength remaining in them. Which Old Age takes away, the Nerves, Tendons and Ligaments ≈øo flagging, that the≈øe Keepers quiver and ≈øhake (tremble we render it) and grow ≈øo u≈øele≈øs that we can no way help our ≈øelves or others with them.

And then he compares the Thighs, Legs and Feet, to ≈øtrong men: they being the Supporters and Pillars, as it were, of the whole Fabrick, which hold it up; till Old Age quite di≈øables them for this Office, and makes the Knees bend, under the burden of the Body alone.

The Rea≈øon of which follows; in that the Grinders fail, &c. in which Metaphor he compares the Teeth in the Jaws above and below, to the upper and nether Mill-≈øtone. For they by cutting, breaking and chewing of the Meat, prepare it to be di≈ø≈øolved in the Stomach, and turned into nouri≈øhment (as the Corn is ground between tho≈øe Stones into Meal, and ≈øo prepared for making Bread, and other ≈øuch like u≈øes) but in time drop out of their: Sockets; or are broken, ≈øo that they can grind no longer.

And the like decay we find in the ≈øight of the eyes; which he means by tho≈øe that look out of the Windows. All tho≈øe Coats, Humours, and Nerves, that make up the eyes: which are ≈øet in
two holes (as the Word is) or hollow places in the Forehead (like the Windows in the hou≈øe) and have a round hole al≈øo in the mid≈øt of them, called the Pupil of the Eye (like a Ca≈øement) through which all things are tran≈ømitted to the inward ≈øen≈øe of Seeing. Until the Skins, and the humours al≈øo, grow too thick; and the very Figure of the Eye, as ≈øome have ob≈øerved, be changed, by the dryne≈øs of the Chry≈øtalline humour: and then the hou≈øe is darkned. Ari≈øtotle in his Problems (Sect. 31. Quae≈øt. 14.) expre≈ø≈øes it thus, in ≈øhort, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , &c. when men grow into years, their ≈øight grows dull, becau≈øe in the eyes of Old men, the Skin is both hard, and al≈øo rugged; ≈øo that their ≈øight is ob≈øcured.

[d] V. 4.] this Ver≈øe hath greater difficulty in it, e≈øpecially in the beginning, and the doors ≈øhall be ≈øhut in the ≈øtreets, when the ≈øound of the grinding is low. But the LXX ≈øugge≈øt an unexceptionable ≈øen≈øe of this Pa≈ø≈øage, in my Opinion, which is; that they are ≈øhut out of all publick meetings, becau≈øe of the lowne≈øs of their voice, which formerly was as loud as a Mill. And there is little rea≈øon to doubt, but by doors are meant the lips (it being a frequent expre≈ø≈øion in Scripture) and by the lowne≈øs of the ≈øound of grinding, the lowne≈øs of the voice, from the lo≈øs of teeth, or the weakne≈øs of re≈øpiration; in ≈øhort, from the defect there is in the Organs of Speech.

Nor do I ≈øee why Maldonate's Tran≈ølation may not be allowed, which is ≈øtill more ≈øimple (and therefore I have taken notice of it, in my Paraphra≈øe) the lips are ≈øhut without (≈øo „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ may be tran≈ølated, foris, extrin≈øecus) that is, they ≈øink and are compre≈ø≈øed; when the voice grows weak and tremulous, becau≈øe of tho≈øe that grind; that is, by the falling of the teeth. Thus he. But it may
more exactly be tran≈ølated thus, by the falling low of the voice, of which the teeth are the principal in≈øtruments. And the whole, I have ≈øometimes thought, may not incongruou≈øly be tran≈ølated in this manner: His lips are ≈øhut in his mouth (for the mouth is the ≈øtreet or high-way into this hou≈øe of which Solomon is ≈øpeaking) by the falling down of the voice of grinding; i. e. the voice that is made by grinding the Air, as it were between the teeth, and the roof of the mouth, &c.

It might be referred to the eating meat, ≈øeldom, becau≈øe of his bad dige≈øtion (the Meat being ground in the Stomach, as in a Mill) if the word voice or ≈øound would agree to this. Which renders Dr. Smith's Interpretation, very difficult, in my judgment. Who by doors under≈øtands all the inlets and outlets of the Body; and by ≈øtreets, the open ways and Pa≈ø≈øages in the Body; in which the matter of nouri≈øhment is conveyed, and pa≈ø≈øeth, without lett or mole≈øtation: and by ≈øhutting the≈øe doors, the cea≈øing from their u≈øe: and by grinding, the dige≈øtions and concoctions in the Stomach, Bowels, Me≈øentery, Glandules, &c. (all which is well enough, though perhaps too Philo≈øophical:) and by the voice of the≈øe concoctions, the natural ≈øymptoms, ≈øignificative of dige≈øtions; all tho≈øe indications, which demon≈øtrate the work of Nature to proceed aright. Which ≈øeems to me very far fetcht, and too great a ≈øtraining of the Word voice or ≈øound: however, I have here mentioned it, that they who are plea≈øed with it, may follow that Interpretation, which is very ingenious.

The next Pa≈ø≈øage in this Ver≈øe is ea≈øier; though it is uncertain, whether he mean that the chirping of the lea≈øt Bird wakes him; or that he wakes early, when the Birds do. For tzippor ≈øignifies all kind of Birds, great and ≈ømall; and may be interpreted
of the Cock as well as any other: and the meaning be, He gets up at the Cock-crowing. This la≈øt ≈øeems mo≈øt probable, becau≈øe being thick of hearing (as the next Pa≈ø≈øage ≈øignifies) it cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed, that the lea≈øt noi≈øe di≈øturbs him. Some fan≈øie that Solomon wrote a Book called Catub Ja≈øcher (the Writing of Uprightne≈øs) or Ja≈øcher dibre emeth (the upright Words of Truth) of which, as there is no certainty, ≈øo I ≈øee no probable grounds to a≈ø≈øert it. Only we know he wrote a great many more Books than we have, 1 King. IV. 32, 33. 2 Chron. XXXV. 4. And ≈øee Jo≈øephus L. VIII. Antiq. C. 2.

[l] V. 11.] Some connect this with the foregoing Ver≈øe in this manner, The Preacher ≈øought to find out the words of the Wi≈øe, &c. And ≈øo the Words run exactly in the Hebrew. But we may take this Ver≈øe by it ≈øelf, ≈øupplying the Word are, as we do in our Tran≈ølation; and look upon it as a commendation of the≈øe wi≈øe Words: which doth not in the lea≈øt alter the ≈øen≈øe. I have had re≈øpect to both; and comprehended al≈øo, in my Paraphra≈øe, two of the Interpretations, which one difficult Phra≈øe is capable of, viz. Ma≈øters of the A≈ø≈øemblies.

Which may be tran≈ølated divers ways, more literally out of the Hebrew than we do; who add the Word by before them, which is not in the Original. For the la≈øt Words, which we tran≈ølate Ma≈øters of A≈ø≈øemblies, may be attributed to Nails, in this manner: As Nails fa≈øtened, whereby things are joined together, (Nails being the In≈øtruments of gathering or bringing tho≈øe things together, which were ≈øeparate) or thus, retaining the Words of our Tran≈ølation, the Ma≈øters of A≈ø≈øemblies are as fixed Nails: or the Ma≈øters of Collections, ≈øuch judicious
Authors as make excellent Collections of Apophthegms and ≈ømart Sayings, Stick in the Mind as Nails do in Planks. Or the Principal, the choice Collections (viz. of Wi≈øe men, mentioned in the beginning of the Ver≈øe) are as, &c. or it may, in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe, be connected (not with Nails, but) with the Words following: the Ma≈øters or Authors that collect wi≈øe and pithy Sayings, have their Gifts from one and the ≈øame Shepherd.

So ungrounded is the fancy of Grotius; who from hence conjectures, that there were ≈øeveral per≈øons appointed by Zerobbabel (whom he takes for this one Pa≈øtor) to collect the Sentences of this Book, and put them out under the name of Solomon. Who him≈øelf may rather be thought to be this one Pa≈øtor or King: who employed (if we interpret the Words this way) many per≈øons to make Collections: of which he afterwards made u≈øe as he ≈øaw cau≈øe.

This ≈øeems to be certain, that he here gives the rea≈øon of this conci≈øe and ≈øententious way of Writing: becau≈øe ≈øuch acute Sayings, not only ≈øtir up and quicken ≈ølothful minds for the pre≈øent (as a Goad ≈øtimulates the dull Oxe to labour) but penetrate deep and ≈øtick fa≈øt in the memory; collecting al≈øo the thoughts, affections and re≈øolutions, to one certain Point or Scope; and gathering together a great deal of ≈øen≈øe into a few Words. As tho≈øe Words baale a ≈øyppoth, Ma≈øters of A≈ø≈øemblies, or Authors of Collections may, I have ≈øometimes thought, be under≈øtood. Such a Collector was that Great Man Julius Cae≈øar; who gathered a Book of Apoththegms; and ≈øhowed by that, he thought it more honourable unto him, if he changed him≈øelf, as it were, into Tables and Codicils, in which the prudent and grave Sayings of others were regi≈øtred; than to have his own Words hallowed like Oracles, as ≈øome vain Princes, corrupted
by flattery, have affected. Though divers of his own Speeches, as the Lord Bacon ob≈øerves (L. I. de Augm. Scient. C. 7.) are truly ≈øuch as tho≈øe which Solomon here de≈øcribes, full of vigour and efficacy: in≈øomuch, that by one word alone he appea≈øed a mutiny in his Army.

But, after all that may be ≈øaid on this Subject, ≈øince I find not only the Vulgar, but the LXX making out the ≈øen≈øe by adding the Word per and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ (as we do the Word by in our Tran≈ølation) before Ma≈øters of A≈ø≈øemblies; I have in the Paraphra≈øe followed that Interpretation al≈øo.

[m] V. 12.] And in this Ver≈øe have adhered to the ≈øame Tran≈ølation, which under≈øtands the fir≈øt Words, as if he had ≈øaid: Beyond the≈øe things do not trouble thy ≈øelf. For ≈øo they may be tran≈ølated exactly, and what is above, or more than them (that is, the the words of the wi≈øe, beforementioned) my Son, be warned, or be enlightned: ob≈øerve the≈øe well, and trouble thy ≈øelf no further. Be content with a few good Precepts of the Wi≈øe; and do not involve thy ≈øelf in many Books. For what is nece≈ø≈øary may be learnt without much labour, out of a ≈øhort Book: if men will be wi≈øer than they need they will but trouble them≈øelves to no purpo≈øe. There being no certainty of mo≈øt things; no ≈øatisfaction when we go beyond the known and acknowledged Principle, and Precepts of Vertue: but what one man a≈ø≈øerts, another confutes; and when we think we have written excellently, another Writer ≈øtarts up and di≈øcovers abundance of errours; and ≈øo Volumes are multiplied without end: and we are led into long di≈øqui≈øitions, without any ≈øatisfaction to the mind, but with much wearine≈øs to the Body, and great lo≈øs of precious time; which had better be ≈øpent in dige≈øting and practi≈øing, ≈øuch ≈øhort, u≈øeful, and nece≈ø≈øary In≈øtructions as the≈øe.

He doth not ab≈øolutely condemn many Books, for there are not a few of the Divine Writings; and about the ≈øame thing: but Books about needle≈øs things; and that dilate too much upon things nece≈ø≈øary; rather tiring, than in≈øtructing. And he condemns the levity of tho≈øe that are always reading, but never meditating: running over ≈øuch a Book as this pre≈øently, and then going to another, not ≈øo profitable; and never returning to this again.

So I take it in ≈øhort, Content thy ≈øelf with this Book, and ≈øuch like; and do not turn over many Authors, to learn how to be happy. For goodne≈øs and truth are included in certain Bounds; but wickedne≈øs and lyes, ≈øine fine ≈øunt, are without end, as St. Hierome here notes. Who ob≈øerves al≈øo, that perhaps he advi≈øeth us, to ≈øtudy brevity; and to mind the ≈øen≈øe more than the words: directly contrary to the Philo≈øophers and Doctors of the World, who to a≈ø≈øert their fal≈øe Opinions, u≈øe abundance and great variety of Words; but the Divine Scripture, brevi Circulo coarctata e≈øt, is confined to a ≈ømall Circle; and as much contracted in Words, as it is dilated in ≈øen≈øe.
The Hebrew Word bahag, which we tran≈ølate ≈øtudy, Aben Ezra ≈øays, in the neighbouring Languages, ≈øignifies reading; and ≈øo we tran≈ølate it in the Margin.

[n] V. 13.] To teach us to contract our labours into as ≈ømall a compa≈øs as we can, he ≈øumms up, in a few Words, the ≈øen≈øe of his whole Di≈øcour≈øe in this Book; which he calls the conclu≈øion or end of the matter; of all that can be ≈øaid on this Subject: the whole ≈øen≈øe of the Sermon, ≈øuccinctly delivered; unto which therefore every one ≈øhould confine his endeavours. It is this, to work his Soul unto ≈øuch a due regard of the Divine Maje≈øty (≈øtanding in awe of him as his Lord, Over≈øeer and Judge) that he
take care to ob≈øerve all his Commandments: without which all Religion is vain and fruitle≈øs.

And the≈øe two things (the fear of God (or devotion) and obedience) he commends from two Arguments. The fir≈øt of which is in this Ver≈øe; that they are things, which concern all Mankind, one as well as another; of which if they be careful, they have done enough to make them≈øelves immortally happy.

For tho≈øe Words, this is the whole, or the all of man, may be expounded four ≈øeveral ways: either this is all the duty of man, or the duty of all men; or the whole happine≈øs of all men; or their whole bu≈øine≈øs; unto which therefore they ≈øhould devote their whole ≈øelves; that is, all their ≈øtrength. For according as St. Hierom under≈øtands it, to this Man was born: that he under≈øtanding God is his Creator, ≈øhould wor≈øhip him with fear, and honour and ob≈øervance of his Commands.

And the fear of God being implanted in our minds, we ≈øhall not fail to wor≈øhip Him, and call upon Him, and expect all good things from Him, and give Him thanks for them: And, as the be≈øt expre≈ø≈øion of our thankfulne≈øs, keep his Commandments, and be obedient to all his Precepts: both in ≈øubduing our ≈øinful Appetites and Pa≈ø≈øions, and in exerci≈øing Charity towards our Neighbours. Which will make us true in word and deed; faithful in all our Contracts; liberal to the Poor; ob≈øervant of our Governours; in ≈øhort, make us ob≈øerve all the directions of this Book, in order to our happine≈øs.

[o] V. 14.] Here is the ≈øecond Argument, why we ≈øhould ≈øeriou≈øly intend the≈øe things; becau≈øe the Lord and Judge of the World, will one day call us to an account for what we do here; and pa≈øs an impartial Sentence upon every action of our life, even
again≈øt every Secret (as ≈øome expound the≈øe Words al col alam) or upon all ≈øecret as well as open actions. Which are all known to Him, though now He ≈øeem to take no notice of them; and ≈øhall then not only be brought to light, but with an apparent di≈øtinction between good and evil: the difference of which, ≈øhall be certainly and notoriou≈øly manife≈øted; by the ≈øevere puni≈øhment of the one, and the bountiful remuneration of the other.

I will imitate therefore (≈øaith Melancthon) the example of Solomon; and in the Conclu≈øion recite the ≈øumm of this Book. He intended to a≈ø≈øert Divine Providence; and to refute the Objections again≈øt it. which are the≈øe; There are great confu≈øions in humane life; a va≈øt multitude of ungodly men, and but few that acknowledge, and fear God: and, which is wor≈øe, the wicked flouri≈øh in honour and riches; but the pious are afflicted, and ofttimes killed by the wor≈øt of men, &c. therefore all things ≈øeem to be carried by Chance. Unto which Solomon an≈øwers: Tho' for the mo≈øt part, ≈øuch be the confu≈øion of things, yet be thou ruled by God's Word; and hold the Opinion of his Providence with a firm Faith. Do not fall from God, becau≈øe of the≈øe Scandals; nor ca≈øt away his fear, or thy confidence in Him; nor de≈øert thy vocation: but oppo≈øe the≈øe two things to the≈øe confu≈øions; There will come a Judgment, when God will take away the≈øe confu≈øions and make an exact di≈øtinction: for the wicked ≈øhall be thrown into everla≈øting puni≈øhment; but it ≈øhall be well for ever with the righteous. And in this life al≈øo, God moderates the≈øe confu≈øions: for he puni≈øhes heinous wickedne≈øs; ≈øupports Government, pre≈øerves Governours, and Order, and Polities in the World. Nay, this is a te≈øtimony of God's pre≈øence, that when the infirmity of humane Nature is ≈øo great, and ≈øo many are no
better than mad and furious; yet God pre≈øerves his Church: and, I may add, we have ≈øuch good Books as the≈øe for our direction into Truth, and encouragement in Piety.
THE SONG OF SOLOMON PARAPHRASED. WITH ANNOTATIONS.
By the ≈øame AUTHOR.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: THat this Book was compo≈øed by SOLOMON is no more doubted, than that he was the Author of the two foregoing.

And that it was always lookt upon as an Holy Book, treating of ≈øome Spiritual and Divine matter, appears from its being placed among the re≈øt of that kind. Nor hath it been doubted of by any con≈øiderable number of men, either among Jews or Chri≈øtians, but only by a few ≈øingular per≈øons; who ought (as Theodoret ≈øpeaks in his Preface to this Book) to have lookt upon tho≈øe ble≈ø≈øed Fathers, who placing this Song among the Divine Writings, took it to be fit for the u≈øes of the Church, as men of greater judgment, and more ≈øpiritual than them≈øelves. And they ought likewi≈øe to have con≈øidered (as he adds) that we have, in effect, the te≈øtimony of the Holy Gho≈øt it ≈øelf, for its. Divine Authority: Ezra, a man excelling in Vertue and full of the Holy Spirit, having thought this worthy of a room among tho≈øe Sacred Volumes, which he gathered together, after their return from the Captivity of Babylon.

And accordingly, a great many holy men have illu≈øtrated it (as he further notes) with their
Commentaries and Interpretations, or have adorned their Writings with its Sentences: ≈øuch as Eu≈øebius, Origen, Cyprian, (who wore the Crown of Martyrdom) „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and others that were more ancient than the≈øe, and nearer to the times of the Apo≈øtles.

It is unnece≈ø≈øary to mention tho≈øe that followed after in future times, who all took this for a ≈øpiritual Book: let us only con≈øider, whether the≈øe things being ≈øo, it be rea≈øonable for us, to de≈øpi≈øe ≈øo many and ≈øuch great per≈øons, nay the Holy Spirit it ≈øelf, and to follow our own private Opinions; nor hearkning to him that ≈øaid, The thoughts of mortal man are vain, and our devices are but uncertain, IX. Wi≈ød. 14. or rather of St. Paul, I. Rom. 21. They became vain in their imagination, and their fooli≈øh heart was darkened.

II. Nor doth it ≈øeem hard, either to find out what that ≈øpiritual matter is, of which the Wi≈øe man here treats (e≈øpecially, ≈øince all Chri≈øtian Writers have from the beginning applied this Song to Chri≈øt and his Church) or to give an account of the ri≈øe and Original of ≈øuch ≈øublime contemplations: which I take to be this.

The great Prophet David having plainly foretold that a far more glorious King than his Son Solomon, ≈øhould one day ari≈øe (as we read in the Song he made at his Marriage, P≈øal. XLV.)
and likewi≈øe more expre≈øly prophe≈øied of his Divinity, Royal Maje≈øty, Prie≈øthood, &c. (P≈øal. CX.) and again re≈øumed this Argument, ju≈øt before his death, when he cau≈øed his Son Solomon to be crowned and to ≈øit upon his Throne (P≈øal. LXXII.) it ≈øtirred up the longing de≈øires of Solomon after the coming of this mo≈øt illu≈øtrious Prince; and made him ≈øtudy to have, at lea≈øt, as clear a ≈øight of Him, as was po≈ø≈øible to be attained, afar off. And that he might ≈øtir up the ≈øame de≈øire in the whole Nation, after his appearing; he ca≈øt his Meditations on this Subject into a Song, in the form of a Pa≈øtoral Eclogue: In which ≈øeveral per≈øons being introduced who ≈øpeak their Parts, it may be called a Dramatick Poem. And ≈øo it is ≈øtiled by S. Greg. Nazianzen, in his XXXI. Oration; where he quotes a pa≈ø≈øage, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ (as his Words are P. 503. Edit. Pari≈ø.) out of this Bridal Interlude and Song. For a Drama, as the Greeks teach us, con≈øi≈øts in the change of per≈øons: ≈øome of which enter; others come to them; others withdraw; till the whole Work be completed, by this ≈øhifting and alteration of the Per≈øons.

Now the Per≈øons which compo≈øe this Song, are the Bridegroom, the Bride, the Virgins attending on her, and the Youths attending on him: to whom ≈øome add the Si≈øter of the Spou≈øe mentioned Chap. VIII; and the Watchmen and Daughters of Jeru≈øalem, who are introduced in their turns. For example, fir≈øt, the Bride,
and her Companions, comes in and ≈øaith, Let him ki≈øs me with the ki≈ø≈øes of his mouth, &c. Then the Bridegroom appears, and ≈øaith, v. 8. If thou knowe≈øt not, O thou faire≈øt, &c. After which he ≈øeems to withdraw him≈øelf, leaving the Bride and her Companions alone upon the Stage (while he ≈øits at his repa≈øt, v. 12.) who thus ≈øpeak to her, We will make the Borders of Gold, &c. And then ≈øhe ≈øpeaks again, v. 13. and he returns and ≈øpeaks, v. 15.

How many Parts there are in this Drama, is not agreed. Some make ten; others make but ≈øeven Colloquies, or interlocutory pa≈ø≈øages, in this ≈øacred Dialogue, as they call it. About which I do not think fit to di≈øpute; but ≈øhall take notice of as many as I can ob≈øerve, in the Argument or Annotations upon each Chapter.

As for the Phra≈øe, it is wholly Allegorical, in expre≈ø≈øions borrowed chiefly from the Fields and Woods and Gardens: as I ≈øhall ≈øhow in their proper places, when we meet with them. And ≈øuch were the fitte≈øt that could be found, ≈øuppo≈øing he would u≈øe Poetical Words; to ≈øet forth the ardent de≈øire he had, and would excite in others (as I ≈øaid before) to have a ≈øight of that great Shepherd of the Sheep, who would make all the World happy.

III. And none need wonder that he ≈øpeaks wholly of this glorious King; for ≈øo doth his Father David in the CXth. P≈øalm, which can be applied to
no other per≈øon what≈øoever: and ≈øo doth the Prophet I≈øaiah in after-times, in his LIII. Chapter. Which though ≈øome have endeavoured to accommodate fir≈øt to another per≈øon, yet they have failed in their attempt; and never could find any in whom it was ≈øo literally fulfilled as in our Ble≈ø≈øed Saviour. Who alone was there intended; as He ≈øeems to me to be here al≈øo, in this pre≈øent Song of Solomon's.

Where it need not ≈øeem ≈øtrange neither to any one, that he is compared to a Bridegroom, and the Church to a Bride, who doth but reflect upon the XLV P≈øalm; and ob≈øerve how Solomon doth only follow the Metaphor, wherein his Father David had repre≈øented this My≈øtery: and ob≈øerve withal, that it is the common Language of the Prophets, who compare Jeru≈øalem and Zion (under which names is comprehended the whole Church of the Jews) to a Virgin, called frequently the Virgin-Daughter of Sion, &c. whom God had e≈øpou≈øed unto him≈øelf.

IV. But, for the fuller Explication of this, it may be fit to note, that the profounde≈øt of the Hebrew Divines, whom they now call Cabbali≈øts, having ≈øuch a Notion as this among them, that ≈øen≈øible things are but an imitation of things above, conceived from thence, that there was (for in≈øtance) an Original pattern of that love and union, which is between a Man and his Wife here in this World This they expre≈ø≈øed by the kindne≈øs
of Tipheret to Malcuth: which are the Names they give unto the invi≈øible Bridegroom and Bride in the upper World. And this Tipheret (i.e. Beauty or Ornament) they call al≈øo by the Name of the Adam on high, and the Great Adam, in oppo≈øition to the terre≈øtrial or little Adam here below. As Malcuth (i. e. Kingdom) they call al≈øo by the name of Chene≈øeth I≈ørael, i. e. Congregation of I≈ørael; who is united, they ≈øay, to that Cele≈øtial Adam as Eve was to the terre≈øtrial. Which heavenly Adam or Tipheret they call likewi≈øe the Sun, and Malcuth the Moon: and make the former an active Principle, the latter a pa≈ø≈øive; or, as their Phra≈øe is, Tipheret is but the Ma≈øculine power which influences Malcuth; who is but the recipient of tho≈øe influences. So that, in ≈øumm, they ≈øeem to ≈øay the ≈øame that the Apo≈øtle Saint Paul doth, when he tells us, that Marriage is a great My≈øtery; but he ≈øpeaks concerning Chri≈øt and his Church, V. Ephe≈ø. 32. For the Marriage of Tipheret and Malcuth (or Chene≈øeth I≈ørael) is the Marriage of Chri≈øt, the Lord, from Heaven, with his Spou≈øe the Church, which is the whole Congregation of Chri≈øtian people. Which was repre≈øented in the conjunction of Adam and Eve, and of all other men and women de≈øcended from them, when they are joined together in holy Matrimony; in≈øomuch that tho≈øe Divines, called Cabbali≈øts, have formed this Maxim about this matter; that where≈øoever in the Scripture we read of the love of Man and Wife, there is my≈øtically
de≈øigned the conjunction of Tipheret and Chene≈øeth I≈ørael.

Now if this Notion (of which the Learned Dr. Cudworth hath long ago wrote a peculiar Di≈øcour≈øe) was ≈øo ancient among tho≈øe Doctors, that they had it before the times of Chri≈øt; it gives the plaine≈øt account, why John the Bapti≈øt u≈øes the word Chri≈øt and Bridegroom, as if they were in a manner ≈øynonymous, and of the ≈øame import, III. Joh. 28, 29. and why Chri≈øt him≈øelf compares the whole bu≈øine≈øs of his heavenly Kingdom (called by the people in St. Mark XI. 10. the Kingdom of our Father David) to a Marriage, or Marriage-fea≈øt, which a King made for his Son, Matth. XXII. 2, &c.

V. And this is one Argument of its being a very ancient Notion among them, that Idolatry and fal≈øe Wor≈øhip in the Church, is con≈øtantly expre≈ø≈øed in the Scriptures, under the name of ≈øpiritual fornication, and going a whoring from God: whom therefore the Church was to look upon as her Husband. And ≈øo he taught the Children of I≈ørael to do, by u≈øing this form of Speech throughout the whole Prophetical Writings, LIV. I≈øai. 5. LXII. 4, 5. III. Jerem. 4.20. XXXI. 32. II. Ho≈øea 2, 7. and many other places. Nay, the very Words of the Apo≈øtle to the Ephe≈øians, ≈øeem to ≈øuppo≈øe ≈øome ≈øuch my≈øtical ≈øen≈øe, which was current in
that Nation, of tho≈øe Words of Adam the fir≈øt man, II. Gene≈ø. 23, 24. This now is bone of my bone, and fle≈øh of my fle≈øh, &c. therefore ≈øhall a man leave his father and mother and ≈øhall cleave unto his wife; and they ≈øhall be one fle≈øh. Which the Apo≈øtle takes, as if they had been ≈øpoken of Chri≈øt, and his love to his Church, as any one may ≈øee that will read V. Ephe≈ø. 29, 30, 31, 32. For the≈øe are not in the account of the Cabbali≈øts, two di≈øtinct ≈øen≈øes: but one and the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe, different only as the matter and the form of the ≈øame thing: which form, ≈øay they, lies latent under the matter, whereby we are led unto it, as the main thing comprehended in it.

Thus Archangelus Burgonoven≈øis ≈øpeaks, in his Preface to the Explication of ≈øome ≈øelect Aphori≈øms of tho≈øe Divines, gathered by Mirandula, who ob≈øerves al≈øo (p. 91. of his Book) that as immediately after the Fabrick of the World was reared, Matrimony followed, as the Emblem of God's great love to tho≈øe that ≈øhould believe on Him; ≈øo this World ≈øhall end in the Sacrament of Marriage: St. John ≈øhutting up all the My≈øteries of the holy Scripture in the Revelation, with the≈øe Words, Let us be glad and rejoyce, for the marriage of the Lamb is come, and his Wife hath made her ≈øelf ready, XIX. Rev. 7. Which, if it be the voice of the heavenly Ho≈øt, agrees with what the Hebrew Doctors ≈øay (in Perke Elie≈øer, Cap. 12.) of the Marriage of Adam and Eve: that the Angels
rejoyced at it, and with mu≈øick and dancing attended upon the Wedding.

VI. All which things put together ≈øhow how naturally the thoughts of David were led, at Solomon's Marriage, to ≈øing concerning Chri≈øt and his Church; and the thoughts of Solomon afterward to ≈øing more largely of the wonderful love of the ≈øame heavenly Bridegroom, in this Song of Songs; that is, mo≈øt excellent Song. For ≈øo it may be truly called both in regard of its Subject matter; and in regard of the manner of its compo≈øure: this Parabolical way of writing, by Figures and Similitudes, being in many regards (as the forenamed Cabbali≈øtical Doctors di≈øcour≈øe) the be≈øt of all others. Fir≈øt, becau≈øe it is taken from things ≈øen≈øible, by which both learned men and ignorant may be in≈øtructed. Secondly, becau≈øe ≈øuch Narrations very ea≈øily imprint them≈øelves on the mind: a Parable (≈øay they) being in≈øtead of an artificial Memory. And thirdly, becau≈øe all our knowledge hath its ri≈øe from ≈øen≈øe, and therefore ≈øymbolizes much with ≈øen≈øible Parables. 15. And therefore I require all tho≈øe that act by authority from me, and to whom I have committed the care of my Church, to u≈øe their early diligence al≈øo to di≈øcover and confute the ≈øophi≈øtry of Deceivers, who craftily in≈øinuate their fal≈øe Doctrines into weak and incautious Souls; and thereby ≈øeduce tho≈øe who are newly converted, or but infirm in the Faith. See Annot. [o].

div.head: Spou≈øe.
div.p: 16. ¬∂ My beloved is mine, and I am his, he feedeth among the lilies.

16. Unto which I hear the Church reply, I will pre≈øerve my fidelity to Him, who is my only Beloved as I am his; I will have nothing to do with tho≈øe ≈øeducing Spirits, but adhere to Him alone: who≈øe Dwelling is not among ≈øubtile and crafty, but with ≈øimple and candid Souls. See Annot. [p].
17. Until the day break, and the ≈øhadows flee away: turn my beloved, and be thou like a roe, or a young hart upon the mountains of Bether.

17. Only let Him be plea≈øed to vouch≈øafe his gracious pre≈øence with me, and to enlighten me more and more; till we have a full knowledge of Him and of his Will, (XIII. Rom. 11, 12.) and the light of it ≈øcatter all the ≈øhadows of the law: Let my Beloved al≈øo make ha≈øte to ≈øuccour and relieve me in all difficulties and di≈øtre≈ø≈øes; and ≈øhow the ≈øame readine≈øs for my pre≈øervation, that he did (v. 9.) for my fir≈øt ≈øalvation. See Annot. [q].

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p: [a] Ver≈øe 1.] There is ≈øo little ground to apply the ≈øeveral Parts of this Song, to the ≈øeveral Ages of the Church, till the end of all things, that I cannot think fit to follow ≈øuch Interpretations. But ≈øhall pur≈øue the Method I have begun, and ob≈øerve that the Me≈ø≈øiah is here introduced, as owning the Prai≈øes which the Church had be≈øtowed upon Him, in the Conclu≈øion of the foregoing Chapter. And that in ≈øuch Phra≈øes, as are becoming a Pa≈øtoral; borrowed from Flowers and Trees (under which Shepherds delight to ≈øit and eat the Fruit) and from ≈øuch Creatures as frequent the Fields and Woods, &c.

I am the ro≈øe] And in this Ver≈øe He fir≈øt compares Him≈øelf to a Ro≈øe: which is ≈øtill one of the goodlie≈øt things to which a great Prince can be likened in tho≈øe Ea≈øtern Countries. As appears from a Letter, written by the great Mogul in the Per≈øian Tongue, to K. James, ≈øent by Sir Tho. Roe: wherein he thus complements his Maje≈øty of Great Britain, As upon a Ro≈øe in a Garden, ≈øo are my eyes fixed upon you: God maintain your E≈øtate, that your Monarchy may pro≈øper, &c. But it was chiefly prized by Shepherds, and Shepherde≈ø≈øes; and accounted by them „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , as Philo≈øtratus ≈øpeaks, the Plant of Love. In≈øomuch, ≈øaith he, that if the great King have his Diadem on his Head, the Souldier his Helmet, as the greate≈øt Ornament; beautiful Youths ≈øhould have Chaplets of Ro≈øes, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , as near of kin to them both in ≈øweetne≈øs and in ruddine≈øs. And Achilles Tatius (L. 2.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ &c.) thus commends this lovely Flower. If Jupiter would ≈øet a King over the Flowers, it would be the Ro≈øe that ≈øhould reign over them: being the Ornament of the Earth, the ≈øplendor of Plants, the Eye of Flowers, the blu≈øhing Beauty of the Field; or refulgent brightne≈øs, &c.

of Saron] i. e. The mo≈øt excellent Ro≈øe: For ≈øuch were the Ro≈øes of Saron; as may be gathered from hence: That the Ro≈øe, according to Pliny's Ob≈øervation, delights in dry places; and will not thrive in fat and unctuous Soils, in rich Clays, or Grounds well watred, but in tho≈øe that are lean, full of rubbi≈øh, &c. Now ≈øuch was the Soil about Saron; as we learn from the Mi≈øchneh in the Title Sota, Chap. VIII. where they that built a Brick Hou≈øe in Saron are ≈øaid to have been deprived of the benefit of that Law, XX. Deut. 5. Upon which Pa≈ø≈øage R. Solomon glo≈ø≈øes, that the Earth thereabout
about was unfit for making Bricks; being ≈øo dry and crumbling that the Hou≈øes that were built of them, had need to be repaired twice in ≈øeven years. In≈øomuch, that the Jeru≈øalem-Talmud ≈øaith, The High Prie≈øt prayed by name for the Saronites, upon the Day of Expiation, that their Hou≈øes might not be converted into their Graves.

Lily of the valleys] By this Lily we are not to under≈øtand ≈øuch as we call Lilium convallium, or May-Lily: but ≈øome more noble and fragrant Flower; being joined here with Ro≈øes: As it is in ≈øeveral Poetical Fragments (quoted by Athenaeus L. XV. C. 8, 9.) with Violets, Marjoram, and divers other ≈øweet Flowers. In≈øomuch that he ≈øaith the Corinthians called the Lily by the name of Ambro≈øia: and he tells us out of Nicander, that it was e≈øteemed „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the joy and delight of Venus, becau≈øe of its beautiful colour: And ≈ømell al≈øo, I ≈øuppo≈øe; for in the XIIth Chapter of the ≈øame Book, he quotes a Pa≈ø≈øage out of Theophra≈øtus, who, treating of ≈øweet Ointments made of Flowers, mentions „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that of Lilies, as well as that of Ro≈øes.
But notwith≈øtanding all this, the Lily being vulgarly celebrated only for its beautiful colour, I have taken notice of that alone in the Paraphra≈øe.

[b] V. 2. As the Lily, &c.] They that believe in Chri≈øt partaking of his Excellencies, He here compares the Church to a Lily (i.e. to Him≈øelf) as much excelling all other people who were not Believers (for Daughters ≈øignifie people in the Hebrew Language) as the Lilies do Thornes, which grow in de≈øolate places. For the Word we tran≈ølate Thornes, is wont to be joined together with tho≈øe which ≈øignifie Nettles and Brambles, XXXIV. I≈øai. 13. IX. Ho≈øea 6.

[c] V. 3. As the Apple-Tree, &c.] To this the Church here replies; and expre≈ø≈øes her reciprocal affection, in ≈øuch Words as may be applied to ≈øignifie his preheminence over all other gods; whom they were wont to wor≈øhip under Trees, as we read in XII. Deut. 2. 1 Kings XIV. 23. LVII. I≈øai. 5. and many other places.
I ≈øat down under, &c.] In the latter Part of this Ver≈øe and in tho≈øe that follow ≈øhe turns her Speech to her Companions and Attendants; relating the ≈øatisfaction and joy ≈øhe took in his love.

[d] V. 4. He brought me, &c.] Which is ≈øet forth by a Banquet, whereby (it is well known) the Hebrews are wont to repre≈øent the joys, even of the other World. And what greater joy have we here than to think of the ≈øtupendous love of God our Saviour towards us? which cannot but ≈øubdue our hearts to love Him intirely. So I have paraphra≈øed the latter part of the Ver≈øe (his Banner over me was love) taking in two ≈øen≈øes of which the Words are capable. The mo≈øt obvious is that Love was the In≈øcription in his Banner: the other that He conquers only by Love; a Banner di≈øplayed ≈øuppo≈øing an Armed Force marching under it. Delherrus in his Electa, L. 3. C. 9. hath not unfitly glo≈ø≈øed upon the Words, thus; The Banner of our Lord is his love which he hath publickly declared to us, that He might draw us to Him≈øelf: by which al≈øo when we are come to Him, He retains us with Him; and ≈øtrengthens us by the ≈øame, when we fight with our ≈øpiritual Enemies. And that we may alway look upon it and never quail, He carries it over us; that is, renders his love mo≈øt familiar to us. He that knows not this Banner, can be none of his Souldiers; and he that de≈øerts it, is undone, unle≈øs he pre≈øently return to it. So that as the Roman Legions had their ≈øeveral names
(one of which was called the Pious, and another the Faithful, another the Thundring, another the Victorious, &c.) in like manner the Chri≈øtian Band may be called Amoris Legio, the Legion of Love.

[e] V. 5. Stay me with flagons, &c.] This Ver≈øe is a de≈øcription of one falling into a ≈øwound, by the abundance of her love: In which ca≈øe Cordial Spirits are wont to be called for, to revive ≈øuch per≈øons, and keep them from fainting quite away. Comfortable ≈ømells al≈øo are wont to be admini≈øtred to the No≈øe; which is the meaning of calling here for fragrant Apples, Oranges, Citrons, &c. (as well as Wine) which are all comprehended under the name of tappuach in the Hebrew: which is a Word that in its very Original imports an exhalation, or odour-breathing from that which is ≈øo called. By all which the Church is repre≈øented to be ≈øo marvellou≈øly affected with the love of Chri≈øt, as to be even oppre≈ø≈øed under the weight of Divine Benefits: and at a perfect lo≈øs, what to think of them; having little or nothing to return for ≈øuch infinite obligations.

[f] V. 6. His left hand, &c.] This is a repre≈øentation of the tendere≈øt affection of an Husband to his Wife, when he ≈øees her in danger to faint: and being applied to Chri≈øt and his Church ≈øets forth his readine≈øs to ≈øuccour us, in all our needs, by the power of his Spirit. I go not about to divine what is di≈øtinctly meant by the left hand, and what by the right (which I look upon as too great a curio≈øity in Interpreters) but take them both to expre≈øs one and the ≈øame thing. And the hand of the Lord ≈øignifying oft-times in Scripture, the power of the Spirit, I have applied them to that.

[g] V. 7. I charge you, &c.] It is dubious whether this Ver≈øe be the voice of Chri≈øt or of the Church.
I take it to be his; who is the good Shepherd, repre≈øented in this Pa≈øtoral Song. Which, ≈øuitable to its nature, is ≈øtill full of Rural Similitudes, taken from the Roes and the Hinds: which are mo≈øt amiable Creatures (as hath been ob≈øerved upon VI. Proverbs) with which not only Shepherds, but the greate≈øt Per≈øons in the World have delighted them≈øelves. And that Word which we well tran≈ølate I charge you, I take to be only a ≈øolemn form of earne≈øt be≈øeeching and entreaty (which all per≈øons are wont to make by tho≈øe things that are deare≈øt to them) not an adjuration, which it is not lawful for any to make, but only by God. I have contented my ≈øelf therefore with this ≈øimple Paraphra≈øe of that Pa≈ø≈øage; and ≈øought for no my≈øtical Interpretation, as the manner is, which may be found in mo≈øt Interpreters. Who, among other things, by Roes and Hinds under≈øtand the Angelical Powers: to which the Cabbali≈øts apply the≈øe Words, and would have them to ≈øignifie as much, as I adjure you by the Tribunal of Ju≈øtice whence the wicked are puni≈øhed.

[h] V. 8. he cometh leaping, &c.] To the ≈øame ≈øort of Creatures, and to young wild Kids, he alludes in this ver≈øe. For they are numbred among tho≈øe Creatures, which are mo≈øt nimble, in running, jumping and leaping, even to the tops of Mountains; as Bochartus hath largely ≈øhown: demon≈øtrating that what we tran≈ølate young Hart, v. 9. is the young wild Goat. I ≈øeek therefore for no My≈øtery here neither; but take the Words to be a de≈øcription only of our Lord's alacrity and cheerfulne≈øs, to come down from the Heavens (which may be meant by Mountains) to dwell among us, who live here below upon the Earth. Yet I ≈øhall note, that they ≈øeem to be mo≈øt ingenious, who hereby under≈øtand his pa≈ø≈øing by Angels (for ≈øo ≈øome tran≈ølate the Words,
skipping over the Mountains) and leaping, as it were, over their heads, to take upon Him the nature of Man.

[i] V. 9.] In like manner, it is a very ingenious conjecture, that his ≈øtanding behind the Wall, in this Ver≈øe, may be applied to his ≈øhowing Him≈øelf in tho≈øe days only in the Law of Mo≈øes (which was the Wall of partition between the Jews and us) and his looking through the Window, or in at the Window, &c. to his ≈øhowing Him≈øelf then in Figures and Prophecies, which they had of Him; by which He was known but ob≈øcurely to them. But I have not medled with this in the Paraphra≈øe.

[k] V. 10, 11. lo the winter is pa≈øt, &c.] In the≈øe Ver≈øes Solomon repre≈øents his voice ≈øpeaking to them by the Prophets (though He him≈øelf was not come) and calling them to Him, as if He was ju≈øt appearing. For by the Winter and the Rain, I under≈øtand with Theodorer,
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the time before his coming: when the Gentile World was buried in Di≈ømal darkne≈øs; and the Jews them≈øelves ≈øaw things only through Clouds: and neither of them had much of the warmth of the Divine Love.

[l] V. 12. The flowers appear, &c.] And then here follows a de≈øcription of the Spring: which is ≈øet forth by three things; the appearing of the Flowers, which had lain as if they had been dead; the ≈øinging of Birds; and the voice of the Turtle. Which, as Ari≈øtotle ob≈øerves (L. VIII. Hi≈øtor. Nat. C. 3.) di≈øappears in Winter, and comes forth again when the Spring is a little advanced: and therefore is here very properly mentioned in the la≈øt place, among the Notes of the Spring. Which being the time of all other mo≈øt welcome to Shepherds, for the feeding of their Flocks, and for all manner of plea≈øures, repre≈øents, as the ≈øame Theodoret conceives, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the joyful time after our
Saviours coming. When a new World appeared, and there was a greater abundance of Divine Ble≈ø≈øings, e≈øpecially of the Spirit, poured forth: which the Chaldee Paraphra≈øt takes to be meant by the voice of the Turtle. Which is a kind of Dove; in the form of which the Holy Gho≈øt de≈øcended at our Saviour's Bapti≈øm. And then the ≈øinging of Birds may be applied to the Songs of the heavenly Ho≈øt, at his Birth. Others will have this Turtle to have been the Figure of John the Bapti≈øt; which is al≈øo pat enough: But I have only toucht upon ≈øuch things, and do not think fit here to enlarge upon them. But conclude this Note, with this Ob≈øervation, that Benjamin Tudelen≈øis, in the Conclu≈øion of his Itinerarium expre≈øly applies the≈øe Words to the coming of the Me≈ø≈øiah: ≈øaying, that they cannot be gathered to their own Land, till that time of the ≈øinging of Birds come, and the voice of the Turtle; and till they come who preach glad tidings, ≈øaying alway the Lord be prai≈øed. R. Al≈øchech al≈øo applies the voice of the Turtle to Elias glo≈ø≈øing thus, The voice of the Turtle al≈øo hath it not been heard in our Land, by the means of the Prophet? according to that which is ≈øaid, Behold I will ≈øend to you Elias the Prophet, IV. Mal. 5.

[m] V. 13. The fig-tree putteth forth, &c.] After the Spring-time, here follows a de≈øcription of the entrance of Summer: of which the putting forth green Figs, and the blowing of the Vines, nay the knotting of the Grapes, were a ≈øign. In the end of which the Harve≈øt coming, hereby is denoted, ≈øaith the ≈øame Father (Theodoret)
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the World which we expect hereafter: unto which I have applied this Ver≈øe. Where, it may be ob≈øerved, that Fig-trees and Vines are fitly joined, for they were wont to be planted together, XIII. Luke 6, 7.

[n] V. 14. O my Dove, that art in the Clefts, &c.] Some of the Hebrew Writers, who≈øe ≈øen≈øe the Chaldee Paraphra≈øt expre≈ø≈øes, refer this to the people of I≈ørael flying from Pharaoh, like a Dove before the Hawk that is ready to ≈øeize her: but may be better referred to the Church of Chri≈øt in danger to be torn in pieces by her Pagan Per≈øecutors, and by the Jews them≈øelves; as it was in the beginning of our Religion. Which forced Chri≈øtians to hold their A≈ø≈øemblies under ground, in ob≈øcure places (where they ≈øung Hymns to our Ble≈ø≈øed Lord before the break of day) and made the Church perfectly like a Dove, who, being in fear of ravenous Birds, flies into Clefts of Rocks, and to ≈øecret Holes in ≈øteep places, to pre≈øerve her ≈øelf.

The Church is ≈øo often compared by Chri≈øt to a Dove in this Book, that it is fit to give ≈øome account of it. And Bochartus de Sacr. Animal. p. 11. L. I. C. 4. takes this to be the principal, if not only rea≈øon of it; to ≈øignifie her to be his only Beloved: and that He alone al≈øo is mo≈øt dear to her. For in Doves there is a wonderful love (ob≈øerved by many Authors) between tho≈øe that are once paired: who never part, but keep faithful the one to the other. And ≈øo are a fit Emblem of the Church, whom the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith he had e≈øpou≈øed to Chri≈øt as a cha≈øte Virgin, 2 Cor. XI. 2.

let me ≈øee thy Countenance] that Word which we tran≈ølate countenance or a≈øpect, may be rendred ≈øhape or fa≈øhion: denoting all the comely proportions of the Church, by her likene≈øs to her Lord Chri≈øt.

[o] V. 15. Take us the Foxes] Foxes abound in Judea, and are ob≈øerved, by abundance of Authors, love Grapes, and to make great deva≈øtations in in Vineyards. In≈øomuch that Ari≈øtophanes in his Equites compares Souldiers to Foxes; ≈øpoiling whole Countries, as they do Vineyards. Now the Prophet Ezekiel comparing fal≈øe Prophets to Foxes, XIII. 4.
it hath bed all Interpreters (in a manner) to under≈øtand by Foxes in this place, Hereticks: who appeared very early in the Church, and therefore are compared to young Foxes: in regard of their known craft and ≈øubtilty, windings and turnings, ≈øhifts and eva≈øions; whereby the more ≈øimple ≈øort e≈øpecially, and ≈øuch as were newly converted (compared here to tender Grapes, as the Church it ≈øelf is to a Vine) were in danger to be undone, unle≈øs a timely care was taken to prevent it. And therefore this Ver≈øe ≈øeems to be an An≈øwer to the Churches Prayers, flying to her Lord for refuge. Who ≈øeeing her danger not to be greater from Tyranny, than from fal≈øe Teachers, calls upon his Companions; that is, the Apo≈øtles, Bi≈øhops, and Pa≈øtors of the Church to look after them, and to take them in their craftine≈øs. And that whil≈øt they were young; in the beginning, that is, of their appearance in the World: becau≈øe their vain bablings were apt to encrea≈øe to more ungodline≈øs, and their words did eat as a Gangrene, &c. 2 Tim. II. 16, 17. E≈øpecially when the Church was but newly planted, and tho≈øe Seducers applied them≈øelves chiefly to ≈øuch as had but newly received the Faith, or to weak and un≈øettled people: who were ea≈øily caught by them, unle≈øs great care were taken to di≈øcover their frauds, and to confute their Sophi≈øtry.

Which was the taking of the≈øe Foxes, as Theodoret expounds it: And St. Bernard al≈øo; who ob≈øerves that he ≈øaith take to us the Foxes: that is, Sibi & Spon≈øae, to Him≈øelf, and to his Spou≈øe. As much as to ≈øay, if it be po≈ø≈øible, let them be reconciled to the Catholick Church, and brought back to the true Faith. If that could not be, then other methods ≈øucceeded; and the Apo≈øtles delivered up ≈øuch dangerous Deceivers unto Satan (which was a puni≈øhment that included in it bodily affliction) that they might learn not to bla≈øpheme, 1 Tim. I. ult.

[p] V. 16. My beloved is mine, &c.] As the former Ver≈øe was his An≈øwer to the Churches Prayers; ≈øo this is the Churches acknowledgment to Him for his care: together with a profe≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch firm adherence to Him, as ≈øutes with the name of a Dove which he had be≈øtowed on her, v. 14.
he feedeth] To feed, viz. his Flock, is to have his abode among them. See VI. 2.

[q] V. 17. Until the day break, &c.] All that ≈øhe de≈øires further, is only his gracious pre≈øence with her; which ≈øhe begs in this Ver≈øe He would vouch≈øafe her upon the Mountains; that is, tho≈øe ≈øteep places mentioned before, v. 14. (where the Church was fain to Wor≈øhip Him in great ≈øecret, becau≈øe of the pre≈øent danger) e≈øpecially while any Di≈øputes and Controver≈øies remained about the Jewi≈øh Ceremonies which were a great di≈øturbance to the Church; as well as the afflictions and per≈øecutions ≈øhe endured, which are compared to the night and darkne≈øs, as the other to ≈øhadows.
turn, my beloved] The Word turn doth not ≈øuppo≈øe Him ab≈øent: but only that He did not immediately attend, or ≈øhow the regard He had to her Prayers in di≈øtre≈ø≈øes.
like a Roe] See Chap. VIII. v. ult.

mountains of Bether] Bether is the ≈øame with Bethel, the≈øe two Letters, r and l, being ea≈øily and often changed, as Bochartus hath ob≈øerved (in his Geograph. Sacra, Part. 2. L. I. C. 33.) in many in≈øtances. As for Example, an I≈øland in the Per≈øian Gulph, is indifferently called Tyrus and Tylus: and Tavila in Spain is the ≈øame with Tabira: and Caralis in Sardinia the ≈øame with Calaris, &c. In another Work indeed of his de ≈øacris Animal. he takes mountains of Bether for Mountains full of Clefts. Which would agree well with what went before, v. 14; and might be hand≈øomely
applied to the State of the Church, when there were many breaches and rents in it: but the other plainer and more literal.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Here begins the third of tho≈øe interlocutory Di≈øcour≈øes, which compo≈øe this famous Song: part of which only is contained in this Chapter. In which the Bride and her Companions ≈øpeaks all; but one Ver≈øe, which ≈øeems to be ≈øpoken by the Bridegroom. For who≈øe coming ≈øhe ≈øtill longs; and is introduced full of ≈øolicitude about it. Which proved not in vain but was gratified with ≈øo much ≈øatisfaction in the hope of it, that, as He takes care it ≈øhould not be di≈øturbed, ≈øo all her Companions rejoyce exceedingly in it. For tho≈øe are the two parts al≈øo of this Chapter. In the fir≈øt of which ≈øhe te≈øtifies her earne≈øt de≈øire to find Him; who filled her with joy, when ≈øhe had got a ≈øight of Him (in the four fir≈øt Ver≈øes:) in the ≈øecond, they that attended on her (after He had renewed his former charge, v. 5.) are tran≈øported with joy, to behold the multitude of his Followers; and the greatne≈øs of his Royal Glory. Which is the ≈øen≈øe of the re≈øt of the Chapter.

div.head: Spou≈øe.
div.p: 1. BY night on my bed I ≈øought him whom my ≈øoul loveth: I ≈øought him, but I found him not.

1. MAny have been my thoughts about Him, who (by what the Prophets have foretold of Him) is become the Beloved of my Soul. But though I have ≈øought Him in the greate≈øt retirements, and when my mind was mo≈øt compo≈øed, and that one night after another; though with a diligent ≈øearch I have ≈øought Him in all
the holy Books; yet I can find no more than predictions and ≈øhadows of Him, which a≈ø≈øure me He will come; but cannot bring me to the ≈øight and clear knowledge of Him. See Annot. [a].
2. I will ri≈øe now, and go about the city, in the ≈øtreets, and in the broad ways I will ≈øeek him whom my ≈øoul loveth: I ≈øought him, but I found him not.

2. Whereupon I re≈øolved to leave the≈øe private Studies, and to go abroad and con≈øult with others: And there is no place which I have not frequented, where I thought I might learn any thing of Him. For I have fetcht a compa≈øs round the whole City of Jeru≈øalem (which is the holy City, the joy of the whole Earth) and there is not one Street, not any place of publick re≈øort, but I have gone into it, and inquired after Him, both in the le≈ø≈øer and greater A≈ø≈øemblies; I enquired of all the holy men I could meet withal: but could meet with no more tidings of Him; whom my Soul longs to ≈øee; becau≈øe I love Him above all things. See Annot. [b].
3. The watchmen that go about the city, found me: to whom I ≈øaid, Saw ye him whom my ≈øoul loveth?

3. But in the mid≈øt of the≈øe anxious thoughts there was ≈øome ≈øatisfaction pre≈øented to me, from ≈øome of tho≈øe great Mini≈øters of God, who watch for the good of others; and employ them≈øelves every where to direct his people: of whom I made the ≈øame enquiry if they could tell me any thing of Him, who had engaged my affections ≈øo much, that I could not often enough profe≈øs my love unto Him. See Annot. [c].

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p: [a] Ver≈øe 1.] The beginning of this Chapter might be connected with the foregoing, and applied to the State of the Church under affliction; if the following Words would ≈øute with that Expo≈øition, which they do not, in my Opinion: For He had de≈øired to hear her voice, v. 14. of the ≈øecond Chapter, and now ≈øhe cannot find Him. Therefore I incline to think, that the very ≈øame thing is again repre≈øented in other Words (after the manner of the Prophets; particularly of I≈øaiah, who over and over again, in ≈øeveral ≈øchemes of ≈øpeech foretels their re≈øtauration from the Captivity of Babylon, and, under that ≈øhadow, their greater ≈øalvation by Chri≈øt) viz. the earne≈øt de≈øire of the Church for the coming of Chri≈øt: which Solomon expre≈ø≈øes by the pa≈ø≈øionate longings he found in him≈øelf to ≈øee that ble≈ø≈øed day.

By night] And ≈øo by night, may be under≈øtood that dark time, which was before his appearing; when good men ≈øought for Him, and had many Dreams and Vi≈øions about Him: but could meet only with the ≈øhadows and images of Him; which ≈øignified Him to come, but did not exhibit his very pre≈øence to them. Of which neither the Temple, nor the Sacrifices, nor the ≈øacred Books, could di≈øcover any thing clearly: but was repre≈øented here to Solomon in a Vi≈øion he had of Him, and of the Church which was e≈øpou≈øed to Him, after he had ≈øought a long time, and groped every where after Him, in that dark night wherein they lived. on my bed] This is expounded with ≈øtrange variety by Interpreters: ≈øome under≈øtanding hereby the bed of affliction, others, the bed of ea≈øe and plea≈øure, others, of weakne≈øs and infirmity, &c. in the ≈øtreets, &c.] Schevakim, which we tran≈ølate Streets are the le≈ø≈øer thorow-fares in the City, or the Streets of le≈ø≈øer Cities: as Rechoboth, are the greater, wider Streets, or rather the Streets of the Royal, Capital City: ≈øignifying here his ≈øearch both in the le≈ø≈øer and the greater A≈ø≈øemblies of God's people.

[c] V. 3. The Watchmen that go about, &c.] By Watchmen I under≈øtand the Prophets, and ≈øuch like excellent per≈øons who in≈øtructed the people (III. Ezek. 17. XXXIII. 6, 7.) of whom he asks, if they ≈øaw Him, whom he ≈øought after. From which Word I gather that he ≈øpeaks of ≈øuch, as were anciently called Seers: of whom he ≈øaith he was found; that is, they ≈øhowed him ≈øomething of the Me≈ø≈øiah.

[e] V. 5.] And there He expre≈ø≈øes his affection to him (that is, to the Church, who≈øe pa≈ø≈øionate de≈øires Solomon here repre≈øents in the four foregoing Ver≈øes) in the ≈øame Words, as He had done before in the foregoing Chapter, ver. 7. where this Ver≈øe is already explained.

[f] V. 6. Who is this, &c.] Here begins a new Vi≈øion, which he had of multitudes of people gathering unto Chri≈øt, like a Cloud of Smoak: which fills his Companions with great admiration. For it is their voice, which we read in this Ver≈øe: where the Word zoth may be tran≈ølated either what, or who: and by the Wilderne≈øs may be under≈øtood the forlorn condition, wherein men were before, not only in Gentili≈øm, but even in the Jewi≈øh E≈øtate. [g] V. 7. Behold his bed, &c.] And here is further repre≈øented in the ≈øame Vi≈øion, the happy condition of the Church (≈øignified by the Bed of Solomon) in Society and fellow≈øhip with Chri≈øt: of whom Solomon was a Type, both in his Royal Per≈øon, and State and Marriage (as appears from P≈øal. And may be lookt upon as a Figure of that ≈øtrong Guard, which is about the pro≈øperity and happine≈øs of the Church: which is defended by Angels, who are mighty ones indeed, and very numerous (LXVIII. P≈øal. 17.) and all mini≈øtring Spirits for tho≈øe that are Heirs of ≈øalvation, I. [h] V. 8. becau≈øe of fear in the night] And do all of them unanimou≈øly oppo≈øe the ≈øpiritual wickedne≈øs, i. e. wicked Spirits, in high places; who ≈øeek to de≈øtroy the Church (VI. Eph. 12. and may be meant by the terrour of the night, as the Hebrews expound the XCI. P≈øal. 5. and being the Rulers of the Gentile World ≈øtirred them up to per≈øecute Chri≈øtianity, as de≈øtructive to their Kingdom of darkne≈øs.

[i] V. 9. made him≈øelf a chariot] But, in ≈øpite of all they could do, Chri≈øt is here repre≈øented, under the Type of Solomon, as carrying his Church triumphantly through the World (for the Word appirjon, which is never el≈øewhere u≈øed, ≈øeems to ≈øignifie an open Chariot, in which Solomon, and, perhaps, his Queen, rode, to be expo≈øed to the view of every one, in the Streets of Jeru≈øalem) who beholding her,

the wood of Lebanon] is Cedar; denoting the perpetuity of the Go≈øpel: the preaching of which is the Chariot here mentioned. So Theodoret, by the „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ (as the Greek tran≈ølates it) „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , &c. let us under≈øtand, ≈øaith he, the holy Apo≈øtles, who carried the name of the Lord before the Gentiles, and Kings, and the Children of I≈ørael, &c. [k] V. 10.] The de≈øcription of the richne≈øs of this Chariot of Solomon's, follows in this Ver≈øe: in which we are not to ≈øeek, I think, for ≈øomething in the Go≈øpel an≈øwering to every part of it; but only to look upon it as ≈øetting forth the great ≈øplendour of it, and the riches of that Grace, which God vouch≈øafed to men therein.

The particular parts of the Chariot I have de≈øcribed as well as I could in our Language; and in≈øerted in my Parapha≈øe another Tran≈ølation of the la≈øt Word mibbenoth: which ≈øignifies as well from or by, as for, the Daughters of Jeru≈øalem. (which the Chaldee Paraphra≈øe touches upon) Where they make the day of Solomon's E≈øpou≈øals, to be the next day after the Fea≈øt which he held ≈øeven days, for the Con≈øecration of the Temple, 1 Kings VIII. 66. argument.head: ARGUMENT.

10. How fair is thy love, my ≈øi≈øter, my ≈øpou≈øe! how much better is thy love than wine! and the ≈ømell of thine ointments than all Spices.

10. Thy love to me and my Commandments, O how amiable is it! how doth it indear thee unto me, my beloved Spou≈øe! How much more delicious is that love, which thy Members have one for another, and for all men, than the be≈øt entertainments the World can give! How much more grateful are the re≈øt of thy Vertues, than the odours of the riche≈øt Spices, even of tho≈øe that are burnt at the Altar. See Annot [k].
11. Thy lips O my ≈øpou≈øe, drop as the honey-comb: honey and milk are under thy tongue, and the ≈ømell of thy garments is like the ≈ømell of Lebanon.

11. Nor are thy words le≈øs plea≈øing than thy deeds, the Honey that drops of it ≈øelf from the Comb, being not more ≈øweet, ≈øincere, and pure, than thy Doctrine, O my beloved Spou≈øe: which is the delicious Food of young and old, of weak and ≈øtrong, and mo≈øt powerfully recommended to their affections by the famed holine≈øs of thy life; which like the ≈øtrong Perfumes that come from the Aromatick Plants of Libanus, fill all places with the delightful ≈øcent thereof. See Annot. [l].
12. A garden enclo≈øed is my ≈øi≈øter, my ≈øpou≈øe: a ≈øpring ≈øhut up, a fountain ≈øealed.

12. For as a Garden well planted, watred and defended abounds with all ≈øort of Flowers, and with variety of plea≈øant Fruit; ≈øo doth my well-beloved Spou≈øe, by the ≈øingular care and ≈øpecial Providence of God over her, with all the fruits of righteou≈øne≈øs; admitting none to her My≈øteries, but tho≈øe who are pure and holy, and wa≈øht from all their defilements. See Annot. [m].
13. Thy Plants are an orchard of pomegranates, with plea≈øant fruits, camphire, with ≈øpikenard.

13. Which makes the ≈øeveral orders and Ranks of thy young Novices (≈øuch is the exemplary purity of their lives) look like the young Setts of Pomegranates, and other odoriferous Fruit: ≈øuch as the Cyprus, and Spikenards, which are growing up into a Paradi≈øe. See Annot [n].
14. Spikenard and ≈øaffron, calamus and cinnamon, with all trees of frankincen≈øe, myrrh and aloes, with all the chief ≈øpices.

14. Planted only with the like precious Herbs, Shrubs and Trees to tho≈øe now mentioned; as Saffron, ≈øweet Cane, Cinnamon, with tho≈øe that yield Frankincen≈øe, Myrrh, Aloes, and the choice≈øt
Spices: which are not more ≈øerviceable to our health or plea≈øure, than that rare compo≈øition of Graces, which is vi≈øible in the Church, make her Members acceptable unto God, and u≈øeful unto men. See Annot. [o].
15. A fountain of gardens, a well of living waters, and ≈øtreams from Lebanon.

15. Who≈øe Vertues are pre≈øerved in life and vigour by that heavenly Doctrine, which flows from me as plentifully and perpetually, as Waters do from tho≈øe Springs that break out of the high Mountain Libanus: which run continually a in large Stream; and, ≈øupplying all the Gardens in the neighbouring places, keep them fre≈øh and flouri≈øhing.
