div.head: Spou≈øe.
div.p: 16. ¬∂ Awake, O north-wind, and come thou ≈øouth, blow upon my garden, that the ≈øpices therefore may flow out: let my beloved come into his garden, and eat his plea≈øant fruits.

16. O let not then the in≈øpirations of the Holy Spirit, and its manifold Gifts be wanting unto me; but breathe perpetually upon me, as the North and the South Wind do upon this Garden: and then ≈øhall I be a Paradi≈øe indeed; and not only fill the World with the ≈øweet odour of the knowledge of Chri≈øt; but take the boldne≈øs to invite Him, the Beloved of my Soul, to come and reap the delightful Fruits (v. 13.) of his own care and labour. See Annot. [q].

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p:
[a] Ver≈øe 1.] Behold, thou art fair] The Lord of the Church is here introduced, de≈øcribing the beautiful e≈øtate of it, under the per≈øon of a lovely Virgin: who≈øe elegant features are particularly repre≈øented to rai≈øe admiration and love in others, and to give the Church the comfort of being ≈øo amiable in his eyes, whom no
beauty can plea≈øe but that which is Divine. And they are repre≈øented, by compari≈øons borrowed from the Country: which was mo≈øt ≈øuitable to a Bucolick, or Pa≈øtoral Poem: as, I have already ≈øaid, this is.

thou ha≈øt doves eyes] And fir≈øt her eyes are compared to tho≈øe of a Dove (for ≈øuch Rea≈øons as are ≈øugge≈øted in the Paraphra≈øe) when they are unveiled: as tho≈øe Words mibbaath let≈øammatech may be tran≈ølated (of which, ≈øee v. 3.) unto which I have had re≈øpect in my Paraphra≈øe, as well as to our Tran≈ølation where this Phra≈øe, is rendred, within thy locks.

thy hair, &c.] Then the hair of this Virgins head, is compared unto that of Goats, as the next Pa≈ø≈øage is to be tran≈ølated, by repeating the Word hair, in this manner; Thy hair is like the hair of a Flock of Goats. Thus the people of I≈ørael are ≈øaid to have brought for the ≈øervice of the Tabernacle, ≈øcarlet, and fine linen, and goats; that is, Goats hair, as we truly tran≈ølate it, XXXV. Exod. 23. And in the next Chapter, v. 13. he made Curtains of Goats (where we ≈øupply the Word hair) for the Tent over the Tabernacle, according as he had been ordered, XXV. 4. XXVI. 7. Upon which Pa≈ø≈øages Abarbinel ob≈øerves, that Mo≈øes makes no mention of Wool, either of Lamb or Sheep; becau≈øe that was vile and contemptible in tho≈øe Countries, in compari≈øon with the hair of Goats: which was wont to be ≈øhorn not only there, but in other places; for Ari≈øtotle ob≈øerves the ≈øame of the Goats of Cilicia. And ≈øome of them had a Wool, as we may call it, ≈øo fine, that it was almo≈øt as ≈øoft as Silk: which was that the Women ≈øpun for the u≈øe of the Tabernacle, XXXV. Exod. 26. To this ≈øort of hair, perhaps, there may be an allu≈øion in this place, in regard of its ≈øoftne≈øs, as well as length and thickne≈øs;
which is a great commendation of hair in men and women.

But there was al≈øo a cour≈øer or harder ≈øort, with which they made Locks and Ornaments for the Head; when they were bald, or would appear very fine: as Braunius hath ob≈øerved, in his Book about the Prie≈øts Garments, L. I. C. 9.

And in general it may be ob≈øerved of hair, that it was always accounted a very great Ornament: which made Philo≈øtratus, in a Letter of his to a Youth whom he loved, be≈øeech him by no means to cut it off, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , there being no le≈øs beauty in a good Head of hair, than in Gold, in Silver, in Pendants, and ≈øuch like Ornaments. Which he illu≈øtrates by what it contributes to the greatne≈øs of ≈øeveral other Creatures, as the Lyon, and Hor≈øe, &c. and was notably expre≈ø≈øed by Lycurgus, when he gave this rea≈øon, why he ordered in his Laws that his Citizens ≈øhould take care of the growth of their hair, becau≈øe it made beautiful per≈øons more comely, and deformed more terrible; as Plutarch relates in his Apophthegms.

that appear from mount Giled] Galaad was a Mountain fit for Goats to brouze on, as may be ≈øeen in Bochart: who ≈øhows the≈øe la≈øt Words of this Ver≈øe, ≈øhould be thus tran≈ølated: that a≈øcend from Mount Gilead, to the higher parts, that is, of that Mountain, or of that Country.

I ≈øhould have adventured to compare the Apo≈øtles and Prophets to the≈øe two eyes; who being illuminated by the Holy Gho≈øt (repre≈øented by a Dove) and having no other aim, but ≈øincerely to make Chri≈øt and his religion known in the World, re≈øembled the eyes of Doves (≈øee Chap. II. v. 14.) but I did not know to what the Locks and the Hair could be hand≈øomely applied; and therefore I have
lookt upon the≈øe, and the re≈øt that follow, only as parts of tho≈øe things that make up together a perfect beauty. Theodoret hath made the apte≈øt application, that I can find, which is this: that hair ≈øignifying what is ≈øuperfluous, the meaning may be (if there be any of every particular in this De≈øcription) that even in humane things, and worldly Affairs, wherewith we cannot but be ≈øometime perplexed, the Church behaves her ≈øelf laudably and pre≈øerves a decorum.

[b] V. 2. Thy teeth are like a flock of ≈øheep] Here follows a de≈øcription of the Teeth; which are a great part of the beauty of the mouth, as that is of the face. And their beauty con≈øi≈øts in their whitene≈øs; in their evenne≈øs and ju≈øt proportions; and in their clo≈øene≈øs and firmne≈øs: ≈øo that there be none wanting, nor any Gap between them. Which are all here expre≈ø≈øed, and ≈øaid to be like a Flock of Sheep come from the wa≈øhing, in re≈øpect of whitene≈øs; and as equal as if they had been exactly poli≈øhed and fitted for their places, in ju≈øt proportion, by an Artificer (≈øo the Word we tran≈ølate ≈øhorn ≈øignifies) they that are below al≈øo an≈øwering to tho≈øe above, as if they were Twins. And none of them mi≈øcarry (≈øo that which we tran≈ølate barren ≈øhould be rendred) i. e. drops out of the mouth: which is as much as to ≈øay, there is a perfect number, as well as order of them.

Now the Teeth being the In≈øtruments whereby we chew our Meat, they may be lookt upon as an apt Emblem of the inferior Pa≈øtors in the Church: who prepare Chri≈øtian Doctrine for the people. Which Application, though I have not adventured to make in my Paraphra≈øe (becau≈øe I take the≈øe five fir≈øt Ver≈øes to mean no more, but only to ≈øet forth the loveline≈øs of the Church in general, by the Figure of a Virgin, of a mo≈øt accompli≈øhed beauty) yet, I ≈øhall here note,
for the help of tho≈øe who≈øe thoughts lead them that way, that the Vertues of ≈øuch Pa≈øtors are, candor, purity, order, concord, exact agreement among them≈øelves, one of them not ≈øeeking ambitiou≈øly to over-top the re≈øt.

[c] V. 3. Thy lips, &c.] In the beginning of this Ver≈øe there is no great difficulty: it being certain that Schani (the colour of the lips) ≈øignifies ≈øome very bright and re≈øplendent colour; which ≈øtrikes the eyes ≈øharply (as it originally ≈øeems to import) viz. either Scarlet, as we tran≈ølate it, or Crim≈øon, or Purple: ≈øuch as the Poets call Coral Lips. Who≈øe finene≈øs is here compared to a Thread; and is another great part of Beauty: as a ≈øweet accent of the Voice al≈øo is; nothing being more ungrateful than a tone that is coar≈øe and clowni≈øh.

If any li≈øt to apply the≈øe particularly to ≈øomething in the Church; the Lips may be thought to ≈øignifie the Teachers in the Church, who delivered the Doctrine they had learnt from the higher Mini≈øters; who had prepared it for them; and, by them, for the people. And then the voice ≈øignifies their excellent manner of preaching: in≈øinuating into the hearts of tho≈øe that heard them; being accompanied with great mode≈øty and humility, though full of authority and power. Unto which only the la≈øt Clau≈øe of this Ver≈øe can be applied; which is this,

p.hi: thy Temples are like a piece of a Pomegranate, within thy locks.

div.p:
Where two or three Words puzzle Interpreters. Fir≈øt, that which we tran≈ølate Temples; which are not reckoned as a part of the beauty of the face, e≈øpecially being cover'd by the Locks: and why they ≈øhould be likened to a Slice of a Pomegranate, is hard to tell. Grotius therefore, by the Temples under≈øtands the Cheeks (as the Vulgar doth) which in regard of their redne≈øs, are like to the Grains or Kernels
within a Pomegranate. So the Chaldee indeed interprets the other Word, a piece of a Pomegranate: when he thus glo≈ø≈øes, They are repleni≈øhed, (viz. ju≈øt and pious men to whom he applies it) with Precepts, as a Pomegranate: i. e. as a Pomegranate is with Kernels or Grains with which it abounds, and to which that Interpreter, no doubt, hath re≈øpect.

But our learned Dr. Ca≈øtell hath out of the Neighbouring Languages more clearly explained both the≈øe Words, and the la≈øt al≈øo; and hath made them all ea≈øie and natural, by ≈øhewing that the whole Clau≈øe is thus mo≈øt exactly tran≈ølated: as the Flower of the Pomegranate, ≈øo are thy Cheeks without a Veil. So he tran≈ølates the la≈øt Words, which we met withal before, v. 1. mibbaath let≈øammatech not within thy locks; but without a Veil. That is, when thy veil is laid a≈øide, thy Cheeks appear of a mo≈øt lovely colour; for ≈øuch is that of the Pomegranate-Flower; the pure≈øt white and red, mo≈øt exactly mixed. V. Orat. in Schola Theolog. p. 37.

[d] V. 4. Thy neck is like, &c.] The neck being compared to the Tower of that goodly Fortre≈øs, which David made upon Mount Sion, which overtopt all the re≈øt of the Buildings of the City of Jeru≈øalem, denotes, among other things, the tallne≈øs of the whole Body.

built for an armoury] This Tower is ≈øaid to be built letalpijoth (for an Armory we render it) which the LXX knew not what to make of, and therefore retain the Hebrew Word: and others do but gue≈øs at its meaning; having no certain Root, from whence to fetch its Original. Aquila tran≈ølates it Fortifications; but Symmachus tran≈ølates it heighths: which la≈øt I have followed, adding another ≈øignification al≈øo derived from alaph, to teach or in≈øtruct.

thou≈øand bucklers] This Tower it ≈øeems was adorned with the Shields and Bucklers of tho≈øe mighty men mentioned 1 Sam. XXIII; and ≈øuch like Worthies: With which Grotius ingeniou≈øly compares tho≈øe precious Stones, which are wont to be the Ornament of the Neck. But what an≈øwers to this in the Body of the Church, I know not; unle≈øs we admit the Opinion of R. Solomon and others of that Nation: who will have this to be the place where the Sanhedrim had a Room called in their Language Liskath haggazith, the Chamber or Parlour of ≈øquare Stones (which ≈øome Interpreters have thought to be the meaning of built letalpijoth with ≈øquare Stones) where Judgment was admini≈øtred, and their Di≈øcipline pre≈øerved. Which was the ≈øtrength and ≈øupport of the Nation, as the General Council of the Apo≈øtles and Elders, mentioned Act. XV. was of the Chri≈øtian Church: who ≈øetled all doubts and Controver≈øies, as future Councils were to do, and thereby maintained the Church in order and peace. From which Theodoret doth not much differ, when he ≈øaith the Church hath many Shields, whereby it is defended. For thou art armed with all the Weapons of the Spirit (≈øaith he paraphra≈øing upon the≈øe Words) whereby thou ea≈øily wounde≈øt thy Enemies, &c. and ≈øometimes do≈øt refel them by the Prophets, ≈øometimes by the Apo≈øtles; and laye≈øt open their weakne≈øs.

[e] V. 5. Thy two brea≈øts, &c.] The two Paps ri≈øe upon the Brea≈øt, like Lilies from the Ground: among which if we conceive two red Kids feeding, that were Twins and perfectly alike, they appeared like the Nipples or Teats upon the Paps, to tho≈øe that beheld them afar off. Thus Bochart explains this Compari≈øon: which ≈øets forth the exact proportion, and the pure complexion of the Brea≈øts; unto which, mo≈øt think the Two Te≈øtaments, the Old
and the New, very aptly an≈øwer in the Chri≈øtian Church, ju≈øt as R. Solomon hereby under≈øtands the two Tables of Stone in the Jewi≈øh. But they forget that this is a de≈øcription of the parts of the Church (not of things belonging to it) and can be applied to nothing, that I can think of, but the two Orders of Preachers, that were, one among the Jewi≈øh Chri≈øtians, and the other among the Gentiles, as Gregory the Great expounds it. Who thinks the≈øe are called Twins, becau≈øe of their perfect agreement and concord in the Chri≈øtian Doctrine: though one of them bent their endeavours mo≈øt toward the conver≈øion of the Jews, and the other of the Gentiles. And indeed they that taught the fir≈øt Rudiments of Chri≈øtian Doctrine, went forth by Pairs, as we read Luke X. where Chri≈øt is ≈øaid to ≈øend them forth by two and two; to admoni≈øh them how nece≈ø≈øary their concord was; and that they had need to be a≈ø≈øi≈øtant, all they could, one to the other in ≈øuch a difficult Work.

[f] V. 6. mountain of myrrhe, &c.] Here now the de≈øcription ≈øtops, and proceeds no further to the lower Members of the Church: which are not particularly commended, but it is only intimated that, in conjunction with their Guides and Directors, they made up a beautiful Body; though for the pre≈øent ob≈øcured by the Night of per≈øecution, as the fir≈øt Words of this Ver≈øe may be applied. Which Body might be well compared to a Mountain of Myrrhe, and Hill of Frankincen≈øe, that is, to Mount Moriah and Jeru≈øalem, ≈øay the Hebrews (and ≈øo the Church is called the New Jeru≈øalem in the Revelation) where the ≈øweet incen≈øe made of the≈øe and other Spices (XXX. Exod. 34.) were continually burnt in the Temple.

I know it is commonly thought that other Mountains (afterwards mentioned, v. 8.) are here meant: about
which I ≈øhall not di≈øpute. But only ob≈øerve that the≈øe two, Myrrh and Frankincen≈øe, were among the mo≈øt precious Spices of tho≈øe Countries (and therefore here mentioned) as appears by what we read in Athenaeus (L. I. Diepno≈øoph. C. 3.) who, ≈øpeaking of the noble Entertainments, which were made by ≈øeveral per≈øons that overcame in the Olympicks, tells us that Empedocles, being a Pythagorean, and eating no Fle≈øh, when he won the Prize, cau≈øed an Oxe to be made of Myrrh and Frankincen≈øe and other precious Spices, which he divided among the Spectators. And (Cap. 8.) he puts the≈øe two among tho≈øe things, which were accounted „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , delicacy. And Hermippus relating what places were mo≈øt famous for ≈øeveral things, ≈øaith ‚Äî „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ that Frankincen≈øe came out of Syria, Cap. 21. The Ver≈øes al≈øo of Arche≈øtratus (L. III. p. 101.) make mention of Syria, and ≈øay the≈øe were u≈øed for Perfumes at Fea≈øts. The ≈øame I ob≈øerve in other places of that Author; and therefore have made the allu≈øion here only to the preciou≈øne≈øs of the≈øe things; which were no where ≈øo excellent as in tho≈øe Countries. And I have taken this Ver≈øe to be ≈øtill in prai≈øe of the before-de≈øcribed Beauty: for it is evident, from the following Ver≈øe, he had not yet done with that matter.

[g] V. 7. Thou art all fair, &c.] And here, to comprehend all that could be ≈øaid, he enlarges the commendation which he began withal, v. 1. and concludes in the≈øe Words that there was no defect in any part: but altogether they made up a compleat Beauty without the lea≈øt ≈øpeck of deformity. Which is not to be applied to every particular per≈øon in the Church: but, as I have taken it in the Paraphra≈øe, to the admirable Con≈øtitution of the whole, in which there was no imperfection.

[g] V. 8. Come with me from Lebanon, &c.] Here now begins a new repre≈øentation; as appears by this that the Style wherein the Bridegroom ≈øpeaks is altered; ≈øhe who hitherto hath been called his Love or Friend, being now called his Spou≈øe, and never before: though very frequently in the following part of the Song. Which hath moved Interpreters, I ≈øuppo≈øe to u≈øe this name throughout, rather than the other: as the higher and mo≈øt excellent Title.

Theodoret therefore here begins his Third Book, very judiciou≈øly: and we may look upon this as a de≈øcription of the Church, coming out of the ≈øtate of per≈øecution: and receiving greater te≈øtimonies of her Saviour's love than ever. For coming from the top of high Mountains, where there were Lyons Dens, and where Leopards inhabited; cannot well ≈øignifie any thing el≈øe, than coming from places where they were in danger to be devoured by their Per≈øecutors: who are compared to Lyons in many places of Scripture.

As for the Mountains them≈øelves, they are well-known where they were. Only Amana ≈øome have fan≈øied to be, that Mountain in Cilicia, called Amanus: which is reckoned among the highe≈øt; and joined by Aelian with Libanus and Carmel. We read al≈øo that there were Tygers and Panthers, &c. in this Mountain; which hath been brought to countenance this Opinion. But Judaea and the Neighbouring places, being the Scene of this Poem, we are not to go ≈øo far off as Cilicia to ≈øeek for Amana: for as Senir and Hermon were but parts of the ≈øame Mountains; ≈øo Amana was a part of Libanus, as Bochartus hath ob≈øerved in his Canaan, L. I. C. 5. And though the lower parts of this Mountain Libanus were very plea≈øant; yet the top of it, which is here ≈øpoken of, was horrid, and inhabited
with wild Bea≈øts. From whence the Spou≈øe is invited to come into more delightful and ≈øecure places: for ≈øhe is compared pre≈øently after to a Garden or Paradi≈øe, v. 12, 13, &c. And it is no wonder Solomon ≈øhould have the ≈øtate of the Chri≈øtian Church in trouble, thus repre≈øented to him: it being very ≈øuitable to the ≈øtate of the Church of the Jews, when it was fir≈øt formed; being then pre≈ø≈øed by Pharaoh, and many other Enemies afterward, before they came to Canaan.

[i] V. 9. Thou ha≈øt ravi≈øhed my heart, &c.] The fir≈øt Word of this Ver≈øe libbavtini (which is not to be found any where el≈øe) ≈øignifies ≈øome extraordinary motion in the heart. And is tran≈ølated by ≈øome, Thou ha≈øt wounded my heart; by the LXX (which we follow) thou ha≈øt taken away my heart: but may as well be tran≈ølated, Thou ha≈øt taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of my heart; and deeply engaged my affection. Which is expre≈ø≈øed by the addition of another name for her, whom he called Spou≈øe in the foregoing Ver≈øe; and here al≈øo calls Si≈øter. Which is only a Word of tenderne≈øs and indearment, u≈øed by Husbands to their Wives; as appears by the Book of Tobit; where Raguel calls his Wife Edna, his Si≈øter, VII. 16; and Tobias call; Sara by the ≈øame name, after he had married her, VIII. 4, 7.

one of thine eyes, &c.] All the difficulty here is, what may be thought to be meant by one of her eyes, and one chain of her neck. Some take eyes to ≈øignifie Faith and Charity; others the Church of the Jews and Gentiles; and then one eye mu≈øt ≈øignifie one glance, one look of thy eyes: but nothing plea≈øes me better than the old Interpretation of Alcuinus, who by the Word one under≈øtands onene≈øs or unity: and by the eyes (as v. 1.) the Pa≈øtors and Guides of the Church: And by the one wreath of
hair about the neck; the pious unity of the people ≈øubject unto them.
It may be interpreted al≈øo, the lea≈øt glance I have of thee and of thy beauty, mightily engages my love to thee: for the eyes are the very Seat of Love, as abundance of Authors expre≈øs it.

[k] V. 10. How fair is thy love] The love or rather loves (as it is in the Hebrew) which is here extolled; may ≈øignifie our love to God, and unto one another. And Ointments, be applied, to all the Graces which flow from thence.

[l] V. 11. Thy lips di≈øtil, &c.] That which di≈øtils from the lips, as Honey from the Comb, can be nothing but pure and mo≈øt delicious Doctrine; delivered in ≈øuch a manner, as to invite all to ta≈øt of it. For this by all ≈øort of Authors is compared to Honey; and made Xenophon be called the Attick, and Sappho the Pierian Bee: becau≈øe of the ≈øweetne≈øs of his Orations, and of her Poems. Whence the rare Eloquence of Plato, is ≈øaid to have been predicted by Bees, which came and ≈øat in his mouth, when he was an Infant: which is reported al≈øo, by no mean Authors, of Pindar, Lucan, and St. Ambro≈øe.

honey and milk are under thy tongue] This ≈øignifies the ≈øame thing; for the≈øe were anciently the Food of Infants; and may denote that the Church hath in≈øtruction for all ≈øorts. So wide from the truth is the Expo≈øition of the Doctors in Maimonides (porta Mo≈øis, p. 83.) that this Milk and Honey being ≈øaid to lie under the tongue, ≈øignifies the concealment of ≈øuch truths as are very ≈øweet, till men be fit to receive them.

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p:
[a] Ver≈øe 1.] Unto that invitation, which is made by the Spou≈øe in the latter end of the foregoing Chapter the Bridegroom here gives an an≈øwer: and te≈øtifies his acceptance, by coming to ta≈øte the Fruit of his Garden, nay, to make a Fea≈øt in it; of which He calls his Friends and Companions, after the manner

Then follows the Fea≈øt, (which they always made when they gathered the Fruits of the Earth) in the≈øe Words, I have eaten my Honey comb with my Honey, &c. Which is put in≈øtead of all other things, becau≈øe it was one of the greate≈øt entertainments of tho≈øe Countries. Who, among other noble Ve≈øtments, had an Embroidered Coat; the Sleeves of which, the Hebrews tell us, came down to his very Wri≈øts; nay, as Maimonides ≈øaith, as far as to the hollow of his hand. Which I take to be here meant by his hands (which comprehend the Arms and Shoulders) that is, the clothing of tho≈øe Parts. And the≈øe Sleeves, as well as the whole Coat, were embroidered (as you read, XXVIII. Exod. 4.) to make the High Prie≈øt appear the more glorious. And if you ask what this Embroidery was, the Hebrews tell us, that part of it con≈øi≈øted in a kind of oilet holes, finely wrought. And R. Solomon Jarchi expre≈øly ≈øaith upon that Text, that they were holes made in golden Rings, in which were fixed Precious Stones, &c. (as is afterward ≈øaid of the Stones of the Ephod, v. 11.) Which ≈øo fully explains the≈øe Words, His hands are as Gold Rings, ≈øet with the Beryl, that I need ≈øeek no further. Though I have ≈øometimes thought, that the Ephod it ≈øelf might be here intended: which being fa≈øtned upon the Shoulders (which in order, after the head, eyes, cheeks and lips, come to be here de≈øcribed, and are comprehended, as I ≈øaid before, under the name of his hands) hung down before and behind to the bottom of the back: and had two golden Rings, unto which the Brea≈øt-plate was fa≈øtned, as we read XXVIII. Exod. 27, 28. Maimonides ≈øaith it had four Rings: two above, at the Jewel-Buttons; and two below, about the Girdle of the Ephod. Which was one of the principal Ornaments of the High Prie≈øt, when He mini≈øtred: the other, and the
greate≈øt of all, was the Brea≈øt-plate hereunto annexed; and, as they ≈øay, was to be in≈øeparable from the Ephod.

Now this Brea≈øt-plate is meant, as I take it, in the latter part of this Ver≈øe. Where under that Word which we tran≈ølate Belly, and properly ≈øignifies Bowels, is comprehended the Brea≈øt, and all: Which this CHOSCHEN, as the Hebrews call it, covered: and as it covered tho≈øe parts, ≈øo was it ≈øelf covered, or overlaid with twelve Precious Stones. The Sapphire, which was the tenth, is only here mentioned; but it is u≈øual in Scripture, to touch only upon one thing in a Hi≈øtory, when the whole is intended. And be≈øides, it is evident from the foregoing part of this Ver≈øe, that more mu≈øt be under≈øtood, when one alone is mentioned: for Rings are ≈øpoken of in the Plural Number, and ≈øaid to be filled with Tar≈øis; which mu≈øt therefore denote more Stones than one; as Sapphire doth all the re≈øt of the twelve, which could not be mentioned in ≈øo ≈øhort a de≈øcription. Or Sepphirim here, in the Plural Number, may ≈øignifie Stones as precious as the Sapphire. Certain it is the Chaldee Paraphra≈øt thought there was ≈øome re≈øpect here to the High Prie≈øt's Brea≈øt-plate; for he mentions all the Stones therein, one by one. Which may make this Interpretation of mine to ≈øeem le≈øs ≈øtrange. And I conceive the Sapphire to be here mentioned rather than any other; becau≈øe it is of the colour of the Heavens, and fitte≈øt to repre≈øent the ≈øublime Dignity in which He is now de≈øcribed. For the Pavement under the feet of the God of I≈ørael, when He appeared unto their Nobles at Mount Sinai, was of this colour, XXIV. Exod. 10. and ≈øo was the Throne of God in the Firmament, which Ezekiel ≈øaw, I. Ezek. 26.

Nor need it ≈øeem ≈øtrange that the Belly, upon which this covering was, is ≈øaid to be of poli≈øhed Ivory (when there is no mention of any ≈øuch thing in the Law) for it only denotes that it was as ≈øhining and bright as that: and may po≈ø≈øibly relate to the Tunick or Coat of fine Linen, wherein the High Prie≈øt was to mini≈øter XXXVIII. Exod. 39. XXXIX. 27.) e≈øpecially upon the great day of expiation, when he was not to put on his Robe, nor his fine Linen Coat, with any Embroidery, but of fine Linen alone, XVI. Lev. 4.

The LXX ≈øeem to think it was the Brea≈øt-plate it ≈øelf (which indeed was very ≈øhining) for they tran≈ølate it „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ : which ≈øhows they meant ≈øome covering of the Belly which was hollow; as the Brea≈øt-plate was. Which I doubt not is the covering of Sapphires here mentioned: it being ≈øet, as you read, with twelve large Precious Stones, wherein were engraven the names of the twelve Children of I≈ørael. And was the mo≈øt precious part of all the High Prie≈øt's habit; and therefore more commonly called by the Jews an Ornament, than a Garment, or any part of his Ve≈øture: the whole of which was contrived for Glory and for Beauty, XXVIII. Exod. 40. i. e. that God might be ≈øerved mo≈øt magnificently.

[p] V. 15.] Next in order follows the de≈øcription of the Thighs; that is, of the Garments upon the Thighs: which were the very fir≈øt that the High Prie≈øt put on, when he went about to clothe him≈øelf for his Mini≈øtry. And are here ≈øaid to be made of Sche≈øch: which is a Word common to fine Linen, and to pure white Marble (≈øo the LXX twice tran≈ølate it Parian Marble, I. E≈øth. 6. 2 Chron XXIX. 2.) which the Breeches of the Prie≈øt re≈øembled, being made of By≈ø≈øus, or pure fine Linen; a thing of great price in tho≈øe Countries,
as appears both by Pliny and Pau≈øanias. The latter of which Authors in his Eliaca, mentions this among the rare things (which were worthy of admiration) in that Country; and ≈øaith, It was not inferiour to the By≈ø≈øus of the Hebrews. Who were ordered to make this part of the Prie≈øt's Garments of twined fine Linen, XXXIX. Exod. 28. which rendred them the more ≈øub≈øtantial; and made them ≈øit the fuller and ≈øtiffer, like Pillars. For the Hebrews ≈øay they were made of ≈øix-thread By≈ø≈øus: and that they came down to the Knees; where they were not gathered at the bottom, but ≈øat open.

Below which Breeches came down the holy Meil or Robe, upon the Skirts whereof hung round about Bells made of pure Gold, XXVIII. Exod. 34. Which may po≈ø≈øibly be the Ba≈øis of fine Gold, here mentioned, to which the Femoralia, or Garments on the Thighs, reached. Some refer all this only to his ≈øtately gate, and Princely motion: others to his ≈øtrength and firmne≈øs (which lies much in the Thighs) and his ability to march again≈øt his Enemies, and pur≈øue them. And then the Sockets of fine Gold are his Sandals, bound upon his feet with golden Ribbands, or ≈øomething of that nature. The Reader may chu≈øe which he thinks mo≈øt probable, for the explication of the fir≈øt Part of this Ver≈øe, His legs (or thighs rather) are as pillars of marble ≈øet upon ≈øockets of fine Gold.

Now if my conjecture be allowed, then the latter part of the Ver≈øe will not be hard to explain. For this and all the re≈øt of his habit being contrived for Beauty and Glory, as was ≈øaid before from XXVIII. Exod. 40. it made the High Prie≈øt appear with an unu≈øual Maje≈øty: the riches of the≈øe Ve≈øtments being not ea≈øily to be valued. And ≈øo his countenance, or rather his a≈øpect, his whole
appearance (as the Hebrew Word may ≈øignifie) was as ≈øtately as Lebanon. Which was one of the goodlie≈øt Sites in tho≈øe Countries both for Cedars; and many other things: e≈øpecially after Solomon had made his Garden there, of which we read in the foregoing Chapter, ver. 15, 16.

Unto which lovely Fore≈øt and Garden, the appearance of the High Prie≈øt may be the better compared; becau≈øe there were Flowers, as well as Pomegranates, if we may believe Philo (in his third Book of the Life of Mo≈øes) wrought in the bottom of the holy Robe. Which the LXX al≈øo affirm in expre≈øs Words; that there was „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , a flowry Work, as well as Pomegranates and Bells in the Hem of the Meil, XXVIII. Exod. 34. And indeed the Pomegranates being made of Wool of divers colours, they them≈øelves might look like divers ≈øorts of Flowers. And, be≈øides this, it is to be ob≈øerved that ≈øeveral other parts of the High Prie≈øt's habit are peculiarly commanded to be made of a Work called Cho≈øcheb, which we tran≈ølate cunning work. Thus the Ephod is ordered to be wrought, XXVIII. Exod. 6. and the Girdle of it, ver. 8. and the Brea≈øt plate, v. 15. Which ≈øome tran≈ølate artificial, others ingenious work: and all agree to have con≈øi≈øted in certain beautiful Figures of Flowers, and Animals; and in variety of colours. The Girdle moreover is ordered to be made of a Work called rokem, which we tran≈ølate needlework, ver. 39. becau≈øe it is thought not to have differed from the former, ≈øave only in this; that the other things were only woven curiou≈øly, but this al≈øo curiou≈øly wrought with the Needle. The Jews give another difference; that this was wrought ≈øo that the Figures appeared on both ≈øides, the other only on one. About which I ≈øhall not trouble my ≈øelf, but only take notice that Jo≈øephus (in his third Book of Antiquities,
Chap. 8.) explains this Work thus, Flowers were woven in this Girdle, with Scarlet, Purple, Blue, &c.

And if Flowers, and (as others ≈øay) Animals, then in all probability, Trees al≈øo were wrought in the≈øe Prie≈øtly Ve≈øtures: which made the fuller repre≈øentation of a Fore≈øt. Among which that of Lebanon was the principal, and indeed the mo≈øt beautiful place in all tho≈øe Countries, which made the Prophet expre≈øs the Glory of the Church in the≈øe Words, The Glory of Lebanon ≈øhall be given to it, XXXV. I≈øai. 2. ≈øee al≈øo XIV. Ho≈ø. 5, 6, 7.
Some think that hereby only the tallne≈øs of his Stature is denoted; which was always lookt upon as a Princely thing, as it was in Saul.

As for my≈øtical applications of the≈øe two Ver≈øes, there are none to be ≈øought for, if I have given the true ≈øen≈øe of them, but ≈øuch as relate to the excellency of Chri≈øt's everla≈øting Prie≈øthood; and its preheminence above the other, as much as the Cedar excells all the Trees of the Forest.

[q] V. 16.] There is little difficulty here. For mouth (Hebrew palate, which is within the mouth) can ≈øignifie nothing but either his words which come from thence, or his breath. And words being mentioned before, v. 13. the latter is probably here intended. Which is ≈øaid to be ≈øweetne≈øs, nay ≈øweetne≈ø≈øes: denoting the perfect ≈øoundne≈øs of the internal parts; as the foregoing de≈øcription ≈øets forth the excellent ≈øhape, and stately Vesture of the outward: It is applied by Interpreters, to the purity of Christ's affections and pa≈ø≈øions: but may be, as well, to his breathing upon his Apostles, when He bid them receive the Holy Ghost. Which concluded, in a manner, what He did upon Earth, as it doth his de≈øcription in this place. For ≈øhe finding his Prai≈øes to exceed all her thoughts, ≈øumms up all in a breath; and comprehends
his whole Character in this: that He is all over lovely; attracting all mens affections; not only tho≈øe that ≈øaw Him, but tho≈øe that heard of Him too.

argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: In the foregoing de≈øcription, the Spou≈øe expre≈ø≈øed ≈øuch an unfeigned affection to Him (which ≈øhe again confidently a≈ø≈øerts in this ≈øixth Part of the Song, v. 3.) that it not only mightily moved her Companions to join with her in the ≈øearch of Him, but invited the return of the Bridegroom again. Who graciou≈øly declares the like affection unto her (from v. 4. to the 11th) in ≈øuch Words as ≈øhowed that his kindne≈øs remained unalterable; and that He delighted in none but her: as incomparably more amiable, even by their own confe≈ø≈øion, than all tho≈øe Beauties whom the World mo≈øt admires. With which kindne≈øs ≈øhe is ≈øo ravi≈øhed, that it ≈ønatches her away from the deare≈øt Friends ≈øhe had, though very de≈øirous of her Company, ver. 12, 13.

div.head: Companions, or Daughters of Jeru≈øalem.
div.p: 1. WHither is thy beloved gone, O thou faire≈øt among women? whither is thy beloved turned a≈øide? that we may ≈øeek him with thee.

1. THe≈øe are high commendations indeed, which thou give≈øt to thy Beloved, which make us in love with Him, as before we were (IV. 9.) and ≈øtill are with thee, O thou mo≈øt lovely of all other Women: whither do≈øt thou think He hath betaken him≈øelf? He is not quite gone away, ≈øure, but
only diverted into ≈øome retirement; which way did He go? And where do≈øt thou gue≈øs He hath hidden Him≈øelf, that we may go along, and enquire Him out, with thee? See Annot. [a].

div.head: Spou≈øe.
div.p: 2. My beloved is gone down into his garden, to the beds of ≈øpices, to feed in the gardens, and to gather lilies.

2. I heard my Beloved ≈øay, that He was gone down into that Garden, which He him≈øelf hath planted (V. 1.) there He delights to be, among tho≈øe pious per≈øons; who≈øe Vertues make them like to the Garden-Beds, that are full of Spices: He is always pre≈øent in every part of this happy Company; and hath fellow≈øhip with them; and is daily adding more and more pure and ≈øincere Souls, who are without all guile, unto their Society. See Annot. [b].
3. I am my beloveds, and my beloved is mine: he feedeth among the lilies.

3. Of which I being a Member, hope I may ≈øtill ≈øay, that He hath not ca≈øt me out of his favour; but ≈øtill retains a kindne≈øs for me: becau≈øe I am ≈øtedfa≈øt and faithful in my love to Him; who takes a con≈øtant care of ≈øuch as ≈øtudy to re≈øemble Him. See Annot. [c].

div.head: Bridegroom.
div.p: 4. ¬∂ Thou art beautiful, O my love, as Tirzah, comely as Jeru≈øalem, terrible as an army with banners.

4. It is true, O my Beloved Friend, who art ≈øtill dear unto me and mo≈øt amiable in my eyes: I have not lo≈øt my e≈øteem of thee; for I ≈øee thou ha≈øt not lo≈øt thy affection to me: nor that lovely, that decent and comely order, which makes thee not only beautiful, but venerable; nay, amazes all Beholders, or, at lea≈øt, ≈øtrikes them with great admiration of thee. See Annot. [d].
5. Turn away thine eyes from me, for they have overcome me: thy hair is as a flock of goats that appear from Gilead.

5. Thou need≈øt not look ≈øo earne≈øtly, and with ≈øuch care and ≈øolicitude,
upon me, as if I had forgotten thee: for I ≈øee the ≈øame ≈øparkling Beauty in thy eyes, which I did before (IV. 1.) and it no le≈øs affects my heart (IV. 9.) thou wante≈øt none of tho≈øe Ornaments which I formerly commended, but retaine≈øt them all, notwith≈øtanding the di≈øcompo≈øure, in which thou ha≈øt been. See Annot. [e].
6. Thy teeth are as a flock of ≈øheep, which go up from the wa≈øhing, whereof every one beareth twins, and there is not one barren among them.

6. The ≈øame I ≈øay al≈øo of thy Teeth, which are ≈øtill white and clean; even ≈øet both above and below; firm and ≈øound al≈øo; without any breach, or want of ≈øo much as one of them. See Annot. [f].
7. As a piece of a pomegranate are thy temples within thy locks.

7. And to be ≈øhort (and not to repeat every thing again) I ≈øee the ≈øame fre≈øh colour in thy Cheeks; which makes thee look as lovely how thy Veil is off (V. 7.) as thou did≈øt in the fir≈øt blooming of thy Beauty. See Annot. [g].
8. There are three≈øcore queens, and fore≈øcore concubines, and virgins without number.

8. Wherefore, tho' other Kings and Princes of the≈øe Countries, have a great many Queens, and more Wives, of an inferiour Rank, and Virgins that attend them without number: who≈øe Beauty they highly admire; See Annot. [h].

9. My dove, my undefiled is but one; ≈øhe is the onely one of her mother, ≈øhe is the choice one of her that bare her: the daughters ≈øaw her, and ble≈ø≈øed her; yea, the queens and the concubines, and they prai≈øed her.

9. I have one only, and none other, whom I entirely love; and that is thy ≈øelf alone: who pre≈øerve≈øt an inviolable faith and affection to me, and therefore art dearer to me, than an only Daughter (and ≈øhe the mo≈øt accompli≈øhed per≈øon and perfect
beauty) is to her Mother: Whom all other per≈øons at la≈øt ≈øhall admire; the Queens them≈øelves beforenamed, calling thee Ble≈ø≈øed and wi≈øhing all pro≈øperity to thee; and they of the next degree ≈øhall prai≈øe thy excellencies, and confe≈øs their own imperfections; See Annot. [i].
10. ¬∂ Who is ≈øhe that looketh forth as the morning, fair as the moon, clear as the ≈øun, and terrible as an army with banners?

10. Saying, What an a≈øtoni≈øhing Beauty is this, that appears like a clear Morning after a dark Night, and encrea≈øeth in lu≈øtre more and more; looking as bright as the Moon when it is at Full, nay, as ≈øplendid as the Sun, when it ≈øhineth in its ≈øtrength: and no le≈øs dazles our eyes, and amazes our thoughts, than the Glorious Ho≈øt of Heaven; or an Army here on Earth, when it ≈øtands in Battalia's with all their Colours di≈øplay'd? See Annot. [k].
11. I went down into the garden of nuts, to ≈øee the fruits of the valley, and to ≈øee whether the vine flouri≈øhed, and the pomegranates budded.

11. Only this I expect from thee, that thou bring forth fruit proportionable to my care of thee, and kindne≈øs to thee: for to that end I went down before (V. 1. VI. 2.) and now go again into my Garden (which I have not neglected to dre≈øs and prune and water) to take a view in what condition it is; and in what forwardne≈øs the ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Fruit are, which I ju≈øtly look to receive in their due ≈øea≈øons. See Annot. [l].

div.head: Spou≈øe.
div.p: 12. Or ever I was aware, my ≈øoul made me like the chariots of Ammi-nadib.

12. Ala≈øs! what am I, that I ≈øhould receive ≈øuch prai≈øes, who am not worthy of thy care? But they have put ≈øuch motions into my ≈øoul, as make me aim at the highe≈øt perfections; and make all the ha≈øte I can likewi≈øe to attain them: And therefore I mu≈øt, for the pre≈øent, take leave of you, O
my Friends, who have kindly a≈ø≈øi≈øted me, in the ≈øearch of my Beloved. See Annot. [m].

div.head: Companions.
div.p: 13. Return, return, O Shulamite, return, return that we may look upon thee; what will ye ≈øee in the Shulamite? as it were the company of two armies.

13. Let us have thy Company again, O thou faire≈øt, and mo≈øt accompli≈øhed of all the Daughters of Jeru≈øalem. Come back again, come back, that we may behold thy wondrous perfections. And if any ask, What is that you would ≈øee? What would you enjoy in her happy Society? Our An≈øwer is, ≈øuch a Divine pre≈øence, as appeared to Jacob, when he ≈øaw the Angelical Choires; which made him cry out, This is God's Ho≈øt, and call the name of that place, Mahanaim. See Annot. [n].

div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p: [a] Ver≈øe 1.] The Daughters of Jeru≈øalem (mentioned V. 8.) here ju≈øtifie what the Spou≈øe had ≈øaid in the Conclu≈øion of the former Chapter: And declaring them≈øelves in love with Him whom ≈øhe had de≈øcribed, are de≈øirous to join them≈øelves to her Company, and go in que≈øt of Him. In order to which, they would know, Whither ≈øhe thought He was gone, when He went from her.

[b] V. 2.] Unto which ≈øhe replies in this Ver≈øe, and ≈øeems to tell them, in his own Words, what ≈øhe had heard Him ≈øay about that matter, V. 1. And it ≈øignifies, that He was ≈øtill in his Church, and in every part of it; though ≈øometimes they were not ≈øen≈øible of it. For ≈øo Theodoret well ob≈øerves, here is di≈øtinct mention made of a Garden and of Gardens. i. e. of the Catholick Church, which is but one, and of the ≈øeveral parts thereof. For
≈øometimes St. Paul mentions only the Church in the Singular, Number, and ≈øometimes the ≈øeveral Churches, even in the ≈øame Nation (as in the Epi≈øtle to the Galatians, I. 1.) and in the ≈øame Province, or City, 1 Cor. XIV. 34.

He is ≈øaid here to go down into his Garden, with re≈øpect to the Mountains mentioned IV. 8. And to feed, in the Hebrew, is either to do the Office of a Shepherd to his Flock; or relates to his Communion with his people, mentioned Chap. IV. 16. V. 1. Which may be the meaning al≈øo of gathering Lilies: or, as Theodoret will have it, by this la≈øt Clau≈øe, is to be under≈øtood, his gathering holy and pure Souls, that are like Him, and joyning them unto his Church. And ≈øo the Arabick Tran≈ølation is, to gather together the Lilies; following the Septuagint, who tran≈ølate it, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . And indeed I find the Hebrew Word lakat ≈øignifies to collect things into an Heap or Bundle; as Stones, XXXI. Gen. 46. Manna, XVI. Exod. 27. Fruit, XIX. Lev. 9. Silver, XLVII. Gen. 14.

The whole denotes, that Communion with Him is only to be ≈øought in his Church: e≈øpecially in that part of it, which pre≈øerves the Order, wherein He hath di≈øpo≈øed all things (like the Walks and Beds in a Garden) and keep them≈øelves al≈øo in the purity of his Religion.

[c] V. 3.] Now ≈øhe ≈øeems to have ≈øo perfectly recovered her ≈øelf out of the ≈ølumber wherein ≈øhe had been, as to have regained her former ≈øen≈øe of Him, and of her intere≈øt in Him: repeating tho≈øe Words which we met withal before, Ch. II. 16. Of the latter part of which [he feedeth among the Lilies] I think fit here further to note, that to feed may relate either unto Him≈øelf, or unto others: for there are Examples of both. Of the former, XLI. Gen. 2. I. Job 14. Of the latter, XXIX. Gen. 7, 9.
XXXVII. 12. I take it here rather in this latter ≈øen≈øe, and ≈øuppo≈øe it ≈øignifies his doing the Office of a Shepherd: and that he is ≈øaid to feed among the Lilies, as in the Revelation, to walk in the mid≈øt of the ≈øeven Candle≈øticks, i. e. there to have his conver≈øation, to take up his abode with them, &c. as He often ≈øaith in the Go≈øpel of St. John (XIV. 23.) that He would with tho≈øe, who love Him and keep his Commandments.

And ≈øuch per≈øons are here compared to Lilies; which being a name given by Chri≈øt to Him≈øelf, Greg. Ny≈ø≈øen and Theodoret hereby, not unfitly, under≈øtand, ≈øuch as are conformed to Chri≈øt their Head, and have his Image wrought in their Souls, in righteou≈øne≈øs and true holine≈øs. For, ≈øaith the former of them, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , &c. what≈øoever things are true, what≈øoever things are hone≈øt, what≈øoever things are ju≈øt, &c. (≈øee IV. Philip. 8.) „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the≈øe are the Lilies in which Chri≈øt delights.

[d] V. 4.] And now we mu≈øt conceive, either that they went to the Garden together, and there found Him; or that He hearing this hearty profe≈ø≈øion of unmoveable love to Him, meets them: and, to revive her drooping Spirits, falls again into a new commendation of the Spou≈øe; in the very ≈øame terms as before, and in ≈øome higher.

And fir≈øt He compares her to Tirzah, which was a beautiful Situation, in the Country of Ephraim; and therefore made choice of after the≈øe times, by Jeroboam, for the Seat of his Kingdom: and ≈øo continued till the Building of Samaria, as we read 1 King. XIV. 17. XV. 21, 23. and ≈øeveral other places: to which add XII. Jo≈øh. 24. The very original of the Word ≈øignifies; as much as Urbs amabilis, or a City that plea≈øeth one: and therefore cho≈øen by one of the ancient Kings of Canaan for the place of his re≈øidence.

And le≈øt this ≈øhould not be high enough, He next compares her to Jeru≈øalem; which was the mo≈øt lovely place in the Territories of Judah, and indeed of the whole Country. And as ≈øhe had commended Him before not only for his Beauty, but Maje≈øty: ≈øo He doth here, in the la≈øt place, call her terrible as an Army ≈øtanding in Battalia's; ≈øtriking an awe, that is, into Beholders. [e] V. 5.] In this and the following Ver≈øes, He ≈øeems to de≈øcend to a particular de≈øcription of the ≈øeveral parts of her Beauty: as He had done before, Chap. IV. 1, 2, &c. And He doth it in the very ≈øame Words, for the mo≈øt part, to a≈ø≈øure her that He had ≈øtill the ≈øame E≈øteem of her and kindne≈øs for her: and that, notwith≈øtanding what had happened, it had not altered her ≈øo much, as to abate any thing of his affection; or to make her appear otherwi≈øe in his eyes than ≈øhe had done. [f] V. 6.] There is no difference between this Ver≈øe and that in IV. 2. but only in one Word; which alters not the ≈øen≈øe. And as harechelim, ≈øheep was to be fetcht from hence to ≈øupply the ≈øen≈øe there: ≈øo another Word, hakketzuboth, even ≈øhorn, is to be fetcht from thence to ≈øupply it here.

[g] V. 7.] This is al≈øo exactly the ≈øame with the latter end of the third Ver≈øe of the IVth Chapter. The LXX have al≈øo the fir≈øt part: but they might as well have added all that there follows; which is here omitted.

[h] V. 8.] Here, mo≈øt think, Solomon alludes to the number of his own Wives; who were fewer, they ≈øuppo≈øe, in the beginning of his Reign (as Bochartus him≈øelf gathers from the≈øe Words, in his Epi≈øtle to the now Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, p. 126.) and that then he compo≈øed this Song, before he let the Reins of his lu≈øt ≈øo prodigiou≈øly loo≈øe, as afterwards we read he did, 1 King. But it is not at all likely that he had ≈øo many as are here mentioned, while his mind was filled with ≈øuch Divine raptures as the≈øe: And therefore I ≈øuppo≈øe he alludes to the cu≈øtom of other Princes in the Ea≈øt; who, be≈øides their principal Wives that were ≈øolemnly e≈øpou≈øed and endowed, had al≈øo another ≈øort who were neither: and yet were Wives, called by the Hebrews Philag≈øhim, Concubines. And then three≈øcore and four≈øcore, are only a certain number for an uncertain; not the preci≈øe number of the≈øe Wives and Concubines. Theodoret thinks by the≈øe are my≈øtically intended, ≈øeveral Ranks of Chri≈øtians in the Church: ≈øome more, ≈øome le≈øs perfect: But they di≈øcour≈øe better, in my Opinion, who rather accommodate the≈øe to the ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Heretical and Schi≈ømatical Churches: ≈øome of which gloried in the multitude of their Followers, and in their wealth and ≈øplendour: but Chri≈øt hath only one Catholick Church, more glorious than them all put together; as it follows here in the next Ver≈øes. And thus, in effect, R. Solomon Jarchi, and ≈øome other Hebrew Expo≈øitors, under≈øtand the≈øe Words, with application to them≈øelves. Abraham and his Po≈øterity, ≈øay they, till the De≈øcendants from I≈ørael were three≈øcore in number (compared here to Queens.) [i] V. 9.] This Ver≈øe needs not much Explication: wherein the Spou≈øe is oppo≈øed to all the forenamed Beauties: who are con≈øtrained to confe≈øs her preheminence. The Hebrew word for one, ≈øignifies al≈øo onely: and an onely Child, is as much as a beloved Child: As appears by this, that „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ

It is in vain to enquire here, who is the Mother intended in this place: for his love is only compared to the love of a Mother toward ≈øuch an onely Daughter: who hath ingro≈ø≈øed, as we ≈øpeak, all the excellent qualities that are in any other per≈øon. [k] V. 10.] This ≈øome take to be the beginning of a new part of this Song; and Theodoret in particular here begins his IVth Book of Commentaries upon it: but I look upon the≈øe Words, as the prai≈øes and commendations, which the Queens and Concubines, before-mentioned, be≈øtow upon the Spou≈øe; with admiration and a≈øtoni≈øhment at her tran≈øcendent Beauty.

[l] V. 11.] This ≈øeems to be the voice of the Bridegroom declaring what returns He expected to his love. The Word agoz which we tran≈ølate Nuts (of which there were ≈øeveral kinds, ≈øome very rich, as the Pi≈øtick) is found only here: and by ≈øome is tran≈ølated ≈øhorn or cut; which I have not omitted

[m] V. 12.] The meaning of this Ver≈øe ≈øeems to be, that the Spou≈øe, hearing ≈øuch high commendations of her ≈øelf, both from Him, and from the per≈øons mentioned, v. 10; with great humility ≈øaith, that ≈øhe was not con≈øcious to her ≈øelf of ≈øuch perfections (for ≈øo the fir≈øt Words ≈øound in the Hebrew, I did not know it, or I did not think ≈øo) but is excited thereby to make the greate≈øt ≈øpeed to endeavour to pre≈øerve this Character He had given her; and to go along with Him into his Garden (which ≈øhe had neglected before, V. 2.) there to give a good account of her proficiency. For which end ≈øhe ≈øeems on a ≈øudden, to take leave of her Friends (who had been ≈øo charitable, as to go along with her to ≈øeek Him) that ≈øhe might, for ≈øome time, enjoy his Company alone: Which is the ground of their calling upon her to return, in the next Ver≈øe. [n] V. 13.] This Ver≈øe is the voice of her Companions or Friends; ≈øome of which wi≈øh for her coming back, that they might enjoy her Company again, and ≈øee how ≈øhe was improved: and the re≈øt ask what they expected to ≈øee in her? to which the other reply in the la≈øt Words, as it were the company, &c.

The repetition of the Word return, four times over, expre≈ø≈øeth their vehement affection to her, and their
de≈øires to have her Company again: whom they called Sulamith; as much as to ≈øay Jeru≈øalamith. For the name of that place, formerly was Salem, which carries peace in its ≈øignification; or, as others will have it, perfection: for Shalam in the ≈øecond Conjugation, ≈øignifies to fini≈øh, or perfect. And is a fit name here for the Church, the New Jeru≈øalem; built by Chri≈øt Him≈øelf. This ≈øeems to me a great deal more probable than the conjecture of Menochius, (L. III. de Repub. Hebr. C. XXI. n. 14.) who, becau≈øe Wives, when they were married, took the name of their Husband, thinks the Spou≈øe from Solomon had the name of Sulamith: which Aquila tran≈ølates „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , pacifick, i. e. Salomonidem. The Reader may follow which he likes be≈øt. Solomon ≈øeems to me not to have had re≈øpect to his own Spou≈øe in this Song.

To ≈øee or look upon her, ≈øignifies to enjoy her happy Society; and the benefit of her excellent Vertues and perfections. Gen. 2. as a token of God's ≈øpecial pre≈øence with him; and mo≈øt lively ≈øets forth the far more glorious pre≈øence of God, now in the Chri≈øtian Church. argument.head: ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Here begins, as I take it, a new part (which is the VIIth) of this Song; and reaches to Ver≈øe the eleventh. In which the Spou≈øe is repre≈øented returning again, as they de≈øired in the end of the foregoing Chapter: and, appearing in greater lu≈øtre than before, the Company of Friends who attended her, prai≈øe her beautiful perfections; in ≈øuch a de≈øcription as was made of them, Chap. div.head: ANNOTATIONS.
div.p: [a] Ver≈øe 1.] They who earne≈øtly ≈øolicited the return of the Spou≈øe, in the conclu≈øion of the former Chapter, ≈øeem now to have a view of her again; and prai≈øe her perfections in a new method; beginning at the feet, and ≈øo upward (whereas before, Chap.
